In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: ou full small and therto softe and rede
But sikirly she had a faire forhede
For hardly she was not vndergrowe
It was almoste a span brode as y trowe
Full fetise was here Cloke as y was ware
Of small corall a boute here arme she bare
A peire of bedys gaudid all with grene .
And thereon hynge a broche of golde full shene
On which was first writen a crowned . A .
And aftur . Amor vincit omia
A nother Nonne with hure had she
That was hure Chapleyne . and prestis the
A Monke there was . a faire for the Mastrie
An oute Rider that loved well venerie
A manly man to be an Abbot able
Full many a deynte hors had he in his stable
And when he rode men myght his bridell here
Gynglyng in a whistlyng wynde as clere
And eke as lowde as doith the Chapell Belle
There as this lorde was keper of the Selle
The rule of Seynte Maury or of Seynt Beneit
Bycause it was olde and somdell streit
This ilke Monke lete olde thynges pace
And hilde aftᵃ the newe worldisspace
He gave not of that texte a Pullyd hen
That seith that hunters ben none holy men
Ne that a Monke . whan he is rechelesse
Ys likenyd to a Fysshe that is waterlesse
This is to sayne . a Monke oute of his Cloystre
But that Texte hilde he not worth an Oystre
And y saide his opyniou was good
What shulde he stodye and make hym self wood
Vppon a boke in Cloystre all day to poure
Or swynke with his hondys and laboure
As Austyn haue bid the . hou shall the worlde be served
Let Austyn haue his swynke to hym reservid
Therefore he was a praunsoure a right
Greihoundys had he that weren full light
On prikkyng . and huntyng for the hare
Was all his lust for nothyng wolde he spare
I sawe his slevis purfilid at the honde
With grice . and that the fynest in the londe
And for to fasten his hode vnde his chyn
He hadde of golde wrought a full curious pyn
A love knot in the grettir ende there was
His hede was balled . that shone as eny glas
And eke his face . as he . had be anoynte
He was a lorde full fatte . and in gode poynte
Hys yeen stepe were . and rollyng in his hede
That stemed as a furneys of lede
His botys souple . his hors in grete state
Nowe certayne he was a faire prelate
He was not pale . as it were a payned goste
A fatte Swan lovid he . best of eny roste
His Palfraye was as broun as a berye
¶ A Frere there was eke a wantou and a merye
A lymytoure and a full solempne man
In the ordres .iiijᵒʳ. is none so well that can
So moche of dalyaunce and faire langage
He had made full many a faire mariage
Of yonge wymmen at his owne cost
Vn to his ordre he was a noble post
Full well belovid and famylier was he
With Frankelens oủere all in his Contre
And with worthy wymmen of the toun
For he had pouere of Confessyoun
As he saide hym self more than a Curate
For of his ordre he was licenciate
Full swetely harde he Confessioun
And plesaunt was his absolucioun
He was an easy man to yeve penaunce
There as he wist to haue agood petaunce
For vnto a pore ordre for to geve
Is signe that a man is well shreve
For yif he gave he durst make a vaunte
He wist well that aman was repentaunte
For many a man is so harde of harte
He may not wepe all though hym sore smarte
Therfore in stede of penaunce and prayer
Men moste geve silvir to the pore fryers
His Tipet was ay farshed full of knyvis
And pynnys for to geve faire wyvis
And certeynly he had a mery note
Well coude he synge and pley on Rote
Of yeddynges he bare vttirly the prise
His necke was white . as floure delise
Therto he was stronge . as a Champioun
He knewe the Taủernys . well in eủery Toun
And eủery hostler and Tapsterre
Better than a laser or Beggesterre
For vnto suche a worthy man as he
Accordith not as to his facalte
To haue with seke lazers acquayntaunce
It is not honest it may not avaunce
For to dele with suche poraile
But all with the Riche and Sellers of vitaile
And oủere all there profite shulde a rise
Curtays he was and lowly of servise
There was no man nowhere so vertuous
He was the best Begger in his hous
For though a widowe had not but a sho
So plesaunte was his In Principio
Yet wolde he haue a ferthyng or he went
His purchas was well bettre than his Rent
And rage he couth as it had ben a whelpe
In love days there coude he moche helpe
For there he was not like a Cloysterere
With a threde bare Cope as ys a scolere
But he was like a Mastere or a pope
Of double worsted was his semy Cope
Rounde as eny Belle . oute of the presse
Somwhat he lispyd for his wantounesse
To make his Englisshe swete on his tonge
And in his harpyng . whan that he had songe
His yeen twynklyd in his hede aright
As doith the sterres in the frosty nyght
This worthy lymytoure was clepid hubbard
A Marchaunte there was with a forked bar
In motle and high vppon an hors he sate
And on his hede a Flaundrisshe be hatte
His botes claspid faire and fetously
His resons he spake full solempnely
Sownyng alway the encres of his wynnyng
He wolde the See were kepte for eny thyng
Betwene Middilburgh and Orwell
Well coude he in Eschaunges Rentes sell
This worthy man full well his witte bisette
There wist no wight that he was in dette
So stedfastly did he with his goủernaunce
With his bargeynes and with his chevisaunce
Forsothe he was a worthy man with alle
But sothe to sayne y not what men hym calle
A Clerke there was of Oxonford also
That vnto logik had longe y go
And lene was his hors as it were a Rake
And he was not right fatte y vndertake
But lokid holowe . and therto sobirly
Full threde bare was his oủerest courtby
For as yit he hadde gete hym none benefise
He was not worldly to haue an offise
For hym was leủere to haue atte his beddes hede
xxᵗⁱ . bokys clad in blacke and rede
Of Aristotle and of his Philophie
Then riche Robys Fidell . or sawtrie
But all be it though . he were a Philosophre
Yit had he but litle golde in his cofre
But all that he from his frendys hente
On bokys and on lernyng he it spente
And besily gan for the soulys praye
Of them that gave hym wherewith to scolaye
Of stodye toke he moste cure and hede
Not a worde spake he more than was nede
And that was seyde in forme and reủerence
And shorte and quyk and full of high sentence
Sownyng in morall vertue was his speche
Gladly wolde he lerne and gladly teche
A Seriaunte of lawe there was ware and wis
That full often had bene atte . parvise
That was full riche of excellence
Discrete he was and of gre reủerence
He semed such his wordis were so wise
Iustise had he be full oftyn in assise
Bothe bi patent . and pleyne commyssiou
For his science and his high renown
Of Fees and Robes had he many one
So grete a purchasoure was nowhere none
All was Fee symple to hym in effecte
His purchasyng myght not be in suspecte
Nowhere so esy aman there nas
And yit he semed bisier than he was
In termys had he cas and domys alle
That fro the tyme of kynge willᵃm were falle
Therto coude he endite and make a thynge
There coude noman pynche at his writynge
And eủery statute coude he playne by rote
He rode but homly in a medley cote
Girt with a seint of silke with barres smale
Of his aray telle y no lengre tale
A Franklyn was in this companye
White was his berde . as is the daisye
Of his complexiou he was sangwyn
Well loved he by the morowe a soppe in wyn
To lyve in delite was eủere his wone
For he was Epicurious owne sonne
That hilde opynyou that pleyne delite
Was verraye . Felitite parfite
An householdre and that a grete was he
The grettist on of all his Contre
His brede his ale . was alway aftur one
A better vyned man was nowhere none
Withoute Bakemete was neủere his house
Off fysshe and flesshe and that so plenteuouse
It snewed in his house of mete and drynke
Of all deyntees that eny man can thynke
Aftur the sondry seasons of the yere
So chaunged he his mete and his soper
Full many a fatte partriche had he in mue
And many a Breme and many a luce in Stue
Woo was his Coke but yif his sause were
Poynaunt and sharpe and redy all his gere
His table dormant in his halle alway
Stode redy coủeryd all the longe day
Atte the cessions there was he lorde and Syre
Full oftyn tyme he was knyght of the Shyre
And an hanlaas and a Gipsiere all of silke
Hynge at his girdill as white as morowe mylke
A Shiref had he be and a Coıı̄unntoure
Was nowhere suche a worthy vauasoure
An habirdassher . and a Carpentere
A wever . a Dyer . and a Tapicere
And they were clothid all in one lyủereye
Of a solempne and a grete fraternytye
Full fresshe and newe here gere piked was
Here knyvis were not chapid with bras
But all with silvyr wrought full clene and well
Here Girdyls and here pouches eủery delle
Well semed eche of them a faire Burgeys
To sitte in the yelde hall vppon the deys
Eủeryche for the wisedom that he can
Was shaply to be an aldreman
For catell had they ynough and rente
And eke here wivys wolde it well assente
And elles certayne they weren to blame
It is full faire to be clepid Madame
And go to vigiles all a fore
And haue a mantell roially bore
A Coke they hadde with hem for the nonys
To boyle the Chykenys with the mary bonys
And pouder Marchant tarte and galyngale
Well coude he knowe a draught of londou ale
He coude roste . sithe . boyle . and frye
Make mortrewes and well bake a pye
But grete harme was it as thought me
That on his shynne a mormall had he
And Blaumangere made he with the bes
A Shipman there was that wd ferre by west
For ought that y wote he was of dertmouth
He rode vppon a Rouncy as well as he couth
In a gowne of faldyng vnto the kne
A dagger hangyng with a lace had he
A boute his necke vnder his arme a doun
The hote Some had made his hewe al broun
And certeynly he was a good felawe
Full many a draught of wyne had he drawe
From Burdeuxwarde while the Chapmen slepe
Of nyce conscience toke he no kepe
Yif that he faught . and had the higher hande
By watere he sente it home from eủery lande
But to rekyn well of his crafte the tydes
The stremes and the strondes hym besides
His herborowe his mone and his lodes manage
There was none suche from hull of Cartage
Hardye he was and wise y vndertake
With many a tempest . had his berde be shake
He knewe all the havyns as they were
Fro Goutlonde to the Cape of Fenestere
And eủery kryke fro Brutaygne in to Spayne
His Barge was clepid the Magdeleyne
¶ With vs there was a doctor of Phisike
In all this worlde was none hym like
To speke of phisik and of surgery
For he was groundid in Astronomye
He kepte his pacient . a full grete dell
In houris by his magik naturell
Well coude he fortune the ascendent
Of his ymagis . for bi his pacient
He knewe the cause of eủery maladye
Whether it were colde hote moyst or drye
And whereof it engendrid and of what humoure
He was a verrey parfite practisoure
The cause he knewe . and of his harme the Rote
Anon he gaf the sikman his Bote
Full redy had he all his Appoticaries
To sende hym dreigges . and his lettuaries
For eche of them made other for to wynne
Here Frenship was not newe to begynn
Well knewe he the olde Esculapius
And Diastorides and eke Rufus
Olde ypocras and Galien
Serapiou Basis and Auicien
Amerois Damastien and Constantyn
Bernardus Gatisden . and Gilbertyn
Of his diet mesurable was he
For he was of none suꝑperfluyte
But of grete norisshyng and digestible
His stody was but litle on the bible
In Sangwyn and in peers clad with all
Lyvid with Taffitta and Sendall
And yet he was but easy of dispence
For he kepte that he wan in the pestlence
For golde in phisike is accordiall
Therfore he lovid golde in speciall
A good wyf the was . of beside Bathe
But she was somdele deef . and that was scathe
Of Clothe makyng . she had suche an haunte
That she passed hem of ypres and of Gaunte
In all the parisshe wif was ther none
That to offryng a fore hure shulde gone
And yif ther did certayne so wroth was she
That she was oute of alle cherite
Here kerchefs weren of fyne grounde
I durst swere they weyd a pounde
That on the sonday were vppon here hede
Here hosyn were of fyne scarlet rede
Full streite tyed and shone moyst and newe
Bolde was hure face faire and rede of hewe
She was a worthy womman all hure lyve
Husbondes atte the Churche dore had she fyve
Withoute other compaignye in hure youthe
But thereof nedith nedith not to speke of noughte
And thrise had she be at Ierlme
She had passed many a straunge streme
At Rome had she be and at Babiloyne
In Galice at Seynte Iames and at Coleyne
She coude of moche wandryng by the wey
Gaptothed was she the sothe to se
Vppon an Amblere easely she satte
Well y wympled and on hure hede an hatte
As brode at it were a bokelere or a targe
A fote mantell a boute hure heppis large
And on hure fete a peyre of sporys sharpe
In felauship coude she laugh and carpe
The remedyes of love the coude ꝑperchaunce
For of that arte she knewe the olde daunce
A good man there was of Religyoun
That was a ꝑpersoıı̄un of a poure toun
But riche he was of holy thought and werke
He was also a lerned man d and a Clerke
That Cristes gospell truly wolde teche
His parisshynes deuoutly wolde he preche
Benygne he was and wondre diligent
And in adủersite full abidyng and pacient
For which he was preysed often sithis
Full lothe were hym to curse for his tithis
But rather wolde hem yeve oute of doute
Vnto his pore parisshenes a boute
Of his offryng and eke of his substaunce
He coude haue yn litle thyng suffisaunce
Wyde was his parisshe and houses ferre a sondre
But he ne lette not for Reyne ne for thondre
In sekenesse and in myschief to visite
The ferthest in his parisshe moche and lite
Vppon his fete . and in his hande a staff
This noble ensample to his shepe he yaff
That furst he wrought and afturwarde taught
Oute of the gospell he tho wordys raught
And this figure he added eke therto
That yif golde rustyd . what shulde Iron do
For yif apreste be foule on whom we trust
No wondre is though a lewid man rust
And shame it is yif a preste take kepe
A shetyn Shepherd and a clene shepe
Well aught a preste ensample for to yeve
By hys clennesse hou his shepe shulde leve
He sette not his benefice for to hire
Ant lette his shepe . accombred be in the myr
Ne renne to londoıı̄un to seynte Poules
To seche hym a Chauntry there for Soules
Or be with a Brotherhood witholde
But dwell atte home . and kepe well his folde
So that the wolf make it not myscarye
He was a Shepherde . and not a mersionarye
And though he holy were and vertuouse
He was not with symple men dispitouse
Ne of his speche daungerous ne digne
But in his speche discrete and benygne
To drawe folke to heven by fairenesse
By good ensample this was his bisynesse
But and he knewe eny ꝑpersone obstynate
Whether he were of high or lowe estate
Hym wolde he snebbe sharpely for the nonys
A bettre preste y trowe nowhere none ys
He waytith aftᵃ no pompe ne reủerence
Ne made hym a spiced conscience
But Cristis lore and his a Postels twelf
He taught but furst he did it hym self
With hym there was a plough man his brothere
That had lad of dunge many a fothere
A true Swynker and a good was he
Lyvyng in pees and ꝑperfite Charite
God lovid he best . with all his hole herte
At all tymes though he gamed or smerte
And than his nyghtboure right as hym self
He wolde thresshe and eke dike and delf
For cristis sake for eủery poure wight
Withoute hire yif it lay in his myght
His tythis payde he full faire and wele
Bothe of his ꝓpropre swynke and of his catele
In a Tabard he rode vppon a meere
¶ There was also a Reve . and a Mellere
A Sompnoure and a Pardonere also
A Manciple ⁊and my self there were nomo
The Miller was a stoute carle for the nonys
Full bigge he was of body and of bonys
That previd well . for wher eủere he cam
At the wrastlyng he wolde haue the Ra
He was shorte shuldrid brode . and a thicke knarre
There was no dore but he wolde lift of harre
Or breke it at a rennyng with his hede
His berde . as eny Sowe or fox was rede
And therto brode as it were a spade
Vppon the coppe . of the nose he hadde
A werte and theruppon stode a tufte of heris
Redde as the brystillys of a Sowes erys
His nose thrillys blacke were and wide
A Swerde and a Buklere he bare by his side
His mowth was as grete as a furneis
He was a Iangler and a Golyardeis
And that was moste synne and harlotries
Well coude he stele corn and stele thries
And yit he had a thombe of gold ꝑparde
A white Cote and a blewe hode wered he
A Bagpipe well coude he blowe and sowne
And therewith all he brought vs oute of towne
¶ A gentill Manciple there was of a Temple
Of which all Catours myght take an example
For to be wise in beyng of Vitaille
For whethir he payde or toke by taille
Ay wayted he so in his accate
That he was ay bifore and in good estate
Nowe is not that of god a full faire grace
That suche a lewede mannys witte shall pace
The wisedom of an hepe of lerned men
That mastres haue hadde mo than thrise ten
That of lawe weren experte and curyouse
Of which there were . an . xijelf . in an house
Worthy to be Stuardys of Rente and londe
Of eny lorde that is in Englonde
To make hym lyve by his ꝓpropre good
In honoure doutlesse but yif he were wood
Or lyve as scarsly as hym lust desire
And able to helpe all a Shire
In many cas that myght falle or happe
And yit this Manciple set theire althir cappe
The Reve was a sclendre colerikman
His berde was shave as nygh as eủere he can
His here was by his eeris full rounde shorn
His toppe was dockid like a preste bifor
Full longe were his leggis and full lene
Like a staff there was no calf sene
Well coude he kepe a Garner and a bynne
There was none Auditor couth on hym wynne
Well wist he by the drought and by the reyne
The yeldyng of his corne and of his greyne
His lordys shepe his Neete his deyrie
His swyne his hors his store and his pultrie
Was hooliche in this Reves goủernyng
And by his couenaunt he yave the rekenyng
Sith that his lorde was . xxᵗⁱ . yere of Age
There coude noman brynge hym a in a rerage
There was no Balyf herde ne other hyne
That he ne knewe here sleight and here covyne
They were drad of hym as of the dethe
His wonnyng was faire vppon an hethe
With grene trees shadowed was his place
He coude better then his lorde purchace
Full riche he was storid privelye
His lorde he coude please full subtellye
To yeve and lene hym of his owne good
And haue a thanke and yit a gowne and a hood
This Reve sate vppon a well good stotte
All pomell gray . and he hight Scotte
Lerned he had in youth a good mystere
He was a good wright and a Carpentere
A longe surcote of peers a bove he hadde
And by his side he bare a lusty bladde
Of Nor Folke was this Reve of which telle
Besides a Towne men clepe Bladwelle
Tukkyd he was as is a Frere a boute
And eủere he rode hyndrest of the route
A Sompnoure there was with vs in tha place
That hadde a fyre rede cherubyns face
Full sausefleme he was with yeen narowe
As hote he was and erous like a sparowe
With scalled browes ke and pilled berde
Of his visage children were sore aferd
There was neyther litarge . quyk silủere . ne Brymston
Borace Ceruse ne Oyle of tartre noon
Ne oygnement that well can clense and bite
That hym myght helpe of his welkes white
Ne of the knobbes sittyng in his chekes
Well lovid he garlyk oynyouns and lekes
And for to drynke stronge wyne as red as blode
Than wolde he . speke and crie as he were wode
And whan that he well dronke the wyne
Than wolde he speke no worde but latyne
A fewe termys had he tweyne or thre
That he had lerned oute of som decre
No wondre ys he herde it all the day
And eke he knowe well hou that a Iay
Can clepe watte as well as can the pope
But who so clo coude in other thynges hym grope
Than had he spendid all his Philosophye
Ay questio quid Iuris wolde he crye
He was a gentill harlot and a kynde
A betre felawe shulde men nowhere fynde

As shortly as y can y will me haste
To telle you all the discripcion
Depeynted ben the walles vp̄ so doun
Of huntyng and of shame fast chastite
There sawe y hou wofull Calistrope
When that Dyane . aggrevid was with here
Was turned from a womman till abere
And aftur was she made the lode sterre
Thus was it peynted y can tell you no ferre
Hure sonne is eke as sterre as ye may see
There sawe y Dane turned untill a Tree
I mene not the goddes Dyane
But Penneus dought̉er which that hight Dane
There saugh y Atheon . an harte y maked
For Vengeaunce that he saugh Dyane all naked
I saugh hou that his houndes haue hym caught
And freten hym for that they knewe hym naught
Yit peynted was there a litel firthermore
Hou Athalant hunted the wilde bor
And Molagre and many other mo
For which Diane wrought hem care and wo
There sawe y many anothere wondre storye
The which me list not to drawe in \to/ memorye
This goddesse on an harte full hyghe she sete
With smale houndes all a boute hure fete
And vndernethe hure fete she hadde a mone
Wexyng it was and shulde wane sone
In gaude Grene here statue clothed was
With bowe in hande and Arowes in a cas
Hure yeen cast she full lowe A doune
There Pluto hath his derke Regioune
A womman travelyng was here beforn
But for hure childe was so longe vnborn
Full pitously lucyna gan she calle
And seide helpe for thou mayst best of alle
Well coude he peynte and lifly that hit wrought
With many a floreyne he the huys bought
Nowe byn thise listes made . and Theseus
That hath with grete cost arraied thus
The Temple and the Theatre eủery dell
When it was done hym liked wonder well
And stynte y will of Athenes A lite
And speke of Palamon and of Arcite
The day aproched of here retornyng
That eủeryche shulde an .C. knyghtis bryng
The bataile to derayne as y you tolde
And till Athenes here couenaunt for to holde
Hath eủeryche of them brought an .C. knyghtis
Well Armed for the werre yn all rightis
And sikyrly there trowed many a man
That neủere sith the worlde began
As for to speke of knyghthode of here honde
As fer as god hath made see and londe
Nas of so fewe so noble a companye
For eủery wight that loved chivalrye
And wolde his thanke have a passand name
Hath praide that he motte be at that game
And well was hym that therto chosen was
For yiff to morowe there fill suche a ca
Ye knowe well that eủery lusty knyght /
That lovith paramours and hath his myght
Were in Engelonde or elles where
They wolde here thankys wilnen to be there
To fight for a lady .A. Benedicite
Hit were a lusty sight forto se
And right so ferd they with Palamon
With hym there went knyghtis many on
Som will ben armed in an haberion
And in a brest plate and a light Gipon
And som woll haue plates large
And som woll haue a Pruce shelde and som a Targe
Som woll byn Armed on his legges well
And haue an axe and som a Mace of stell
There is no newe gise that it nas olde
Armed weren they as y haue you tolde
Eủeryche aftur his oppynyon
There mayst thou se com with Palamon
Lygurge hym self the grete kyng of Trace
Blacke was his berde and manly was his face
The sercles of his yeen in his hede
They glowedyn betwyxt yolowe and rede
And like a griffon loked he aboute
With kempte heres on his browes stoute
Hys lymmes grete his brawnes harde and stronge
His shuldres brode his Armes rounde and longe
And as the gise was in the Contreye
Full high on a Chare of golde stode he
With .iiii. white boles in the Traies
In stede of cote Armoure oủere his harneies
He had a beres skyn coll blak for olde
With nayles yeolowe and bright as eny golde
His longe here was kempte by hynde his backe
As eny Ravyns fether hit shou for blacke
A writhe of golde Arme grete of howge wyght
Vppon his hed set full of stones bright
Of fyne Rubies and Dyamauntes
A boute his Chare there went white Alauntes
.xxᵗⁱ. \and/ mo as white as any steere
To hunten at the lyon and at the dere
And folowid hym with mosell fast y bounde
Collers of golde and Turrettes filed round
An .C. lordes had he in his route
Armyd full well with hartis sterne and stoute
¶ With Arcita yn stories as y fynde
The grete Emetreus the kyng of ynde
Vppon astede bay trapped in stele
Coủeryd with clothe of golde diapred wele
Come ridyng like the god of Armes Mars
His Cote Armure was of cloth of Tars
Couchid with perles white rounde and grete
His sadell was of brende golde newe y bete
A Mantelet vppon his shuldre hangyng
Brette full of Rubies red as fire sparklyng
His crispe here lyke rynges was y ronne
And that was yeolowe and gleteryng as the sonne
His nose was high . his yeen bright citryn
His lippys rounde his coloure was sanguyn
A fewe frakyns yn his face y spreynt
Betwyxt yelowe and som dele blak meynt
And as a lyon his lokyng he cast
Of . xxv. yere his age y cast
His berde was well begon to spryng
His voyce was a Trumpe thundryng
Vppon his hede he werid a laurer grene
A garlond fresshe and lusty for to sene
Vppon his hande he bare for his delite
An Egle tame as eny lilye white
An hundred lordes had he with hym there
All armed save here hed and all here gere
Full richely yn all man̉ere thynges
For trusteth well that Dukes Erles and kynges
Were gadred in this noble companye
For love and for encres of Chivalrye
A boute this kyng ran on eủery parte
Full many a tame lyon and liparte
And ni this wise thise lordes all and somme
Ben on the Sonday to the Cite comme
Aboute pryme and in the toun a light
This Theseus this Duke this worthy knyght
When he had brought them in to the Cite
And Inned hem eủerych at his degre
He festeth hem . and doth so grete laboure
To esen hem and to do hem all honoure
That yit men wene that no mannes wit
Of none estate coude amenden hit /
The Mynstralcie the service at the feste
The grete yiftis to the leste and meste
The riche araye of Theseus Paleys
Ne who sate furst ne last on the deys
What ladyes fairest be or best daunsyng
Or whiche of them can pley best and syng
Ne who moste felyngly spekith of love
What haukys seten in the perche above
What houndes liggen in the flore a doun
Of all this nowe make y no mencioun
But all the effecte that thynkith me best
¶ Nowe comth the poynte herkeneth yif ye lest
The Sonday nyght er day gan to spryng
When Palamon hard the larke syng
All though it were not day by houres two
Yit songe the larke . and Palamon right tho
With hole herte . and with an high corage
He rose to wynden on his pilgrymage
Vnto the blisfull Citherea benygne
I mene Venus honorable and digne
And in hure houre he walkith furth a pas
Vnto the listes where the Temple was
And doun he knelith and with humble chere
And with herte sore he seide as ye shull here
¶ Fairest of faire .O. lady myne Venus
Dought̉er of ioue and spouse to Vlcanus
Thou gladdere of the mounte Citheron
For thilke love thou haddist to Adoon
Haue pite on my bittre teres smerte
And take myn humble praiere at thyn herte
¶ Alas y ne haue no langage to telle
Theffectis ne the turnement of myn helle
Myn herte may not myn harmes bewrey
I am so confuse y can not sey
But m̉ercy lady bright. that knowest well
My thought . and seest what harme y fell
Considre all this and rewe vppon my sor
As wisly as y shall for eủeremore
Hens furth my myght thy true seruᵃaunt be
And holde werre alway with Chastite
That make y nowe myn avowe so ye me helpe
I kepe not of A\r/mes for to yelpe
Ne axe not to morowe to haue victorie
Ne renoun in this cas ne veyne glorie
Or price of Armes . to blowen vp̄ and doun
But y wolde haue fully possessioun
Of Emelye . and die in thy ʆservice
Fynde thou the man̉ere hou and in what wice
I reckenat . but it better may be
To haue Victorie of hem or they of me
So that y haue my lady in myn Armes
For though it so be that Mars is god of Armes
Youre vertue is so grete in heven a bove
That yif you list y shall well haue my love
Thy Temple woll y worship̄ eủere mo
And on thyn Auter where y ride or go
I will do sacrifice and fires bete
And yif ye wol not so my lady swete
Then prey y the to morn with a spere
That Arcita thrugh the harte me bere
Then rek y nought when y haue lost my lyf
Though that Arcite wyn hure to his wyf
This ys the effecte and ende of my praiere
Yef me my love my blisful lady dere
Whan the orison was do of Palamon
His sacrifice he did and that anon
Ful pitously with all circumstaunces
All telle y not as nowe his obseruances
But at the last the Statue of Venus shoke
And made a signe where by that he toke
That his preiere accepted was that day
For though the signe shewed a delay
Yit wist he well that graunted was his bone
And with glad herte he wente hym hom sone
The .iiiᵈᵉ. houre in equall that Palamon
Be gan to Venus temple for to gon
Vp̄ rose the sonne . and vp̄ rose Emely
And to the Temple of Dyane gan hye
Hure maydenes that she thidder with hure hadde
Full redily with hem fire they hadde
The ensence . the clothes and the remenaunt all
That to the sacrifice longen shall
The hornes full of Meth as was the gise
There lackith not to don here sacrifise
Smokyng the Temple full of clothes faire
This Emelie with harte debonaire
Hure body wisshe with water of a well
But hou she did here right. y dar not tell
But it be eny thyngin in gen̉erall
And yit it were a game for to here all
To hym that meneth well it were no charge
But it is good . Aman be atte his large
Here bright here was kembed vntressed all
A cronet of a gre\ne/ oke ceriall
Vppon hure hede was sette well feire and mete
Two firis on the Auter gan she bete
And did here thynges as men may beholde
In Stace of Thebes . and thise bokes olde
When kendled was the fire with pitous chere
Vnto Dyane she spake as ye may here
O. Chast goddesse of the wodes grene
To whom bothe hevyn and Erthe and see is sene
Quene of the reigne of Pluto derke and lowe
Goddesse of Maydenes that myn herte hast knowe
Of many a yere and wost what y desire
As kepe me fro thy vengeaunce and thyn ire
That Atheon a bought cruelly
Chast Goddesse well wost thou that y
Desire to be a maiden all my liff
Ne neủere wolde be neither love ne wiff
I am thou wotist well. yit of thy compenye
A maide and love huntyng and venerye
And for to walkyn in the wodes wilde
And nat to be a wif and ben with Childe
Nought will y knowe company of man
Nowe helpe me lady sith ye may and ca
For the .iiiᵉ. fourmes that thou hast in the
And Palamon that hath suche love to me
And eke Arcite that loveth me so sore
This grace y prey the withouten more
As graunte love and peace betwixt hem two
And fro me turne a waye here hertis so
That all here hote love and here desire
And all here besye turnement and here fire
Be queynte or turned in to a nothere place
And yif so be ye will not do me grace
Or yif my destenye be shape so
That y shall nedes haue one of hem two
As sende me hym that moste desireth me
Beholde goddesse of clene chastite
The bittre teres that on my chekys falle
Syn thou arte mayde and keper of vs alle
My maidenhode thou kepe and well conserve
And while y leve a maide y woll the serve
The firis brenden on the Auter clere
While Emelye was thus in here praere
But sodenly she sawe a sight queynte
For right a non one of the firis queynte
And quycked ageyne and aftur that a non
That other fire was queynt and all a gon
And as it queynted it made a whistlyng
As doith thise wete brondes in here brennyng
And at the brondes ende oute ran a non
As it were blody dropes manyon
For which so sore agast was Emelye
That she was well nygh madde and gan to crye
For she ne wist what it signyfied
But only for the fere thus she cried
And wepte that it was pite for to here
And there with all Diane gon apere
With bowe in honde right as an huntresse
And seide dought̉er stynt thyn hevynesse
Amonge the goddesse high it is affermed
And by eterne worde. wreten and confermed
Ye shalbe wedded vn to the one of tho two
That haven for the so moche care and wo
But vnto whether first . y may not tell
Fare well y ne may no lengre dwelle
The fires which on myn Auter brenne
Shull the declaren or that thou go henne
Thyn aventure of love as in this plas
And with that worde the Arowes in the cas
Of the goddesse clat̉eryn fast and ryng
And furth she went and made vanysshyng
For which this Emelie a stonyed was
And seide what a mounteth this alas
I putte me fully in thy proteccyon
Diane ; and in thy disposicyon
And home she goith anon the nexte wey
This is the effecte there nys nomore to sey
¶ In the oure of Mars nexte folwyng aftur this
Arcite vnto the Temple walked is
Of fers Mars to do his sacrifise
With all the Rites of his payn gise
With pitous herte and hygh devocion
Right thus to Mars he seith his orison
O. strong god . that in the Regnes colde
Of Trace honoured arte and lorde y holde
And hast in eủery Regne and in eủery londe
Of Armes all the bridell in thyn honde
And hym fortunest as the list devise
Acceptith of me my pitous sacrifise
Yif so be my youth may deserve
And that my myght be worthy for to serve
Thy godhed . that y may be one of thyn
Then prey y the to rewe vppon my pyn
For thilke peyne and thilke hote fire
In which thou whilom brennest for to desire
Whan that thou vsedest the beaute
Of faire yonge venus fresshe and fre
And haddist hure in Armes at thy will
All though that on a tyme the mysse fill
When Vlcanus had caught the in his las
And founde liggyng by his wif allas
For thilke sorowe that tho was in thyn herte
Haue ruyth aswell vppon my peynes smerte
I am yonge and vnknowyng as thou wost /
And as y trowe with love offended most
That eủere was eny lyvis creature
For she that doth me all this wo endur
Ne reckith neither whether y synke or flete
And well y wote withouten helpe or she me m̉ercy hete
Of mot with streynth wyn hure in the place
And well y wote withouten helpe or grace
Of the. ne may my streynth nought a vaile
Than helpe me lorde to morowe in my bataile
For thilke fire that whilom brende the
Aswel nowe thilke fire brenneth me
And do that y to morowe haue victorie
Myn be the Traveill and thyn be the glorie
Thy soủerayne Temple woll y moste honouren
Of my place and alwey most labouren
And in thy plesaunce and in thy Craftis stronge
And in thy Temple y woll my baner honge
And all the Armes of my compenye
And eủeremore vnto that day y dye
Eterne fire y will beforn the fynde
And eke to this a vowe y will me bynde
My berde myn heere that hongith longe adoun
That neủere yit felte offensioun
Of Rasoure nor of Shere y woll the yeve
And be thy true servaunt while y leve
Nowe lorde haue rowthe vppon my sorowes sore
Yeve me the victorie. y aske the no more
The praire stynt of Arcita the stronge
The rynge on the Temple dore that honge
And eke the dores clateryn full faste
Of which Arcite somwhat hym agaste
The fires brenden vppon the Auter bright
That it began all the Temple to light
A swete smell anon the grounde vp̄ yaf
And Arcite anon his hande vp̄ haf
And more ensence vnto the fire he caste
With other rites mo . and at the laste
The statue of Mars began his hauberke rynge
And with that sowne he harde a murmurynge
Full lowe and dym . and seide thus Victorie
For which he yaf to Mars honoure and glorie
And thus with ioye and hope well to fare
Arcite anon vnto his sime is far
And fayne as the fowle is of the bright sonne
And right anon suche a strif there is be gonne
For thilke grᵃauntyng in heven above
Betwyxt Venus the goddesse of love
And Mars the sterne god omnipotent
That Iubit̉er was besye hit to stent
Till that the pale Saturnus the colde
That knewe so manye aventures olde
Founde in his owne exꝑperience an arte
That he full sone hath pleased eủery parte
As sothe ys seide: elde hath grete avauntage
In elde is bothe wisedom and vsage
Men may the olde oủere renne and not oủere rede
And saturne anon to stynte strif and drede
All be it that it be ageyne his kynde
Yit of the strif he gan remedie fynde
My dere dought̉er Venus quod Saturne
My cours that hath so wide a whele to turne
Hath more powere than wote eny man
Myn is the drenchyng in the See so wan
Myn is the prison in the derke Cote
Myn is the stranglyng and hangyng by throte
The murmur and the Churlys rebellyng
The groynyng and the prive swonnyng
Myn is the ruyne of the hygh halles
The fallyng of the Toures and of the walles
Vppon the mynoure or the Carpenter
I slough Sampson shakyng the peler
And myn ben the maladies colde
The derke tresons and castes olde
I do veiaunce and playne correccion
While that my dwellyng is with the lyon
My lokyng is the fader of pestilence
Nowe wepe no more y shall do my dilygence
That Palamon that is thyn owne knyght
Shall haue his lady as thou hast hym hight
Though Mars shall helpe his knyght nathelesse
Betwixt you there mot be som tyme pesse
All be ye not of one complexion
That causeth all day suche divisio
I am thyn ay redy atte thy will
Wepe nomore y will thy lust fulfill
¶ Nowe woll y stynt of the goddes above
Of Mars and of Venus goddes of love
And telle you as pleynly as y can
The grete effecte which that y began
¶ Grete was the feste at Athenes that day
And eke the lusty season of that May
Made eủeryche wight to be in suche plesaunce
That all that monday iusten they and daunce
And spenden it in Venus here servise
And by cause they shulde arise
Erely for to se the grete sight
Vnto there reste wente they at nyght
And on the morowe when that day gan spryng
Of hornes and harneis noyse and clateryng
There was in Ostleries all a boute
And to the paleys rode ther many a route
Of lordes vpon stedes and palfreys
There myghtest thou se divisions of ha\r/neys
So vncouth and so riche and wrought full well
Of Goldesmythrie of browdyng and of steell
The sheldes bright the Testers and Trappures
Golde huen helmes hauberkys and Cote Armures
Lordes Emparimentes of here Coursers
Knyghtis of retenue and eke Squyers
Naylyng the speres and helmes bokelyng
Gynglyng of sheldes with layners lasyng
There as nede was they were nothyng idle
The foomy stedes on the golden bridle
Armurers lokyng the Armure also
With file and hamur prikkyng to and fro
Yomen on fote and Comons many on
With shorte staves as thik as they may gon
Pipes Trumpes a nakerns and Clarious
That in Bataill blowen blody sowns
The paleys full of peples vp̄ and doun
There .iiiᵉ. there .x\ten/. holdyng here questioun
Denyng of thise Theban knyghtis two
Som seiden thus som seide it shulde be so
Som hilde with hym with the blacke berd
Som with the balled som with the thik hered
Som seide he loked grym and he will fight
He hath a Oparre of .xxᵗⁱ. pounde of wight
Thus was the hall full of divynyng
Longe aftur that the sonne be gan to spryng
The grete Theseus of slepe a waked
With mynstrelsye and noyse that was maked
Holdith yet the Chambre of his paleys riche
Till that the Theban knyghtis bothe y liche
Honorably were vnto the Paleys fet
Duke Theseus is in a wyndowe set
Araied richely as he were god in Trone
The people presith thidderward fulsone
Hym for to see and to do reủerence
And eke to herken his hest and his sentence
An herawld on a Scaffold made an hoo
Till all the noyse of the people was y doo
And when he sawe the people of noyse stille
Thus shewed he the myghty Dukes wille
The lorde hath of his high discression
Considred that it were grete destruccion
To gentill blode to fight in this gise
Of mortall bataill nowe in this emprise
Therfore to shapen that they shulde not dye
He will his furst purpos modifye
No man therefore vppon peyne of lost of lyf
No man̉ere pollax . ne shot. ne shorte knyf
In to the listes sende. ne thider bryng
Ne shorte swerde. for the stroke with poynt bityng
No man drawe ne bere it by his side
No man shall to his felawe ride
But .one. Cours with a sharpe growden spere
Foyne yif hym lyst hym self on fote to were
And he that is at myschief shall be take
And not slayne but brought to a stake
That shall be ordeyned on either side
But thider he shall by force and there to abide
And yif so befalle that the Chieftayne
Be take on either side other slayne
No longur shall the turmentyng laste
God spede you echon and leith on fast
With longe swerde and with mas fight youre fille
Goth nowe youre wey this is the lordes wille
The Voyce of the people touched heven
So loude cried they with mery steven
God salue suche a lorde that is so good
He wilneth no destruccion of blood
Vp goith the Trumpes and the melodye
And to the listes rideth all the companye
By ordinaunce thrugh the Cite large
Honged with clothes of golde and nat with sarge
Full like a lorde this noble Duke gan ride
Thise .iiᵒ. Thebanes vppon either side
And aftur rode the Quene and Emelie
And aftur that another companie
Of one. and other aftur there degre
And thus they passen thrugh the Cite
And to the listes camen they be tyme
Hit was not of the day fully pryme
When sette was Theseus full riche and hyghe
Ypolita the Quene and Emelie
And other ladies in degrees aboute
Vnto the setes preseth all the route
And westwarde thrugh gates vnder Marte
Arcite and eke the .C. of his parte
With baner redde is entred right anon
And in the same moment Palamon
Is vnder Venus Estward in the place
With baner white. and hardy there of face
In all the worlde to seken vp̄ and doun
So evene a companye withoute variacioun
There nere suche companyes twey
For there was none so wise that coude seye
That eny of other had a vauntage
Of worthynesse ne of estate and age
So evene were they chosen̄ for to gesse
And in .iiᵒ. Renges faire they hem dresse
When̄ that here names redde were eủerychone
That in here nombre gile was there none
And to were the yates shet and cried loude
Doth nowe youre devoure yonge knyghtis proude
The herawldes lefte here prickyng vp̄ and dou
Nowe blowen Trumpes lowde and Clarioun
There is nomore to sey but Est and West
In goth the spere full sadly in to the Rest
In goth the sharpe spore in to the side
There se men . who can. iust and who can ride
There sheveryn shaftis vppon the sheldys thikke
He felt thrugh the herte renne the prikke
Vp̄ spryngeth speres. xxᵗⁱ. fote on hight
Oute gon the swerdes as the siluyr bright
The helmes they to hewen and to shrede
Oute brestith the blode with sterne streames rede
With myghti Mas the bones they to brest
He thrugh the thikkist of the throng gan threst
There stomblen stedes stronge and doun goth all
He rolleth vnder fote as doith a ball
He foyneth on his fete with his Tronchoun
And he hym hurteth . with his hors a doun
He thrugh the body is hurte and than y take
Maugre. his hed and brought vnto the stake
As forward was. right there he most a bide
Another lad is on that other side
And som tyme doth hem. Theseus to rest
Hem to refresshe and drynkyn yif them lest
Full ofte on the day have thise Thebanes two
To gedre y mette and wrought his felawe wo
Vnhor fed hath sche other of hem tweye
There is no tigre in the vale of Galoniopheye
When that hure whelpe is stole while it is lite
So cruell on the hunte as is Arcite
For ielowse herte vppon this Palamon
Ne in wildernesse there is no lyon
That hunted ys or for his hungre wood
Ne of his pray desireth so his blood
As Palamon to sle his foo Arcite
The ielouse strokes on here helmes bite
Oute renneth blode on bothe here sides rede
Som tyme an ende there is of eủery dede
For er the sonne vnto rest wente
The stronge kynge Emetreus gan hente
This Palamon as he faught with Arcit
And made his swerde depe in his flesshe to bite
And by the force of .xxᵗⁱ. is he take
Vn yolden and y drawyn to the stake
And in the restons of this Palamon
The stronge kynge ligurge is born adown
And kynge Emetreus for all his streyngth
Ys born oute of his Sadle a swerdes leyngth
So hit hym Palamon or he were take
But all for naught. he was brought to stake
His hardy harte may hym helps hym naught
He moste a bide when that he was caught
By force and eke by composicion
Who sorowith nowe but wofull Palamon
That mote nomore go a geyne to fight
And when that Theseus hath seyne this sight
Vnto the folke. that fought yet echone
He cried hoo no more for it is done
I wilbe true Iugge and not partie
Arcite of Thebes shall haue Emelie
That be his fortune hath here faire y wonne
Anon there is a noise of folke begonne
For ioy of this so loude gren they alle
It semed as the listes shulde falle
What can faire Venus do nowe a bove
What seith she nowe. What doth this Quene of love
But wepith so for wantyng of here wille
Tille that hure teres in to the listes fille
She seide y am y shamed doutles
Saturnus seide dought̉er holde thy pes
Mars hath his will. his knyght hath his bone
And by my hede thou shalte ben eased sone
The Trumpers with the loude mynstralsie
The herauldes that full loude yelle and crie
Ben in here wele for ioy of daun Arcite
But herkneth me and stynteth noyse a lite
Which a Miracle there befele anon
This fers Arcite hath of his helme don
And on a Coursoure for to shewe his face
He priketh endelonge the large place
Lokyng vpward vppon Emeli
And she ageyne hym cast a frendelich ye
For wommen for to speke in Comune
Folowen gladly the fauoure of fortune
Therfore she was all his in chere and harte
Oute of the grounde sodenly a fire infernall upstarte
From Pluto sente at the request of Saturne.
Of which his hors for fere be gan to turne
And lepe a side and foundred as he lepe
And er that Arcita myght take kepe
He pight hym on the pomell of his hede
That in the place he lay as he were dede
His brest to brosten with his Sadle bowe
As blak he lay as eny cole or Crowe
So was the blode shoten in his face
Anon he was born oute of the place
With harte sore to Theseus Paleys
Tho was he corven oute of his harneys
And in a bed y brought full faire and elive
For he was as yet in memorie \and/ a live
And alway criyng aftur Emelye
Duke Theseus with all his companye
I comyn is home to Athenes his Cite
With all blisse and grete solempnyte
All be it that this a venture was falle
He nolde not discomforte wa hym at alle
Men seiden eke Arcite shulde nat dye
He shalbe heled of his maladye
And of a nother thyng they were as feyne
That of them all was the none slayne
All were they sore hurte and namely one
That with a spere was thrilled the brest bone
Two other woundes and .iiᵒ. broken armes
Som hadden salvis som hadden Charmes
Drynkys and herbes. and thynges that shulde hem save
They drynken for they wolde here lyves save
For which this noble Duke as he well can
Comfortith and honourith eủery man
And made Revell all the longe nyght
Vnto the straunge lordes as it was right
Ne there was holden no discomfetyng
But as iustyng or a turneyn
For sothely there nas no discomfiture
For fallyng is nat but a venture
Ne to ben hadde by force to the stake
Vn yolden and with .xxᵗⁱ. knyghtis take
A parsone all alone withouten moo
And haried furth by arme. by fote . by too
And eke his stede dreven furth \with/ stavys
Of fotemen both yemen and knavys
It was a rekened hym no vilanye
There may noman callen it a Cowardye
For whiche anon Duke Theseus lete crye
To stynten all rancoure and envye
The gre as well on one side as on other
And either side. like as eyther is brother
And yave hem yiftis aft̉er here degre
And fully hilde a feste days. thre
And conveyed the knyghis worthylie
And ledde hem oute of his Toune a iornay largelye
And hom wente eủeryman the right way
There ys nomore . but fare well haue good day
Of this bataile y woll nomore endite
But speke of Palamon and Arcite
Swelleth the brest of Arcite and the sore
Encresith at his harte more and more
The clotered blood for eny leche crafte
Coruptith and is in his hely laste
That no vayne blode nether ventisyng
Ne drynke of herbes . may ben his helpyng
The vertue expulsif or adinvalle
Fro thilke vertue y clepid naturalle
Ne may the venym voide ne expelle
The pipes of his longes gon to swelle
And eủery lacerte in his brest a doun
Is shente with venym and corupcion
Hym geyneth neủere for to haue his lif
Neither upward vomet nor dounward laxatif
All is to broken thilke regioun
Nature ne hath no domminacioun
And certaynlye there that nature will not werche
Farewell fysik go bere the man to cherche
This is all and som that Arcita motte dy
For which he sendith aftur Emelye
And Palamon that was his Cosyn dere
And thus he seide as ye shull here
Nat may the wofull sprite in myn herte
Declare on poynte of all my sorowys smerte
To you my lady that y love moste
But y be quethe the servise and my goste
To you above eny creature
Syn that my lyf may no lenger dure
Allas that wo . Allas that peynes stronge
That y for haue suffred so longe
Allas that deth . Allas myn Emelie
Allas departyng of youre companye
Allas myn hertes Quene Allas my lif
Myn hertis lady ender of my lif
What ys this woorlde . what axeth men̄ to haue
Nowe with his love . nowe in the colde graue
Alone withouten eny companye
Farewell my swete lady Emelye
And softe takith me in youre Armes tweye
For love of god . and herkneth what y seye
I haue here with my Cosyn Palamon
Had strif and Rancoure many a day agon
For love of you and for my Ielousie
And iubiter so wis my soule gie
To speke of a seruᵃaunt ꝓpropirly
With all circumstaunces truly
That ys to sey of trueth. honoure and knyghthede
Wisedom humblesse estate and high kenrede
Fredom and all that longeth to that arte
So iubiter haue of my soule parte
And in this worlde right nowe knowe y non̄
So worthy to beloved as is Palamon
That servith you. and don well all his lif
And eủere that ye shall ben a wif
Forgetenot Palamon the gentilman
And with that worde his speche faile began
For fro his herte vp̄ to his brest was com
The colde dethe that had hym oủercom
And yet more oủere. for in his Armes two
The vitale streynth is loste and all ag
Only the intellecte. Withouten more
That dwelled in his herte seke and sore
Gan failen. When the herte felte dethe
Duskyn his yeen .iiᵒ. And failen brethe
But on his lady caste. he yet his yee
His last worde was mercie Emelyee
His sprite changed hous and wente there
As y cam neủere .I. cannot telle where
Therfore y stynte . y am none divynystre
Of soules fynde y nought in this Registre
Ne me list not the oppynyons to telle
Of hem though they wreten where they dwelle
Arcite is colde there Mars his soule gie
Nowe woll y speke furth of Emelie
Shrykith Emelye and howlith Palamon
And Theseus his suster toke anon
Swounyng and bare hure fro the Corps away
What helpith to tarie furth the day
To telle hou she wepte bothe even and morowe
For in suche cas wȳmen haue grete sorowe
When that hure husbonde ys fro hem go
That for the more parte they sorowen so
Or elles falle in suche maladie
That at the laste certaynly they die
Infynyte ben the sorowes and teres
Of olde folke and folke of tendre yeres
In all the Toun for deth of this Theban
For hym wepith bothe Childe and man
So grete a wepyng was ther not certayne
When Ector was brought all fresshe slayne
To Troie allasse the pite that was there
Cracchyng of Chekes rentyng of here
Why woldest thou be dede this wymmen crie
And haddest thou golde y nowe and Emelie
No man myght gladen Theseus
Savyng his olde fader Egeus
That knewe this worldes trᵃaunsumtacioun
As he had seyn it chaungen vp̄ and doun
Ioye aft̉er wo . and wo aft̉er gladnesse
And shewid hem ensaumples and likeness
Right as there died neủere man qduod he
That he ne leved in Erthe yn som degre
Right so ther lyved neủere man he seyde
In all this worlde that som tyme he ne deyde
This worlde is not but a through fare full of wo
And we be pilgrymes passyng to and fro
Deth is an ende of eủery worldly sore
And oủerall this yit seide he moche more
To this effecte full wissely to exhorte
The people that they shulde them recomforte
Duke Theseus with all his besy Cure
Caste nowe. Where that his sepulture
Of good Arcite may best y maked be
And eke moste honourable in his degre
And at the last he toke conclusion
That there first as Arcite and Palamon
Hadden for love the bataill hem betwene
And in that self Grove sote and grene
There as they had there Amorousis desires
Here complaynte . and for love here hote fires
He wolde make a fire in which the offise
Funerall he myght all accomplise
And lete commaunde anon to hacke and hewe
The ekes olde and leide hem on arewe
In Culpons well araide for to brenne
His men anon swyftly furth they renne
And riden anon at his commaundement
And aftur this Theseus hath sent
Aftur a Bere . And it al oủere spradde
With clothe of Golde . the richest that he hadde
And of the same sute he clad Arcite
Vppon his hondes put glovis white
And eke on his hede a Croune of laurer grene
In his hande a swerde bright and kene
And leide hym bare the visage on the Bere
There with he wepte that pite was to here
And for the people shulde see hym all
When it was day he brought hym into hall
Where roryng and criyng and grete soun
Tho came this wofull Theban Palamo
With flotery berde and ruggy asshen heres
In Clothes blake droppid all with Teres
And passyng other of wepyng. Emelie
The Rufullyst of all the companie
In as moche as the ʆservise shulde be
The more noble and riche yn his degre
Duke Theseus lete furth .iiiᵉ. stedys brynge
That trapped were yn stile all gliterynge
And coủered with Armes of Daun Arcite
Vppon thise stedis grete and lilye white
There seten folke . of which on bare his shelde
Another his spere vppon his hande helde
The .iiiᵈᵉ. bare with hys Bowe Turkeys
Of brente golde was the cas and eke the harneys
And riden furth a pas . with a sorowfull chere
Towarde the Grove as ye shull aftur here
The noblest of the Grekis that was there
Vppon here shuldres cariden the Bere
With slak paas and yeen redde and wete
Thrughoute the Cite by the Maister strete
That spradde was all with blacke wonder highe
Right of the same is all the strete y wrighe
Vppon the right hande wente olde Egeus
And on that other side Duke Theseus
With vessels in hande of golde full fyne
And full of honye. milke . blood. and wyne
Eke Palamon with full grete companye
And aftur that came wofull Emelye
With fire in hande as was that tyme the gise
To don the offise of fynerall servise
With high laboure and full high apparaillyng
Was atte the servise and the fire makyng
That with his grene Toppe the hevene raught
And .xxᵗⁱ. fathom of brede the Armes straught
This is to sey the bowes were so brode
Of stres there was leide first many a lode
But hou the fire was made vp̄ on heyght
Ne eke the names that the trees hygh
As. oke. Firre. Birche. Aspe. Eldre. holme. popoler
Wilowe. Elme. Plane. Asshe. Box. Chesteyn. lynde. laurer
Mapill. Thorn . Beche. hasill. Ewe. whipiltre
Hou they were. felde shall not be tolde for me
Ne hou the goddes romen vp̄ and doun
Deserited of there habitacioun̄
In which they wonneden in rest and pes
Nymphes. phawnes. and. Amadrides
Ne hou the briddes and bestes alle
Fledden for fere when the wode was falle
Ne hou the grounde agast was of the light
That was not wonte to se no sonne bright
Ne hou the fire was couchid first with stre
And then with drie stikkes cloven̄ on thre
And then with grene wode and spicerie
And there with clothe of golde and with perrie
And garlondes hangyng with many a floure
The Mirre and ensence. that yave so grete odoure
Ne hou Arcite lay amonge all this
Ne what Richesse a boute his bodye ys
Ne hou that Emelie as was the gise
Put in the fire of Funerall servise
Ne hou she swouned when she made fire
Ne what she spake ne what was hure desire
Ne what iewelles men on the flame caste
When that the fire was grete and brende faste
Ne hou som caste here shelde and som here spere
And of here vestimentis which that they were
And Coupes full of wyne and mylke and blood
Into the fire that brende as hote were wood
Ne hou the Grekys with an huge route
Thries riden all the fire aboute
Vppon the lefte hande with a lowde shoutyng
And. thries with here speres clateryng
And thries hou the ladies gon crie
Ne hou that lad was homward Emelie
Ne hou that Arcite is brende to Asshen colde
Ne hou the liche wake was y holde
All thilke nyght ne hou the Grekis pley
The wake pleys kepe y nought to sey
Who wrastleth best naked well with oyle anoynte
Ne who that baar hym best in no disoynt
I woll not tell eke hou that they gone
Home to Athenes. When the pley is done
¶ But shortly to the poynte woll y wende
And make of my longe tale an ende
By processe and leyngth of certeyne yeres
All styntod is the mournyng and the teres
Of Grekys by a gen̉erall assent
As semed me there was a parlement
At Athenes vpon acetayne poynt and caas
Amonge the which poynt spoken waas
To haue with certayne Contreys Allyaunce
And fully of Thebans obeisaunce
For which this noble Theseus anon
Lete sende aft̉er gentill Palamon
Vnwist of hym what was the cause and why
But in his blacke clothes sorowfully
He came at his commaundement in hie
Tho sente Theseus for Emelie
When they were sette and husht was all the place
And Theus a bide had a space
Or eny worde came fro his wise brest /
His yeen sette he there as was his lest
And with a sadde visage he sighed stille
And aftur that yit he seide thus his wille
The first mover of the cause a bove
When that he made first the cheyne of love
Grete was the effecte and high was the entente
Well wist he why . and what the rook he mente
For which the faire Cheyne of love he bonde
The fire the eyre the water and the londe
In certayne bondes that they may not fle
That same Prynce that same mover qduod he
Hath stabblisshed this wrecched worlde a doun
Ce\r/tayne day. and duracioun
To all that are engendred in this place
Oủere the which day they may not passe
All mowe they yit tho dayes well a bregge
There nedith none auctorite to a legge
For it is proved by exꝑperience
But that me list declare my sentence
Then may men by thys ordre well descerne
That thilke mover stable is and etern
Well may men knowe. but it be a fole
That eny parte derivid from his hole
For nature hath not can his begynnyng
Of no partie or Cantell of a thyng
But of a thyng that ꝑparfite is and stable
Descendyng so till it be corumpable
And therfore of his wise purveaunce
He hath so well beset his ordynaunce
That spices of thyngis and progressions
Shall endure by successions
And not eterne. Withouten eny lye
This maist thou vnderstonde and se at ye
Lo the eke that hath so longe anorisshyng
Fro tyme first hit begynneth to spryng
And hath so longe a lyf as we may see
Yet at the last wasted is the Tree
Considerith eke hou that the harde stone
Vnder oure fete on which we trede and gone
Yet wastith hit as it lieth in the weye
The brode River somtyme wexith drye
The grete Townes se we wany and wende
Then may y sey . that all thynge hath an ende
Of man of womman . se we well also
That wenden̄ in one of thise t̉ermes two
That is to seyne in youth or elles in age
He motte be dede the kynge as shall apage
Som in his bed som in the depe see
Som in the large folde as men may see
There helpith nought. all goith that ylke weye
Then may y sey. that all thyng motte deye
What makith this but iubiter the kynge
That ys Prynce and cause of all thynge
Convertyng all vnto his ꝓpropir wille
From which it ys dereyued sothe to telle
And there ageyns no creature on live
Of no degree availeth for to strive
Then is this wisdom as thynkith me
To make vertue of necessite
And take it well that we may not eschue
And namly that. that to vs alle is due
And who so grucchith ought. he doth foli
And rebell is to hym that all may gie
And certaynly aman hath moste honoure
To dye in his excellence and floure
When he is sikyr of his good name
Then hath he don his frende ne hym self no shame
And gladder aught his frende be of his dethe
When with honoure is yolden is vp̄ his brethe
Then when his name appalled ys for age
For half forgoten is his vessellage
Then is it best as for a worthy fame
To dye when aman is best of name
The contrarie of all this is wilfulnesse
Why grucche we than. Why haue we hevynesse
That good Arcite of Chyvalrie the floure
Departed is with dute and honoure
Oute of this foule prison of this lif
Why grucchith here his Cosyn and his wif /
Of his welfare that lovith hem so wele
Can he hem eny thanke. nay god wote neủere a dele
That bothe his soule and eke hem self offende
And yet they mowe not here lustes amende
What may y conclude of this longe ferie
But aftur wo y rede vs to be merie
And thanke Iubiter of all his grace
And er that we departen fro this place
I rede that we make of sorowis two
O. ꝑparfit ioye lastyng eủere mo
And loketh nowe where moste sorowe is here ynne
There will we first amende and begynne
Suster quod. he . this is my full assente
With all the advis here of my parlemente
That gentill Palamon thyn owne knyght
That servith you with will with harte and with myght
And eủere hath do seth that ye first hym knewe
That ye shulde of youre grace vppon hym rewe
And take hym for husbonde and for lorde
Lene me youre hande for this is myn acorde
Latte se \nowe/ / of youre wommanly pite
He is a kynges brother sonne parde
And though he were a pore Bachelere
Sith he hath served you so many ayer

div.l: (base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
Explicit Fabula Militis
Hic incipit prologus Fabule Molendinarij et cetera
When that the knyght had thus his tale y tolde
In all the companye was ther yonge ne olde
That hene seide it was a noble storie
And worthy to be drawe into memorie
And namely the Ientils eủerychone
Oure hoste seide and swoor so mot y gone
This goith a right vnbocled is the male
Let se nowe who shall telle a nother tale
For truly this game is well begonne
Nowe telle sir Monke yif that ye conn
Somwhat to quyte with the knyghtis tale
The Miller that for dronkyn was of ale
So that vnnethe vpon his hors he sate
He nolde avale nether hode ne hatte
Ne a bide noman for his curtesie
But in pilates voice he gan to crie
And swere by armes blode and bones
I can a noble tale for the nones
With which y will nowe quyte the knyghtis tale
Oure hoste saugh he was dronke of ale
And seide Robyn abide dere brother
Som bettur man shall telle vs first another
A bide and let vs werkyn thriftly
By goddis soule quod he that will not y
For y will speke or ellys goo my wey
Oure hoste than aunswerde . tell on a devilwey
Thou arte a fole thy wit ys oủerecom
Nowe herkneth quod the Miller all and som
But furst y make a protostacioun
That y am dronke y knowe well by my soun
Therfore yif y myspeke or sey
Witith it the ale of suthwerke y you prey
For y will telle a legende or a lyf
Bothe of a Carpynter and of his wyf
How that a Clerke hath sette the wrightes cappe
The Reve than aunswerde and seide stynte thy clappe
Lette be thy lewede drunkyn harlatrie
It ys a synne and eke a grete folie
To apeire eny man or hym defame
And eke to brynge a wif in suche name
Thou mayst y nowe of other thynges seyne
This drunkyn Miller spake full sone ageyne
And seide leve brother Oswolde
Who so hath no wyf he ys no Cokolde
But y sey not therfore that thou art one
There be full good wifis many one
Why arte thou angry with my tale nowe
I haue a wife pardie as wele as thowe
Yit nolde y for the Oxen yn my plough
Take vppon me more than y nough
As demen of my self that y were one
I will beleve well that y am none
An husbonde shall not be Inquysitif
Of goddis pryvite ne of his wi
So he may fynde goddis foysou there
Of the remenaunte nedith not to enquere
What shulde y more seyne . but this Millere
He wolde his wordes for noman forbere
But tolde his Churles tale yn this manere
Me athynkith that y shall rehers it here
And therfore eủery Ientill wight y prey
Demeth not for goddis love that y sey
Of evill entente . but for y mot reherce
Here tales all be they bet or werce
Or elles falsen som of my matere
And therfore who so lystnot it to here
Turne oủere the lef and chese a nother tale
For he shall fynde ynowe grete and smale
Of storiall thyng that touchith ientilnesse
And eke moralite and holynesse
Blameth not me yif þe . chese amysse
The Miller is a churle ye knowe well thysse
So was the Reve eke and other mo
And harlotrie they tolden bothe two
Avisith you and put me oute of blame
And eke men shulde not make ernest of game
Whilom there was dwellyng yn Oxonford
A Riche Gnoff that gestys hilde to bord
And of his crafte he was a Carpenter
With hym there was dwellyng a pore scoler
That had lerned arte . but all his fantasie
Was turned to lerne Astrologye
And coude acerteyne of conclusions
To deme by interogacions
Yif that men asked hym in certayne houres
When men shulde haue droughte other elles shoures
And yif men asked hym what shulde befalle
Of eủery thyng y may not rekon all
This clerke was cleped hende Nicholas
Of derne love he coude and of Solas
And therto he was sly and full prive
And like a mayde meke for to se
A chambre had he in that hosterye
Alone withoute eny companye
Full fetously dight with herbys sote
And he hym self as swete as is the rote

Y shall it well tell the another day
And caught the Cultur by the colde stele
Full softe oute at the dore he gan to stele
And wente vnto the Carpentars wall
He coughed furst and cnocked there with all
Vppon the wyndowe right as he did ere
This Alisou aunswerd who is there
That knockith so y warant it is a thef
Nay nay quod he god wote my swete lef
I am thyn Absolou thy derlyng
Of golde quod he y haue brought the a Ryng
My Moder yaf it me so god me save
Full fyne it is and therto well y grave
This will y yeve the yif thou me kysse
This Nicholas was risen vp to pysse
He thought he wolde a mende all the Iape
He shulde kis his ars or that he scape
And vp the wyndowe he did hastely
And oute his ars he put prively
Oủere the buttok to the haunche bone
And therewith spake hym Absolone
Speke swete birde y not where thou arte
This Nicholas anon lette fle a farte
As grete as it had ben a thonder dent
That with the stroke he was all most y blent
And he was redy with his Iron hote
And Nicholas in the ars he smote
Of goth the Skyn an hand brede aboute
The hote Cultur brende so his toute
That for the smerte he wende forto dye
As he were wode for wo he gan to cry
Helpe water water . for goddes herte
This Carpynter oute of his slomer sterte
And harde one crie water as he were wood
And thought allas nowe commeth Noes flood
He set hym vp withoute wordes moo
And with his Axe he smote the corde two
He fell doun to the flore and there a swoun he lay
Vp sterte hure Alisoıı̄un and Nicholay
And cried oute and harowe in the strete
The nyghtbours than bothe smale and grete
In ronnen for to gawren on this man
That in swounyng lay bothe pale and wan
For with the fall he broken had his armes
But stonde he moste to his owne harmes
For when he spake . he was anon bore doun
Of hende Nicholas and Alisoun
They tolden eủery man that he was wood
He was agast so of Noes flood
Thrugh fantasie that of his vanyte
He bought hym knedyng Tubbys thre
And had hem hanged in the Rof a bove
And that he praide them for goddis love
To sitten in the Rof for companye
The folke gan laughen at his fantasye
Into the . Rof they kekyn and they gape
And turned all his harmys vnto Iape
For what so that this Carpenter aunswerd
It was for nought . no man his reasou herd
With othes grete he was so sworn doun
That he was holden wode thrugh all the toun
For eủery Clerke anon right hilde with other
And seide the man was wode my lef brother
And eủery wight gan laughen at this strif
Thus swyved was the Carpenters wif
For all his kepyng and his Ielosie
And Absolou had kist hure nether ye
And Nicholas is scalded in the toute
My tale is don . and god save all this route
Thus endeth the Millers tale
Here begynneth the prologge of the Rev
Wheannehannehenne folke haue laughen at this nyce cas
Of Absolon̄ and hende Nicholas
Dyủers folke dyủersly they seiden̄
And for the more parte they loughen and pleiden̄
But at this tale I sawe noman̄ hym̄ greve
But it were only Oswolde the Reve
By cause he was of Carpenters crafte
A litle Ire in his harte was lafte
He gan̄ to grucche and blame it alite
So thik quod he full well coude y the quite
With bleryng of a proude Millers ye
Yif that me list to speke of ribaudrye
But y am̄ olde me list not to pley for age
Gras tyme is don̄ my fodder is nowe forage
This white toppe writith myn̄ olde yerys
Myn̄ herte is also mowled as myn̄ hers ys
But yif y fare as doth an̄ opene Ers
That ilke frute is eủere lenger the wers
Till it be roten̄ yn̄ mullok or in stre
We olde men̄ y drede so fare we
Till we be roten̄ can̄ we not be ripe
We hoppyn̄ alway while that the worlde woll pipe
For in oure will there stikith eủere a vaille
To haue an̄ hoor here and a grene taille
As hath a leke for though oure myght begone
Oure will desireth folye eủere in one
For when̄ we may nought do then̄ will we speke
Yit in oure olde asshen̄ fire is y reke
·iiij· Gledes haue we whiche y shall devise
Avauntyng · liyng · angre ·and Covetise
Thise ·iiij· sparkles longen̄ vnto elde
Oure olde lymmys mowe well be vnwelde
But will ne shall faile that is soth
And yet haue y allway a Coltis toth
As many yere as it is passed henne
Sith that my tappe of lif began̄ to renne
For sikirly when̄ y was born̄ anon̄
Dethe drough the tappe of lif and lete it gon̄
And eủere sith hath the tappe y ronne
Till that all moste all empty is the tonn
The streme of lif nowe droppith on̄ the Chymbe
The sely tunge may well rynge and Chymbe
Of wrecchidnesse that ys passed full yore
With olde folke save dotage is nomore
When̄ that oure hoste had harde this sermonyng
He began̄ to speke as lordely as a kyng
And seide what a mountith all this witte
Whi shull we all day speke of holy writte
The devill made a Reve forto preche
Or a Sowter a Shipman̄ or a leche
Sey furth thy tale and tary not the tyme
Lo Depford and it is half wey to pryme
