div.l: Nowe sires quod this Oswolde the Reve
Y pᵃray you all that ye not greve
Though y aunswere and somdell sette his hove
For lefull is with force · force of shove
This drunken̄ Millere hath tolde vs here
Hou that that begiled was a Carpentere
Paraventure in scorne for y am̄ one
And by youre leve y shall hym̄ quyte anone
Right in his Cherles t̉ermes woll y speke
I pray to god his necke mot to breke
He can̄ well in myn̄ ye se a stalke
But in his owne he cannot see a Balke
Hic incipit fabula p̉ropositi
At Trumpyngton̄ not fer fro Caumbrigge
There goith a broke and oủere that a Brigge
Vppon̄ the which broke there standith a Mille
And this is verrey sothe that y you telle
A Millere was there dwellyng many a day
As eny Pecok he was proude and gay
Pipe he coude and fisshe a nettys bete
And turne Cuppes and well wrastle and shete
Ay by his belte he bare a longe panade
And of a a swerde ful trenchaunt was the blad
A Ioly poppar bare he in his pouche
There was no man̄ for ꝑperell durst hym̄ touche
A Sheffelde thwytell bare he in his hose
Rounde was his face and camused was his nose
As pilled as an̄ ape was his sculle
He was a MarketMaketMarket beter at the fulle
There durst no wight hande on̄ hym̄ legge
That he ne swore anon̄ he shulde abegge
A Thef he was forsoth of corn̄ and mele
And that a sly and vsaunt for to stele
His name was hote digneus Symkyn̄
A wyf he hadde comyn̄ of noble kyn̄
The parson̄ of the Toune hire fader was
With hure he yaf full many a pan̄ of bras
For that Symkyn̄ shulde yn his blode a lye
She was fostred in a Nonnerye
For Symkyn̄ wolde no wif ~meidewif as he seide
But she were · well norisshed or a Meide
To save his estate of yomanrye
And she was proude and perte as a pye
A full faire sight was it vppon̄ hem̄ two
On̄ holy days a forn̄ hure wolde he go
With his Tippet wounden̄ aboute his hede
And she cam aftur yn Gite of Rede
And Symkyn̄ had hosen̄ of the same
There durst nowight clepe hure but dame
Was none so hardy that wente by the way
That with hure durst rage other play
But yif he wolde be slayne of Symkyn̄
With panade knyf or with Boidekyn̄
For Ielous folke ben̄ ꝑperilous eủere mo
Algate they wolde hure wyfes wende so
And eke for she was somdele smotirliche
She was as deyne as water in a Diche
So full of hoker and of bysmare
Hure thought that a lady shulde hure spare
What for hure kynred and hure nortelrie
That she had lerned in the Nonnerie
A doughtur had they betwixt hem̄ two
Of xxᵗⁱ · yere olde · withoute eny mo ennabling collatio
Savyng a Childe that was of half yere age
In Cradill it lay · It was a ꝓpropir page
This wenche thicke and well y growen̄ was
With Camuse nose and yeen̄ grey as glas
With buttokkys brode and brestis rounde and hie
Right feire was hure here y woll not lie
The parson̄ of the Toun̄ for she was feire
In purpos was to maken̄ hur͗e his heire
Bothe of his catell and of his Mesuage
And straunge he made it it of hure mariage
Grete soken̄ had this Millere oute of doute
Of whete and malte of all the lande aboute
And namlyche there was a grete Collage
// Men clepyn̄ the Soler halle of Caumbregge
There was here whete and eke here malte ygrounde
And on̄ a day it happid in a stounde
Seke lay the Manciple on̄ a maladie
Men̄ wenden̄ wisly that he shulde die
For which this Millere stole bothe mele mele bothe mele and corn̄
An̄ hundred tyme more than̄ beforn̄
For there before he stole but curteisly
And nowe he was a thef outeragiously
For which the wardyn̄ chid and made fare
But therof set the Miller not a tare
// He crakith boste and swore it was not so
Then̄ were there poure scolers two
That dweldyn̄ in the halle of which y sey
Testif they were and lusty for to pley
And only for hure myrth and revelrye
Vppon̄ the wardyn̄ besily they crye
To yeve hem̄ leve but a litle stounde
To go to Mille and see there corn̄ grounde
And hardely they durst ley here necke
The Miller shulde not stele hem̄ half a pecke
Of corn̄ by sleight ne by force hem̄ reve
And at the last the wardyn̄ yaf hem̄ leve
Iohn hight that on̄ and Aleyn̄ hight other
And in one Toun̄ were they born̄ that men̄ calle Strother
Ferre in the North y cannot telle where
This Aleyne makith redy all his gere
And on̄ an̄ hors the sacke they casten̄ anon
Furth gon̄ Aleyne the Clerke and also Iohn
With good swerde and buckler by here side
Iohn knewe the wey hem̄ nede no gide
And at the last the sakke doun̄ he leyith
Aleyn̄ spake first all haill Symond in feyith
Hou faris thy faire doughtᵘur and thy wyf
Aleyin̄ welcom̄ quod Symkyn̄ by my lyf
And Iohn also · what do ye nowe here
By god quod Iohn nede hath no pere
Hym̄ behovith to serve hym̄ self that hath no swayne
Or ellys he is a fole as Clerkis sayne
Oure Manciple is seke and like forto be dede
So werkys ay the wanges in his hede
And for thy · I · is com̄ and eke Aleyne
To grynde oure corn̄ · and to carie oure mele oure mele mele ageyne
I pray you spede vs hens what ye may
It shall be don̄ quod Symkyn̄ by my fay
What woll ye do while it ys in honde
By god right by the hoper will y stonde
Quod Iohn · and se hou the corn̄ goith ynne
Yet sawe y neủere by my Fader kynne
Hou that the hoper waggith to and fro
Aleyn̄ aunswerd · Iohn wolte thou so
Then̄ will y be bynethe by my Croune
And see hou that the Mele fallith doune
In to the Trowgh · that shall be my disporte
For Iohn in faith y may be of youre sorte
I am̄ as ille a Millere as be ye
This Mellere smylith at there nycete
And thought all this is don̄ but for a wile
They wene that no man̄ shall hem̄ begile
But by my thrift yet shall y blere here ye
For all there sleight of there philosophye
The more queynte krekys that they make
The more woll y stele when̄ that y take
In stede of floure yet wolle y yeve them̄ bren̄
The grettist Clerkys be not wisest men̄
As whilom̄ to the wolf · spake the Mare
Of all here arte counte y not a tare
Oute at the dore he goith full privel
When̄ he saugh his tyme softly
He loked vp̄ and doun̄ till he had founde
The Clerkys hors there as it stode bounde
Behynde the Melle vnder a lefsell
And to the hors he goth feire and well
And stripeth of the bridell right anon̄
And when̄ the hors was louse he gynneth to gon̄
Tawarde the fen̄ · there wilde Mares renne
And furth · with · we he · thrugh thicke and thenne
This Miller goth a geyne no worde he seide
But doth his note and with the clerkys pleide
Till that hur͗e corn̄ was faire and well y grounde
And when̄ the mele was sackid and y bounde
This Iohn goth oute and fyndith his hors away
And gan̄ to crie harowe and well away
Oure hors is lost · Aleyne for goddes bones
Stepe on̄ thy fete · com̄ on̄ man̄ all attones
Allas oure warden̄ has his palfrey lorn̄
This Aleyne all forgate bothe mele and corn̄
All was oute of his mynde his husbandrie
What whilke way is he gon̄ he gan̄ crie
The wif cam̄ lepyng Inward with a renne
Sheo seide allas youre hors goth to the Fenne
With wilde Mares as fast as he ma goo
Vnthanke com̄ on̄ his hed that bande hym̄ soo
And he that shulde bettir haue knyt the Reyne
Alas qduod Iohn · Aleyn̄ for cristes peyne
Ley doun̄ thy swerde and y will myn̄ alsoo
I am full wight god wote as is a Roo
By goddis harte he shal not scapyn̄ vs bathe
Why ne haddest thou put the caple in the lathe
Ilhayle Aleyne by god thou is a Fonne
Thise sely Clerkys haue full swithe y ronne
Towarde the Fenne · bothe Aleyn̄ and Iohn
And when̄ the Millere saugh they were gon̄
He half a busshell of her͗e floure hath take
And bade his wif to knede it on̄ a Cake
He seydeseyseyde y trowe the Clerkis ben̄ a ferde
Yet can̄ a Miller make a Clerkis berde
For all here arte · ye let hem̄ go here wey
Lo where they go · ye lette the children̄ pley
They gete hym̄ not so lightly by my Croun̄
These sely Clerkys romen̄ vp̄ and doun
With kepe · kepe stonde stonde iossa war the rere
Go whistill thou · and y shall kepe here
But shortly till it was verrey nyght
They coude not though they did all here myght
Here Caple cacche he ran̄ all way so fast
Till in a diche they caught hym̄ at the last
Wery and wete as beest is in the reyne
Comth sely Iohn and with hym̄ Aleyne
Allas quod Iohn that day that y was born̄
Nowe are we driven̄ to hethyng and to scorn̄
Oure corn̄ is stole men̄ woll vs fonnes call
Bothe oure warden̄ and oure felawes all
And namely the Millere welaway
Thus pleyneth Iohn as he goith by the way
Toward the Mille and bayard in his honde
The Millere sittyng by the fire he fonde
For it was nyght and ferther myght they nought
But for the love of god they hym̄ bysought
Of herborowe and ease as for here peny
The Miller͗e seide ayen̄ yif ther be eny
Suche as it is yit shull ye haue youre parte
Myn̄ house is streite · but ye haue lerned arte
Ye conne by Argumentes make a place
A · Mile brode of · xxᵗⁱ · fote of space
Lette se nowe yif this place may suffise
Or make it romere with speche as is youre gise
Nowe Symond seide this Iohn by seynte CutbertdCutbertCutberd
Ay is thou mery · and that is faire aunswerd
I haue hard sey aman̄ shall take of · ijᵒ · thynges
Suche as he fyndes or suche as he brynges
But specially y pray the hoste dere
Gete vs mete and drynke and make vs chere
And we shull pay truly at the fulle
With empty hande men̄ may none haukis calle
Lo here oure silủere redy for to spende
This Millere to the Toun̄ his doughtᵘur sende
For ale and for brede and rosted hem̄ a goos
And his hors he shulde nomore go loos
And in his owne Chambre he made hem̄ a bedde
With shetes and Chalon̄s feire y spredd
Nought fer fro her͗e owne bed · xᵉⁿ · fote or twelf
ThereHysThereHys doughtᵘur had a bed all by here self
div.note: Per Mosser "exʳ" is a correction mark.
div.l: Right in the same Chambre by and by
It myght be no bette and cause why
There was none romer herborowgh in the place
They soupen̄ and speken̄ of solace
And drunkyn̄ eủere stronge ale at the beste
Aboute mydnyght wente they to reste
Well hath the Miller vernysshid his hede
Full pale he was for drunkyn̄ and not rede
He yeskith and spekith thrugh the nose
As he were on̄ the quak or on̄ the pose
To bed he goth and with hym̄ his wif
As eny Iay he light was and Iolif
So was hure Ioly whistell well y wette
The Cradell at the beddis fete was sette
To rocke and to yeve the Childe soke
And whan̄ that drunken̄ was all in the Croke
To bedde wente the doughtur anon̄
To bedde goth Aleyn̄ and also Iohn
There was nomore hem̄ nedith no dwale
This Miller hath so wisely bibbed the ale
That as an̄ hors he fnorteth yn̄ his slepe
Ne of his taile behynde he toke no kepe
Hys wyf bare hym̄ a burdon̄ that was full stronge
Men̄ mygh here routyng here a furlonge
The wenche routed eke ꝑpar companye
Aleyn̄ the Clerke that herde this melodye
He poked Iohn and seide slepist thow
Herde thou eủere suche a songe er now
Lo which a couplyng is amonge hem̄ alle
A wilde fire on̄ there bodies alle
This longe nyght tide me no reste
But yit no force all shalbe for the beste
For Iohn seide he as eủere mot y thrife
Yif that y may yonder wenche woll y swife
Som̄ esement has lawe shapen̄ vs
For Iohn there is a lawe that seith thus
That yif a man̄ in on̄ poynte be agrevid
That in another shalbe relevid
Oure corn̄ is stole sothely it is no nay
And we haue had an̄ evill fit this day
And sithen̄ y shall haue none amendement
Ageyn̄ my lostis y will haue an̄ easement
By goddes feith it shall non̄ other be
This Iohn aunswerd · Aleyne avise the
The Millere is a ꝑperilous man̄ he seide
And yif that he oute of his slepe abreide
He myght do vs bothe a vilanye
Aleyne seide y counte hym̄ not at a flye
Vp̄ he arisith and to the wenche he crepe
This wenche lay vprighte and fast slepe
Till he so nygh was er she myght espie
That it had be to late for to crie
And shortly forto sey they were at on̄
Nowe pley on̄ Aleyn̄ and y shall speke of Iohn
This Iohn lieth still a forlong wey or two
And to hym̄ silf makith rueth and wo
Alas quod he this is a wicked Iape
Nowe may y say y am̄ but an̄ Ape
Yit hath my felawe somwhat for his harme
He hath the Millars doughtᵘur in his arme
He auntred hym̄ and hath his nede spedde
And y lie as a drafsacke in my bedde
And when̄ this Iape is tolde a nother day
I shalbe holden̄ a daff a Cokenay
Y wolle arise and aunter me by my feith
Vnhardy vnsely thus men̄ seith
And vp̄ he arose and softly wente
Vnto the Cradell and in his hand it hente
And bare it softe vnto his beddis fete
Sone aftʳur this wif hure rowtyng lete
And gan̄ a wake and went hure oute oute to pisse
And came ageyne and gan̄ hure Cradell misse
And groped here and there · and she founde none
Alas quod she I had almost mysgon̄
I had almoste gon̄ to the Clerkis bed
Ey benedicite then̄ had y evill sped
And furth she goth till she the Cradell fonde
And groped alway furth with hure honde
And founde the bed · and thought naught but goo
By cause that the Cradill by it stood
And nyst where she was for it was derke
And faire and well she crepte in by the Clerke
And lieth full still and wolde haue caught a slepe
Within a while this Iohn this Clerke vp lepe
And on̄ this good wif he leide on̄ sore
So mery a fitte had she not full yore
He prickith harde and depe as he were madde
This Ioly lyf haue thise Clerkys hladdehaddeladde
That till the Cokke thrise be gan̄ to synge
Aleyn̄ wex wery in the mornynge
For he had swonkyn̄ all the longe nyght
And saide farewell Malkyn̄ swete wyght
The day is com̄ y may no lenger abide
But eủermore where so eủere y go or ride
I am̄ thyn̄ owne Clerke so haue y helle
Nowe dere lemman̄ qduod she go fare welle
But or thou go othyng y will the telle
When̄ that thou wendyst homward by the Melle
Right at the entre of the dore behynde
Thou shalte a Cake of half a busshell fynde
That was made of youre owne mele
Which that I halpe my fader for to stele
And good lemman̄ god the save and kepe
And with that worde almoste she began̄ to wepe
Aleyn̄ vp̄ arist and thought er it dawe
I will go crepe in by my felawe
And founde the Cradell at his honde anon̄
By god qduod he all wronge haue y gon̄
Myn̄ hede is toty of my swynke to nyght
That makith me that y go not aright
I wote well by the Cradill y haue mysgo
Here lieth the Millere and his wif also
And furth he goith on̄ · xxᵗⁱ · devilway
Vnto the bed there as the Millere lay
He wende haue cropyn̄ by his felawe Iohn
And by the Millere yn he crepith anon̄
And caught hym̄ by the necke and softe spake
And seide thou Iohn · thou Swyneshed awake
For cristis soule · and here a noble game
For by that lorde that is clepid is is seynte Iame
I haue · thrise in this shorte nyght
Swyfed the Millers doughtᵘur bolte vpright
While thou hast as a Coward be agast
Ye fals harlot quod the Millere hast
A fals traitoure fals Clerke heqduodheqduod he
Thou shalte be dede by goddis dignyte
Who durst be so bolde to disꝑparage
My doughtʳur that is com̄ of suche lynage
And by the throte bolle he caught Alyen̄
And he hente hym̄ dispitously ageyn̄
And on̄ the nose he smote hym̄ with his fest
That doun̄ ran̄ the blode streme vppon̄ his brest
And in the flore with nose and mouthe broke
They walwyn̄ as don̄ · ijᵒ · pigges in a poke
And vp̄ they gon̄ and doun̄ ayen̄ anon̄
Till that Millere spurned at aston̄
A doun̄ he fele bakward on̄ his wif
That wist nothyng of this nyce strif
For she was fall a slepe alitle wight
With Iohn the Clerke that wakid hadde all nyght
And with the fall oute of hure slepe she braide
Helpe holy Crosse of Bromholm̄ she saide
In manus tuas · lorde to the y calle
Awake Symkyn̄ the fende is onomon me falle
Myn̄ herte is brokyn̄ helpe y am̄ but dede
There lieth on̄ vppon̄ my wombe and on̄ my hede
Helpe Symkyn̄ for the falce Clerkis fight
This Iohn sterte vp̄ as fast as eủere he might
And gropith by the walles to and fro
To fynde a staff and she starte vp̄ also
And knewe the Estres bet than̄ did Iohn
And by the wall she founde a staf anon̄
And saugh a litle glemeryng of a light
For at an̄ hole yn̄ shone the mone bright
And by that light she sawe them̄ bothe two
But syker she nyst who was who
But as she sawe a white thyng in here ye

This wofull womman brought he to londe

She saide she was so mased on the See

And so ferfurth she gan oure lay declare

But natheles there was grete mornynge

Marie y mene Doughtᵘur to seynte Anne

O · Quenes levyng in ꝓprosꝑperite

To done this synne ben̄ eyther sleyn̄ or shente
Hou may this weyke womman̄ haue the streyngth
Hure to defende ageyne this renegate
O · Golias vnmysurable of leyngth
Hou myght Dauid make the See mate
So yonge and of armure so desolate
Hou durst he loke on̄ thy dredfuƚƚ face
Weƚƚ may men̄ seen̄ it was but goddis grace
Who yave Iudith corage and hardynesse
To sle hym̄ Olyferne in his tente
And to deliủere oute of wrecchidnesse
The people of god · y sey for this entente
That right as god · Sprite of vigor sente
To hem and savid hem̄ oute of myschaunce
So sente he myght and vigor to Custaunce
Furth goith hure Ship̄e thrughoute the narowe mowth
Of Iubaldare · and Cepte · drivyng alway
Somtyme West and somtyme North and South
And somtyme Est fuƚƚ many a wery day
Tiƚƚ Cristis Moder blessed be she ay
Hath shapen̄ thrugh hure endles goodnesse
To make an̄ ende of aƚƚ hure hevynesse
Nowe let vs stynte of Custaunce but a throwe
And speke we of the Romayn̄ Emꝑperoure
That oute of Surrye hath by lettres knowe
The slaughtre of Cristen̄ folke and dishonoure
Done to his doughtᵘur by a fals Traitoure
I mene the cursed wickid Sawdenesse
That at the feste lete sle bothe more and lesse
For which this Emꝑperoure hath sente anon̄
His Senatoure with roiaƚƚ ordenaunce
And other lordes god wote many on̄
On̄ Surreyns to take veniaunce
They bren̄ · sleen̄ · and brynge hem̄ to myschaunce
Fuƚƚ many aday · but shortly this is the ende
Homward to Rome they shapen̄ hem̄ to wende
This Senatoure repaireth with victorye
To Romewarde sailyng fuƚƚ roially
And mette the Ship̄e drivyng as seith the storye
In which Custaunce sate fuƚƚ pitously
Nothyng knewe he what she was ne why
She was in suche aray ne she nolde seye
Of hure estate though she shulde deye
He bryngith hure to Rome and to his wif
He yaf hure and hure yonge Sonne also
And with the Senatoure she ladde hure li
Thus can̄ oure lady bringe oute of woo
Wofuƚƚ Custaunce and many other moo
And longe tyme dwelde she in that place
In holy werkis eủere as was hure grace
The Senatours wif hure aunte was
But for aƚƚ that she knewe hure neủere the more
I wiƚƚ no lengur tarie in this cas
But to kynge Alla of which y spake yore
That wepith for his wif and sighith sore
I woƚƚ retorne and lette y woƚƚ Custaunce
Vnder the Senatours goủernaunce
Kynge Alla which that hath his Moder slayne
Vppon̄ a day feƚƚ in suche repentaunce
That yif y shortly tellen̄ shaƚƚ and playne
To Rome he comth to receyve his penaunce
And to putte hym̄ in the Popes ordynaunce
In hygh and lowe and Ihu Criste besoughte
For yeve hym̄ his wicked werkes that he wroughte
The fame anon̄ thrughoute the Toun̄ is born̄
Howe Alla kynge shaƚƚ com̄ yn pilgremage
By herbeiours that wenten̄ hym̄ biforn̄
For which the Senatoure as it was vsage
Rode hym̄ ageyns and many of his lynage
As weƚƚ to shewe his high Magnyficens
As to done eny kynge a reủerens
Grete chere makith this noble Senatoure
To kynge Alla and he to hym̄ also
Eủerych of them̄ doth other grete Honoure
And so befele that with yn̄ a day or two
This Senatoure is to kynge Alla go
To feste · and shortly yif y shaƚƚ not lie
Custaunce sonne wente in his companie
Som̄ men̄ wolde seyne that at the request of Custaunce
This Senatoure hath ladde this Childe to feste
Y may not teƚƚ eủery circumstaunce
Be as be may he was there at the leste
But soth it is that at his moders heste
Byfore Alla duryng the metis space
The Childe loked in the kynges face
This Alla Kynge hath of this Childe grete wonder
And to the Senatoure he seide anon̄
Whas is this faire Childe that standith yonder
I not qduod he by god and by seynte Iohn
A Moder he hath · but fader hath he non̄
That y of wote · but shortly in a stounde
He tolde Alla hou the Childe was founde
But god wote qduod this Senatoure also
So vertuous a lever in aƚƚ my lif
Ne sawe y nevir as she is ne herde of mo
Of worldly wymmen̄ mayde ne wif
Y dar weƚƚ seyne hure had levir a knif
Thrughoute the brest than̄ be awomman̄ wicke
There is noman̄ coude brynge hure to that pricke
Nowe was this Childe as like vnto Custaunce
As possible is a creature for to be
This Alla hath the face yn remembraunce
Of dame Custaunce and thereon̄ mused he
Yif that the Childes Moder were aught she
That is his wif and prively he sighte
And sped hym̄ fro the table that he mighte
Parfay thought he the fantom̄ is in my hede
I aught deme of skilfuƚƚ Iugement
That in the salte See · my wif is dede
And afturwarde he made his argument
What wote y yif Criste haue hur hedur sent
My wif by See aswele as he hure lente
To my Contre fro thens that she wente
And aftur none hom̄ with the Seatoure
Goith Alla to se this wonder Chaunce
This Senatoure doith Alla grete honoure
And hastely he sente aftur Custaunce
But trustith weƚƚ hure list not to daunce
When̄ that she wist wherfore was that sonde
Vnneth vppon̄ hure feet she myght stonde
When̄ Alla saugh his wif faire he hur grette
And wepte that it was ruyth to see
For at the first loke he on̄ hure sette
He knewe verrey that it was shee
And she for sorowe as dombe standith as a tre
So was hure hert shet in hure distresse
When̄ she remembred his vnkyndenesse
Twise she swouned in his owne sight
He wepith and hym̄ excusith pitously
Nowe god qduod he and his halowes bright
So wisly on̄ my soule haue mercy
That of youre harme as gilty am̄ y
As is Maurice my sonne like to youre face
Elles the fende fecche fecche me oute of this place
Longe was the sobbyng and the bittir peyne
Er that there wofuƚƚ hertis myghten̄ sece
Grete was the pite for to here them̄ pleyne
Thrugh which pleyntes gan̄ there wo encrece
Y pray you aƚƚ my laboure to relece
I may not teƚƚ there wo vntiƚƚ to morowe
I am so werye for to speke of sorowe
But fynally when̄ the sothe is wist
That Alla giltles was of hure wo
I trowe an̄ hundred tymes ben̄ they kist
And suche a blisse is betwene them̄ two
That save the ioy that lastith eủere mo
There is none like that eny creature
Hath seen̄ or shaƚƚ whils the worlde may endure
Tho praide she hure husbonde mekely
In releef of hure longe pitouse peyne
That he wolde pray hure Fader specially
That of his Magiste he wolde enclyne
To vouchesave som̄ day with hym̄ to dyne
She preide hym̄ eke he wolde by no wey
Vnto hure Fader no worde of hure sey
Som̄ men̄ wolde seyne hou that the Childe Maurice
Doith this Message vnto the Emꝑperoure
But as y gesse Alla was not so nice
To hym̄ that was of so soleyne honoure
As he that is of Cristen̄ folke the floure
Sente eny Childe · but it is bet to deme
He wente hym̄ self and so it may weƚƚ seme
This Emꝑperoure hath grauntid jentilly
To com̄ to dyner as he hym̄ besought
And weƚƚ rede y y he loked besily

div.l: Husbondes at the Cherche dore haue y wedded five
y so ofte myght haue weddid be
And al were worthy men in there degre
But me was tolde not longe a gon ys
Criste wente neủere but onys
To weddyng in the Cane of Galile
by the same ensample taught he me
That y weddid shulde be but onys
Lo herkene what a sharpe worde for the nonys
Bside a wel Ihu god and man
Spake in repref of the Samaritan
Thou hast had .v. husbondes qd he
And that ilke man that hath nowe the
Is not thyn husbonde he seide certeyne
What that he mente therby y can nought seyne
But that y aske why that the .vᵉ. man
Was not husbonde to the Samaritan
Hou many myght she haue in mariage
But yet herde y neủere tel in myn age
Of the nombre diffinycioıı̄unn
Men may demen and glosen vp and doun
But wel y wote expresse withoute lie
God bade vs to wexe and multiplie
That gentil texte can y wel vnderstonde
For wel y wote that my husbonde
Shulde let fader and moder and take to me
But of non nombre menciou made he
Of Bigamie or of Octagmie
Whi shulde men speke of it vilonie
Lo here the wise kynge Salamon
owe he had wifis mo than on
As wolde god it leful were to me
be refresshed half so ofte as he
ich a yefte of god had he for al his wifis
No man hath suche that nowe a lyve is
wote this worthy kynge as to my witte
The first nyght had many a merye fitte
With eche of them so wel was hym a live
Blessed be god that y haue weddid five
Of which y haue piked oute the best
Bothe of here nether purs and of there Ches
Dyvers scoles makyn diủers Clerkys
And diủers practikis in many sondry werkis
Makith the ꝑparfite man ful sikirly
Of .v. husbondes scolyng am y
Welcom the .vj. when that eủere he shal
I wil hym not forsake nothyng at al
When my husbonde is fro the worlde gon
Som Cristen man shal wedde me anon
For the Apostle seith that y am fre
To wedde a goddis half where it likith me
He seith to be weddid is no synne
Bette is to be weddid then to brynne
What reckith me though men sey vilonye
Of shrewid Lameth and of his bigamye
I wote wel Abraham was an holy man
And eke Iacob as ferre as y here can
And eche of them had wifis mo than two
And many another holy man also
Where can ye sey in eny mane of age
That high god defendid mariage
By expresse wordes y prey you tellith it me
Or where commaundid he virginite
I wote aswel as ye it is no drede
The Apostle when he spekith of Maidenhede
He seide thereof precepte had he none
Men may counsail a womman to be one
But counseil is non commaundement
He puttith hit in oure owne Iugement
For had god commaunded Maydenhede
Then hadde he dampned weddyng with the dede
And certis yif there were no sede y sowe
Virginite than whereof shulde it growe
Paule durst not commaunde at the leste
Athyng which his Master yaf non heste
The darte is sette vp for virginite
Cache who so may who renneth best let se
But this worde is not take of eủery wight
But there as god wol yeve it of his might
I wote wel the Postle was a Maide
But natheles though he wrote and saide
He wolde that eủery wight were as h
nys but counsaile to virginite
And forto be a wif he yave me leve
Of indulgence so it is not to repreve
To wed me yif that my make die
Withouten excepciou of Bigamie
Al were it good noman for to touche
He mente in his bed or in his couche
For perel is fire and towe to assemble
Ye knowe what this ensample may resemble
This is al and som. he hilde virginite
More ꝑparfite than weddyng in frealte
Frealte clepe y but yif that he and she
Wolde lede there lif in Chastite
I graunte it wel y haue none envie
Though Maidenhode preferre Bigamie
It liketh hem to be clene in body and gost
Of myn estate y wol make no bost
Ful wel ye knowe alorde in his housholde
Hath not eủery vessel al of golde
Som ben of tre and do hure servise
God clepith to hym folke in sondry wise
And eủerych hath of god a propre yifte
Som this . som that . as hym list to shifte
Virginite is grete ꝑperfecciou
And contynence eke with devociou
But Criste that of ꝑperfecciou is welle
Bade not eủery wight he shulde go selle
Alle that he had and yeve it to the pore
And in suche wise folowen hym and his lore
He spake to them that wolden live ꝑparfitly
And lordyngis by youre leve that am not y
wol bestowe the floure of al myn age
the actes and in the fruyt of Mariage
Telle me also to what conclusioun
Were membres made of genacioun
And of so ꝑparfite wise a wight y wrought
Trust right wel they were not made for naught
Glose who so wil and sey bothe vp and doun
That they were made for purgaciou
Of vryne and other thynges smale
Was eke to knowe a female from a Male
And for none other cause sey ye no
The exꝑperience wote wel it is not so
So that the Clerkis be not with me wroth
I sey thus that they ben maked for both
That is to seye for offise and for ease
Of engendrure dar we not god displease
Why shulde men elles in here bokes sette
That man shalde yelde to his wif hure dette
Nowe wherewith shulde he make his payment
Yif he ne vsed his sely Instrument
Then were they made vppon a creature
To purge vryne and eke for engendrure
But y seye that eủery wight is holde
That hath suche harneys as y you tolde
To go and vse them in engendrure
Then men shulde take of Chastite no cure
Criste was a Maide and shapen as a man
And many an holy seynte seth the worlde began
Yet lived they eủere in ꝑparfite chastite
I nel envie none virginite
Lette hym haue bred of pured whete seed
And lette vs wifis ete barly breed
And yet with barly bred . Marke tel can
Oure lorde Ihu refresshed many a man
In suche estate as god hath cleped vs
I wol ꝑperseủere y am not precious
In wifhode wol y vse myn Instrument
As frely as my Maker hath it sent
Yif y be daungerous god yeve sorowe
Myn husbonde shal it haue bothe at eve and eke at morowe
When that hym list com forth and paie his dette
An husbonde wol y haue y wol not lette
Which shalbe bothe my dettoure and my thral
And haue his tribulaciou with al
Vppon his flesshe the while y am his wif
I haue the powere duryng my lif
Vppon his ꝓpropre body and not he
Right the Apostle tolde it vnto m
And bade oure husbondes forto love vs wel
d this sentence me likith eủery del
stert the Pardonere and that anon
Nowe dame by god and by seynte Iohn
Ye be a noble prechoure in this cas
Y was a boute to wedde a wif alas
What shulde y bie on my flesshe so dere
te had y leủere wed no wif to yere
Abide qd she my tale is not yit begonne
Nay thou shalte drynke of another Tonne
Er that y goo shal sauoure wers then ale
And when y haue tolde furth my tale
Of tribulaciou that is in mariage
Of which y am experte in al myn age
This is to seyne my self haue be the whippe
Then mayst thou chese whether thou wilte lepe or skippe
Of thilke Tonne that y shal a broche
Beware of hit er thou to nygh a proche
For y shal tel ensamples mo then ten
Who so woll not be ware by other men
By hym shal other men corrected be
Thise same wordes writith Protholome
Rede in his Almagest and take it there
Dame y wolde prey you yif youre wil were
Seide this Pardonere as ye began
Tellith furth youre tale sparith for no man
And teche vs yonge men of youre practike
Gladly qd she sen that it may you like
But that y pray to al this companye
Yif that y speke aftʳ my fantasye
As takith it not a gref that y say
For myn entent is but for to play
Nowe sires then wol y tel furth my tale
As eủere y mot drynke wyne or ale
I shal sey furth thise husbondes that y hadde
As .iijᵉ. of them were good . and .ijᵒ. were badde
The .iijᵉ. men were good and riche and olde
nethe myght they the statute holde
In which they weren bounden vnto me
wote wel what y mene of this parde
helpe me god y laugh when y thynke
pitously a nyght y made hem swynk
And by my feith y tolde of hit no store
They had me yeven there londe and there tresore
Me nedid not do lenger diligence
To wynne there love or don hem reủerence
They loved me so wel by god a bove
That y ne tolde no deynte of there love
A wise womman wol besye hure eủere in one
To geten hure love there as she hath none
But sith that y had them hole in my honde
And aftur that they had yeven me here londe
What shulde y take kepe them for to please
But yif it were for my profite and for myn ease
I sette them so a werke by my fey
That many a nyght they songen welawey
The Bakou was not fet for hem y trowe
That som men haue in Essex at Donmowe
I goủerned hem so wel aftur my lawe
That eche of them ful blisful was and fawe
To brynge me gay thyngis fro the feire
They weren ful fayne whan y spake to them feire
For god it wote y chid them spitously
Nowe herkeneth howe y bare me ꝓpropirly
¶ Ye wise wifes that can vnderstande
Thus shulde ye speke . and beren them on hande
For half so boldely . can ther no man
Swere and lye as a womman can
Y sey this not by wifis that ben wise
But yif it be whan they them mysavise
A wise wif yif that she can hure goode
Shal bere them on hande that the kowe is wode
And take witnes of hure owne Maide
Of hure assent . but herkeneth hou y saide
Sir olde kaynarde this is thyn araye
Why is my Neightbours wif so gay
Sheo is honoured oủere al there she goth
I sit at hom y haue no thrifty cloth
What dost thou at my Neightbours house
Is she so feire . arte thou so Amarouse
What rowne ye with oure Maide . Benedicite
Sir olde lechoure let thy Iapis be
And yif that y haue a Gossipp or a frende
Withouten gilte ye chiden as a fend
Yif that y walke or pley . vn to his house
Thou comst hom as dronkyn as a mouse
And prechist on thy benche with evil pref
Thou seist to me that it is a grete myschef
To wedde a pore womman y for costage
And yif that she be riche of hygh parage
Thou seist than that it is a Turmentrie
To suffre hure pride and hure malyncolie
And yif that she be faire thou verrey knave
Thou seist that eủery holoure wil hure have
She may no while in Chastite a bide
That is hastif a sailed vppon eche a side
Thou seist som folke desiren vs for oure richesse
Som for oure shap and som for oure feirenesse
And som for either she can syng or daunce
And som for hure Ientilnes and daliaunce
Som for hur handes and hure Armes smale
Thise goith al to the Devil by thy tale
Thou seist men may not kepe a Castel wal
It may so longe be assailed oủere al
And yif that she be foule thou seist that she
Covetith eủery man . that she may se
For as a Spanyel she wol on hym lepe
Til that she fynde som man hure to chepe
Ne none so grey Gose goith ther in the lake
As seist thou that wol be withouten a make
And seist it is an harde thyng for to wolde
A thyng that no man wolde his thankis holde
Thus seist thou Lorel whan thou gost to bedde
And that no wise man nedith for to wedde
Ne no man that entendith vn to heven
With wilde Thondre dynt and firy leven
Motte thy wickid necke be to broke
Thou seist that the droppyng hous and eke smoke
And chidyng wifis make men for to fle
Oute of there owne houses a Benedicite
What eilith suche an olde man for to chide
Thou seist we wifis wil oure vices hide
Till we ben fast and then we wol them shewe
Wel may that be a proverbe of a Shrewe
Thou seist thus eke that . Oxen . Asses . hors . and houndi
They ben assaide at diủers stoundes
Basons . Lavours er men hem bye
Spones . Stoles . and suche husbondrie
And so ben pottes . Clothes . and aray
But folke of wifis makyn none assay
Tille they byn weddid . olde Dotard shrewe
And then seist thou . we wol oure vices shewe
Thou seist also that thou displeasist me
But yif that thou wolte preise my beaute
And but thou poure al way vppon my face
And clepe me faire dame in eủery place
And but thou make a feste on thilke day
That y was born and make me fresshe and gay
And but thou do to my Norice honoure
And to my Chambre with yn my boure
And to my Faders folke and his alies
Thus seist thou olde barel ful of lies
And yet for oure apprentise Ienkyn
For his crispe here shynyng as golde fyn
And for he Squyerith me bothe vp and doun
Yet hast thou caught a fals suspecioun
I wol hym not though he were dede to morowe
But tel me this . why hidist thou with sorowe
The keys of thy Chest alway fro me
It is my good aswel as thyn parde
What wenest thou make an ydeot of oure dame
Nowe by that lorde that clepid is seynte Iame
Thou shalte not bothe though thou were wode
Be master of my body and of my gode
That on thou shalte for gon maugre thyn yeen
What nedith the of me to enquere and spyen
I trowe thou woldist lokke me in thy Chest
Thou shuldist sey good wif go where the lest
Takith youre disporte y wol leve no tales
I knowe you for a true wif Dame Ales
We love no man that takith kepe or charge
Where that we go we wol ben at oure large
Of al men blessed be mot he be
That wise Astrologien Daun Protholome
That seith this proverbe in Almagest
Of Al men his wisedom is the best
That reckith not who hath the worlde in hande
By this ꝓproverbe thou shalte vnderstand
Have ye y nough what dar ye recke or care
Hou merily that other folke fare
For certis olde dotarde by youre leve
Ye shal haue queynte right y nowgh atte eve
He is to grete a Nigarde that wol werne
A man to light a Candil at his lanterne
He shal neủere haue the lasse light parde
Have thou y nough thou darstnot pleyne the
Thou seist also yif we make vs gay
With Clothyng or with precious aray
That it is ꝑperil of oure Chastite
And yit with sorowe thou moste en force the
And sey thise wordes in the Apostles name
In habite made in Chastite and in shame
Ye wymmen shulde apparaille you qd hee
And not yn tressed heere and riche perree
As in perles ne with golde ne clothes riche
Aftur thy texte ne aftur thy Rubriche
Y wol not worche as muche as is a gnat
Thou seist thus y walke oute like a Cat
But who so wol senge the Cattis skynne
Then wolde the Catte dwelle in his ynne
And yif the Cattis skyn be slike and gay
She wol not dwelle in house half a day
To shewen hure skyn and go a Catewrawed
But forth she wolde er eny day be dawed
This is to sey yif y be gay Sir shrewe
Y wil renne oute my borel for to shewe
Sir olde fole what helpith the to espien
Though thou preise Argus with his .C. yeen
To be my wardecorps as he may best
In feith he shal not kepe me but yif my lest
Yet coude y make his berde so mot y the
Thou seist eke ther byn thyngis thre
The which thynges troublen al this Erthe
And no wight may enduren the ferthe
O. leve sire shrewe Ihu short thy lif
Yet prechest thou and seist an hateful wif
Rekened is for on of thise myschaunces e
Ben ther none other Resemblaunces
That ye may liken youre parables to
But yif a sely wif be on of tho
Thou likenyst vs eke wommans love to helle
To baren londe there watir may not dwelle
Thou likenest vs eke to wilde fire
The more it brenneth the more it hath desire
To consume eủery thyng that brent wol be
Thou seist right as wormes shenden a Tre
Right so a wif destroith hur husbonde
This knowen they that ben to wifis bonde
Lordynges right thus as ye haue vnderstond
Bare y stifly myn olde husbondes an hond
That thus they seiden yn there drunkynnesse
And al was fals as y toke witnesse
Of Ienkyn and of my Nece also
O. lorde the peyne y did them and the wo
Ful giltles by goddis swete pyne
As an hors y coude bothe bite and whyne
I coude pleyne though y were in the gilt
Or elles often tyme I had ben spilt
Who so comth first to the Mille first he grynt
I pleyned first so was oure warre y stynt
They were ful glad to excuse them blive
Of thyng of which they neủere gilte yn there live
Of wenchis wolde y bere them an honde
When that for sike vnnethis myght they stonde
Yet ticled y his hart for that he
Wende that y of hym had so grete cheriste
Y swore that al my walkyng oute by nyght
Was for to espie wenchis that he dyght
Vnder the coloure had y many a Mirthe
For al suche thynge was yeve vs in oure birthe
Disceite . wepyng . Spynnyng god hath yeve
To wymmen kyndly while that they may leve
And thus of othyng y may avaunte me
Atte the ende y had the bettʳ in eủerich degre
By sleighte or by force or som man̉ere xthyn
by contynual murmurr or grucchyng
ily a bed had they myschaunce
There wolde y chide and do them no plesaunce
I wolde no lengur in the bed a bide
Yif that y felt his arme oủere my side
Til he had made his raunsom vnto me
Than wolde y suffre hym to do his nycite
And therfore eủery man this tale y telle
Wise who so may for al is for to selle
With empty hande men may none hawkis lure
For wynnyng wolde y al his last endure
And make me a feyned a petite
And yit in bacou had y neủere delite
That made me eủere y wolde hem chide
For though the Pope had seten hem beside
Y wolde not spare hem at there owne borde
For by my trouthe y quyte them eủery worde
As helpe me verray god omipotent
Though y right nowe shulde make my testament
I owe them not a worde that it nys quyte
I brought it so a boute by my wytte
That they moste yeve it vp as for the best
Or elles had we neủere ben in rest
For though he loked as wode as a lyou
Yit shulde he faile of high conclusyou
Then wolde y sey good leef lo . take kepe
Hou mekely lokith wilkyn oure shepe
Com nere my spouse let me ba. thy cheke
Ye shulde be al pacient and meke
And haue a swete spiced conscience
Sith ye preche of Iobes pacience
Suffreth alway sithen ye so wel conne pche
And but ye do certayne we shul you teche
That it is faire a man to haue awif in pees
On of vs two . most bowe doutlees
And sith a man is more resonable
Than womman is ye moste be suffrable
What aylith you thus to grucche and grone
Hit is for ye wolde haue my queynte allone
We take it al . lo haue it eủery dele
Petir y shrewe you but ye love it wele
For yif y wolde sel my beel chose
I coude walke as fresshe as is the Ros
But y wol kepe it for youre owne tothe
Ye be to blame by god y sey you sothe
Such man̉ere wordes had we an honde
Nowe wol y speke of my first husbonde
My furst husbonde was a Reveloure
This is to sey he had a ꝑparamoure
And y was yonge and ful of ragerie
Stiborne and stronge and Ioly as a pie
Wel coude y daunce and harpe smale
And syng y wis as eny nyghtyngale
When y had dronkyn a drawght of swete wyne
Metellius the foule Cherle the Swyne
That with a staf berafte his wifis lif
For she dranke wyne . though y had be his wif
He shulde not haue daunted me fro drynke
For aftur wyne . on venus most y thynke
For al so siker as colde engendrith haille
A licorours mowth moste haue a licorous taille
In wymmen vinolent is none defence
This knowen lechours by exꝑperience
But lorde Crist but when it remembrith me
Vppon my youth and vppon my Iolite
Hit tikleth me a boute the harte rote
Vnto this day it doth myn harte bote
That y haue had my worlde as in my tyme
But age alas that al wol envenyme
Hath me berafte my beaute and my pith
Let it go farewel the devil go ther with
The floure is gon there is no more to telle
The bren as y best may nowe mott y selle
But yet to be right mery wol y fonde
Nowe wol y tel of my .ijde. husbonde
I seie y had in harte grete dispite
That he of eny other had delite
But he was quyt by god and by seynt Ioce
Y made hym of the same wode a Croce
But certaynly y made folke suche chere
Nat of my body in no foule manere
That in his owne grece made hym frie
For angre and for verrey Iolesie
For which y hope his soule be in glori
god in erthe y was his Purgatorie
god it wote he sate ful ofte and songe
When that hys sho ful bittirly hym wronge
There was no wight save god and he wist
many a wise hou sore y hym twist
He died when y come fro Ierusalem
And lieth in his Grave vnder the Rode Bem
Al is his Toumbe not so curious
As was the Sepulture of hym Darious
Which that Appelles wrought subtelly
It is but wast to berie hym preciously
Lette hym fare wel god yeve his soule good rest
He is nowe in Grave and deed in his Chest
Nowe of my .iijde. husbonde wolle y telle
God let his Soule neủere com in helle
And yet was he to me the moste shrewe
That fele y nowe on my Ribbes al a rewe
And eủere shal vnto myn endyng day
But in oure bed he was ful fresshe and gay
And therewith also wel coude he me glose
Whan that he wolde haue my beele chose
That though he had bete me on eủery bone
He coude wyn ageyne my love a none
I trowe y lovid hym best for that he
Was of his love so daungerous to me
We wymmen haue y that y shal not lie
In this mater a queynt fantesie
Waite what thyng we may lightly have
There aftur wol we crie alday and crave
For bede vs a thyng . and that desiren we
Prece on vs . and than wol we fle
With daunger vtter we al oure Chaffare
Grete prece at the Market makith dere ware
And to grete chepe . is holde at litle prise
This knowith eủery womman that is wise
My .iiijth. husbonde god hissoule blesse
Which y toke for love and for no richesse
He somtyme was a Clerke of Oxonford
And had lefte scole and went at hom to bord
With my Gossibbe dwellyng in oure toun
God saue hure soule hure name was Alisoun
She knewe myn harte and eke my privit
Bet than oure parisshe prest so mot y the
To hure bewreied y my counsaile al
For had myn husbonde pissid on a wal
Or don a thyng that shulde haue cost his lif
To hure and to a nother worthy wif
And to my Nece . which that y lovid wel
I wolde haue tolde his counsaile eủery del
That made his face ful ofte red and hote
And so y did ful ofte god it wote
For verrey shame and blamed hym self that he
Had tolde to me so grete a privete
And so bifele that ones in a lente
So ofte tyme y to my gossip wente
For eủere yet y lovid to be gay
And for to walke yn March . April . and May
Fro house to house to here sondry tales
That Iankyn Clerke and my Gossip dame Ales
And y my self vnto the feldis went
Myn husbonde was at londou al that lent
I had the bettre leiser for to pley
And for to se and eke for to be sey
Of lusty folke . what wist y where my grace
Shape was for lo be or in what place
Therfore y made my visitacions
To vigiles and to processions
To prechyng eke and to thise pilgrimages
To pleys of miracles and to Mariages
And wered vppon my gay Scarlet Gites
Thise wormes thise mothis ne thise mytes
Vppon myn appareile frete they neủere a del
And wost thou why for they weren vsed wel
¶ Nowe wol y tel hou it happid me
Y sey that in the feldis walkid we
Til truly we had suche daliaunce
This Clerke and y what of my purveaunce
Y spake to hym and seide hou that he
Yif that y were widowe he shulde wed me
For certis y sey for non bobaunce
Yit was y neủere withoute purveaunce
Of mariage ne of other thynges eke
I holde a mouses harte not worth a lek
t hath but one hole for to stert to
yif that faile then is al y do
Y bare hym an honde he had enchauntid me
My dame taught me that subtilte
And eke y seide y mette of hym al nyght
He wolde haue slayne me as y lay vpryght
And al my bed was ful of verrey blood
But yit y hope ye shul do me good
For blood betokeneth golde as was me taught
And al was fals y dremed of hym right naught
But as y folowed ay my dames lore
As wel of that as of other thynges more
And nowe sire let me se what shulde y seyne
A . ha . by god y haue my tale ageyne
When that my .iiijth. husbonde was on bere
I wepe al gate and made sory chere
As wifis moten for it is the vsage
And with kerchief y coủered my visage
And for y was purveide of a make
I wepte but smal y vndertake
To cherche was myn husbond born a morowe
With Neightbours that for hym maden sorowe
And Iankyn oure Clerke was on of tho
As helpe me god and when y saugh hym go
Aftur the Biere me thought he had a peire
Of legges and of fete so clene and so feire
That al myn harte y yaf vnto his holde
He was y trowe of .xxᵗⁱ. wyntir olde
And y was .xlti. yif y shal sey the sothe
But yet had y alway a Coltis tothe
Gaptothed y was and that become me wele
I had the preynte of Seynt Venus sele
As helpe me god y was a lusty on
And feire and riche and yonge and wel begon
And truly as myn husbondes tolde me
I had the best Quonyam that myght be
For certis y am ful venerien
In felyng of myn harte is Mercien
Venus me yaf my lust and my licourisnesse
And Mars yaf me my sturdy hardinesse
Myn ascendent was Taure and Mars there Inne
Alas . alas that eủere love was synn
Y folowid ay myn Inclynacioun
By vertue of my Constellacioun
That made me y coude not with drawe
My Chambre of venus from a good felawe
Yet haue y Mars marke vppon my face
And also in another prive place
For god so wisly be my saluacyou
I levid neủere by no discreciou
But eủere folowed myn apetite
Al were he shorte longe blak or white
I toke no kepe so that he likid me
Hou poure he was ne eke of what degre
What shulde y seie but at the monthis ende
This Ioly Clerke Ienkyn that was so hende
Hath weddid me with grete solempnyte
And to hym yaf y al the londe and fe
That eủere was me yeve there byfore
But afturward me repentid ful sore
He nolde suffre no thyng of my list
By god he smote me onys with his fist
On the Cheke for y rent oute of his boke a leef
That of that stroke myn ere wax al deef
Styborne y was as is a lyonesse
And of my tonge a verrey Iangleresse
And walke y wolde as y had don biforn
Fro house to house al though that he had it sworn
For which he oftyme wolde preche
And me of olde Romayns gestis teche
Hou Symplicius Gallus left his wif
And hure forsoke certeyn for al his lif
Nought but for open hed he hure say
Lokyng oute at his dore vppon a day
A nother Romayn tolde he me by name
That for his wif was at Somer game
With outyn his wetyng he forsoke hure eke
And then wolde he vppon his bible seke
That ilke proverbe of eccliāesiaste
Where that he commaundith and biddith faste
Men shulde not suffre his wif to go roial aboute
Then wolde he seyn thus withoute doute
Who that bildith his house al with salwes
And prickith his blynde hors oủere the falwe
And suffreth his wif to seke Halowes
worthy to be hanged on the Galowes
But al for naught y sette it not at an hawe
al his proverbis ne of his olde sawe
y wolde not of hym correctid be
I hate hym that of my vices tel me
And so god wote do mo of vs than y
This made hym with me wood al wittirly
I nolde hym forbere in no cas
Nowe wol y sey you sothe by seynt Thomas
Why that y rent oute of his boke a leef
For which he smote me so that y am deef
He had a boke that gladly nyght and day
For his disporte he wolde rede alway
He clepid it Valerie and Theofaste
Atte the which boke he lough alway ful fast
And eke there was a Clerke som tyme a Rome
A Cardynal that hight seynte Ierome
That made a boke a yenst Iouynyan
In which boke eke there was Tertulian
Crispus . Trotula . and helowys
That was Abbesse not fer fro Parys
And eke the Parables of Salomon
Ovides art and bokys many on
And al thise weren boıı̄unde in on volume
And eủery nyght and day was his Custume
Whan he had leyser and vacaciou
From other worldly occupaciou
To rede on this boke of wicked wifis
He knewe of them mo legendis and lifis
Than be of good wifis in the bible
For trustith wel it is an vnpossible
That eny Clerke wol speke of good wifes
But yif it be of holy seyntes lifes
Ne of none other wymmen neủere the mo
Who peynted the lyou tel me who
By god yif wymmen had writen stories
As Clerkis haue within here oratories
They wolde haue writen of men more wickidnesse
Than al the markis of Adam coude redresse
The Children of Mercurie and of venus
Ben in there werking ful contrarius
Mercurie lovith wisdom and scienc
And venus lovith roiot and dispence
And for here diủers disposiciou
Eche falleth in others exaltaciou
And thus god wote Mercurie is desolate
In pisses when venus is exaltate
And venus falleth there Mercurie is reised
Therfore womman of no Clerke is preised
The Clerke when he is olde and may naught do
Of venus werkis nought worth his olde sho
Then sittith he doun and writith in his dotage
That wymmen connat kepe there mariage
But nowe to purpos why that y tolde the
That y was bete for a boke parde
Vppon a nyght Iankyn that was oure Sire
Redde on his boke as he sate by the fire
Of Eve first that for hure wickidnesse
Was al mankynde brought to wrechidnesse
For which that Ihu Criste hym self was slayne
That bought vs with his harte blode a gayne
Lo here expresse of wymmen may ye fynde
That wymmen were the los of al mankynde
Tho radde he me hou Sampsou lost his heres
Slepyng his lemman kut hit with hure Sheres
Thrugh which treasou lost he bothe his yeen
Tho radde he me yif y shal not lyen
Of Ercules . and of Dyanyre
That caused hym to sette hym self a fyre
Nothyng forgate he the sorowe and the wo
That Socrates had with his wifis two
Hou Exantipa . cast pisse vppon his hede
This sely man sate stil as he were dede
He wipte his yeen no more durst he seyn
But er that the Thundre stynt there comth a reyne
Of Phisipha that was the Quene of Crete
For shrewdnesse hym thought the tale swete
Fy . speke no more it is a grisly thyng
Of hure horrible lust and hure likyng
Of Clitermistra for hure lecherie
That falsly made hure husbonde forto die
He radde yit ful good devocioun
He tolde me eke for what occasioun
Amphiorax at Thebes lost his li
n husbond had a legende of his wif
philem that for an ouche of golde
h prively vnto the Grekes tolde
re that hure husbond hid hym in a place
which he had at Thebes a sory grace
lyuia tolde he me and of lucie
y bothe made hure husbondes forto die

ia licorous lovid hure husbond so
For that he shulde alway vppon hure thynke
She yaf hym such a man̉ere love drynke
That he was dede or it were a morowe
And thus algatis husbondes haue moche sorowe
Then tolde he me hou that latymeus
Compleyned vnto his felawe Arryus
That in his garden growed suche a tre
On which he seide hou that his wifis thre
Hanged hem self for hartis dispituous
O. leve Brother qd this Arrious
Yeve me a plante of that ilke tre
And in my Garden plantid shall it be
Of latter date of wifis hath he red
That som haue slayne hure husbondes in ther bed
And lette hure lecchoure dight hure al the nyght
When the Corps lay dede in the flore vpright
And som haue driven naylis in there brayne
Whiles that they slepe and thus they haue them slayne
Som haue yeve them poisou yn there drynke
He spake more harme than harte may thynke
And there with al he knewe of mo proverbis
Than in this worlde growen gresses or herbis
Bettir is qd he thyn habitacioun
Be with a lyou or with a foule dragoun
Than with a womman vsyng for to chide
Bettir is qd he high in the Rofe to abide
Than with an angry wif doun in the house
They ben so wicked and so contrariouse
They haten that hure husbondes loven ay
He seide a womman castith hure shame away
When she castith of hure smocke and further m
A faire womman but she be chast also
Is like a Goldryng on a Sowis nose
Who wolde leve or who wolde suppose
The wo that was in myn herte and pyne
And when y saugh he wolde neủere fyne
To rede on his cursed boke al nyght
And sodenly .iij. levis haue y plyght
Oute of his boke right as he rad and eke
Y with my fist so toke hym on the cheke
That in oure fire he fel bakward a doun
And he vp stert as doth a wode lyou
And with his fist he smote me on the hede
That in the flore y lay as y were dede
And when he sey hou stil that y lay
He was a gast and wolde haue fled a way
Til at the last oute of my swoun y breide
O. hast thou slayne me fals thef y seide
And for my lande thus hast thou murthrid me
Or y be dede yit wol y kysse the
And nere he came and kneled faire adoun
And seide dere Sustir Alisoun
As helpe me god y wol the neủere smyte
That y haue don it is thy self to wyte
For yeve it me and that y the beseche
And yet eftesones y hitte hym on the cheke
And seide thef thus moche am y a wreke
Nowe wol y die y may no lenger speke
But at the last with moche care and wo
We fele accordid betwen vs selfen two
He yaf me al the bridel in myn honde
To haue the goủernaunce of house and londe
And of his tonge and his honde also
And made hym bren his boke anon right tho
And when that y had goten vnto me
By Mastrie al the soủeraynte
And that he seide myn owne true wif
Do as the list the t̉erme of al thy lif
Kepe thyn honoure and eke myn estate
And aftur that day we had neủere debate
God helpe me so y was to hym as kynde
As eny wif fro Denmarke in to ynde
And al so true and so was he to me
I pray to god that sittith in Magist
So blesse his soule for his mercy dere
We woll y sey my tale yif ye wol \it/ here
The Frere lough when he had hard all this
Wolde dame qd he so haue y joy or blis
This is a longe preamble of a tale
And when the sompnoure harde the Frere gale
To qd the sompnoure for goddis armes two
A Frere woll entremete hym eủere mo
To good men a flie and eke a Frere
Woll fall in eủery disshe and matere
What devill spekist thou of preambulacioun
What Aumbill . or trot . or pisse . or go sit a doun
Thou lettist of oure disport in this manere
Ye wolt thou so sompnoure qd the Frere
Nowe by my feith . y shall er that y go
Telle of a sompnoure suche atale or two
That all the folke shull laughe in this place
Nowe elles Frere y beshrewe thy face
Quod this sompnoure and y beshrewe me
But yif y tel tales .ijᵒ. or thre
Of freres er that y com at sydyngborne
That y shall make thyn harte to morne
For wel y wote thy pacience is gone
Oure hoste cried pees and that anone
And seide let the womman tell hure tale
Ye fare as folke that drunken ben of ale
Do dame tell furth youre tale and that is best
All redy Sir qd she right as you lest
Yif y haue licence of this worthy Frere
Yis Dame qd he . tel furth and y shall you here
Hic finitur prologus vxoris de Bathe
Et hir incipit fabiila vxoris de Bathe
In olde days of the kynge Arthoure
Of whom that Britons speken greet honoure
All was this londe full of Feirie
The Elf Quene with ioly compainie
Daunced full ofte in many a grene mede
This was the olde opynioun as y rede
Y speke of many hundred yeres ago
But nowe can no man se Elfes m

div.l: For nowe the grete cherite and preyres
Of lymitours and of other holy Freres
That serchyn̄ eủery londe and eủery streme
As thike as motes in the sonne beme
Blessyng halles Chambres kichyns and bowres
Citees · Burghes Castels and high Towres
Thropis Barnes · Shepens Dayries
This makith that ther ben̄ no fayries
For there as wont wits to walks an̄ Elf
There walkith the lymitoure hym̄ self
In vndermeles and in morwenyngis
And seith his matens and his holy thyngis
As he goith in his lymytacioun̄
Wymmen̄ mwe go safly vp͒ and doun̄
In eủery busshe or vnder eủery Tre
There is none other Incubus but he
And he nell don̄ them̄ nodamaged texte dishonoure
MarginaliaAnd so bifell that this kynge Arthoure
Had in his house a lusty Bachelere
That on a day com̄ ridyngi fro the Rivere
And hapnedi that alone as he was born
He sangh a maide walkyngi hym̄ biforn
Of which maide anon̄ maugre hure hede
By verrey force he rafte hure maiden hede
For which oppressioıı̄un was suche clamoure
And suche pursute to kyng Arthoure
That dampnedi was this knyght for to be dede
By cours of lawe and shulde hane lost his hede
Par abenture suche was text erased the statute tho
But that the Quene and other ladies mo
So longe praiden̄ the kynge of grace
Till that he his lif grauntidi in that place
And yafi hym̄ to the Quene all at hure wille
To chese whether she wolde hym̄ saw or spille
The Quene thankidi the kynge with all hure myght
And aftur this·thus spake she vnto the knyght

That of thy lif yit hast thou no suorte

What thynge is it that wymmen̄ most desiren

div.l: Be ware and kepe thyn necke from Iren
And yif thon canst not tell it anon
Yit woll y yeue the lif for to gon
A XIIᵉ and on day to seche and lere
An annswere sufficiantly in this matere
And suerte woll y hane er that thou passe
Thy bodis for to yelden in this place
Wo was this knyght. and sorowfully he sikith
But he may not do all as hym likith
And at the last he chese hym forto wende
And com ayan right at the yeres ende
With suche annswere as god wold hym purveye
And takith his leve and wendith furth his weye
He sekith eny house and eny place
Where he hopith to fynde his grace
To lerne what thyng wymmen loven moste
But he coude ariven in no Coste
Where as he myghte fynde in this matere
Two creatures accordyng in fere
Som seiden wymmen love best richesse
Som seide honoure som seide Iolynesse
Som riche aray som seide lust abedde
And ofte tyme to be widdwe and wedde
Somme seide that oure harte is most eased
When that we been flaterd and pleased
He goith full nygh the soth y woll not lye
A man shall wyn vs best with flaterye
And with attendaunce and with besynesse
Ben we lymed bothe more and lesse
And som seide that we love best
For to be fre and do right as vs lest
And that no man repreve vs of oure vice
But sey that we be wis and nothyng nice
For truly there is none of vs alle
Yif eny wight woll clawe vs on the galle
That we nyll like for he seith vs sothe

Approcheth that this weddyng sholde be
And al the palays put was in array
Bothe halle and chambres ech in his degree
Houses of office stuffed with plentee
Ther maystow seen of deynteuous vitaille
That may be founde as fer as last Ytaille
This Roial Markys richeliche arrayed
Lordes and ladys in his compaignye
The whiche that to the feste were yprayed
And of his retenue the Bachilrye
With many a sown of sondry melodye
Vn to the village of the which I tolde
In this array the righte wey han holde
Grisilde of this god woot ful Innocent
That for hir shapen was al this array
To fecchen water at a welle is went
And cometh hom as soone as euer she may
For wel she hadde herd seyd that thilke day
The Markys sholde wedde and if she myghte
She wolde fayn han seyn som of that sighte
She thoghte I wole with othere maydens stonde
That been my felawes in oure dore and se
The Markisesse and therfore wol I fonde
To doon at hom as soone as it may be
The labour which that longeth vn to me
And thanne I may at leyser hir biholde
Yf she this wey vn to the Castel holde
And as she wolde ouer the thresshfold gon
The Markys cam and gan hir for to calle
And she sette doun hir water pot anon
Bisyde the thresshfold in an Oxes Stalle
And doun vp on hir knees she gan to falle
And with sad contenance kneleth stille
Til she hadde herd what was the lordes wille
This thoghtful Markys spak vn to this mayde
Ful sobrely and seyde in this manere
Where is youre fader o Grisildis he sayde
And she with reuerence in humble cheere
Answerde lord he is al redy heere
And she goth with outen lenger lette
And to the Markys she hir fader fette
He by the hand than took this olde man
And seyde thus whan he hym hadde asyde
Ianicula I neither may ne kan
Lenger the plesance of myn herte hyde
If that thow vouche sauf what so bityde
Thy doghter wol I take er that I wende
As for my wyf vn to my lyues ende
Thow louest me I woot it wel certeyn
And art my feithful lige man ybore
And al that liketh me I dar wel seyn
It liketh thee and specially ther fore
Tel me that point that I haue seyd bifore
If that thow wolt vn to that purpos drawe
To take me as for thy sone in lawe
The sodeyn cas this man astoneyd so
That reed he weex abayst and al quakyng
He stood vnnethe seyde he wordes mo
But oonly this lord quod he my willyng
Is as ye wole ne ayeins youre likyng
I wol no thyng ye be my lord so deere
Right as yow list gouerneth this matere
Yet wol I quod this Markys softely
That in thy chambre I and thow and she
Haue a collacioun and wostow why
For I wol aske if it hir wille be
To be my wyf and rule hir after me
And al this shal be doon in thy persence
I wol noght speke out of thyn audience
And in the chambre whil they were aboute
Hir tretys which as ye shal after heere
The peple cam vn to the hous with oute
And wondred hem in how honeste manere
And tentifly she kepte hir fader deere
But outrely Grisildis wondre myghte
For neuere eft ne saw she swich a sighte
No wonder is thogh that she were astoned
To seen so greet a gest come in to place
She neuere was to swiche gestes woned
For which she looked with ful pale face
But shortly forth this matere for to chace
Thise arn the wordes that this Markys sayde
To this benygne verray feithful mayde
Grisilde he seyde ye shal wel vnderstonde
It liketh to youre fader and to me
That I yow wedde and eek it may so stonde
As I suppose ye wol that it so be
But thise demandes aske I first quod he
That sith it shal be doon in hastif wyse
Wol ye assente or ellis yow auyse
I sey this be ye redy with good herte
To al my lust and that I frely may
As me best thynketh do yow laughe or smerte
And neuere ye to grucche it nyght ne day
And eek whan I sey ye ne sey nat nay
Neither by word ne frownyng contenance
Swere this and heere I swere oure alliance
Wondrynge vp on this word quakyng for drede
She seyde lord vndigne or vnworthy
I am to thilke honour that ye me bede
But as ye wol your self right so wol I
And heere I swere that neuere willyngly
In werk ne thoght I nel yow disobeye
For to be deed thogh me were looth to deye
This is ynough Grisilde myn quod he
And forth he goth with a ful sobre cheere
Out at the dore and after that cam she
And to the peple he seyde in this manere
This is my wyf quod he that standeth heere
Honureth hire and loueth hire I preye
Who so me loueth ther is namoore to seye
And for that no thyng of hir olde gere
She sholde brynge in to his hous he bad
That wommen sholde dispoylen hir right there
Of which thise ladys were noght right glad
To handle hir clothes wher Inne she was clad
But nathelees this mayde bright of hewe
Fro foot to heed they clothed han al newe
Hir herys han they kembd that laye vntressed
Ful rudely and with hir fyngres smale
A coroune on hir heed they han ydressed
ꝙquoday tyred hire heed that longe rudely lay dressed
And sette hir ful Nowches grete and smale
Of hir array what sholde I make a tale
Sche is now fair of hew that arst was pale
Vnnethe the peple hir knew for hir fairnesse
Whan she translated was in swich richesse
This Markys hath hire spoused with a ryng
Broght for the same cause and thanne hir sette
Vp on an hors snow whyt and wel amblyng
And to his palays er he lenger lette
With ioyful peple that hir ledde and mette
Convoied hire and thus the day they spende
In reuel til the sonne gan descende
And shortly forth this tale for to chace
I seye that to this newe Markysesse
God hath swich fauour sent hire of his grace
That it ne semed nat by liklynesse
That she was born and fed in rudenesse
As in a cote or in an Oxes Stalle
But norissed in an Emperours halle
Was as well tauȝt as any wiȝt in an emperours halle
To euery wight she woxen is so deere
And worshipful that folk ther she was bore
That from hir burthe knewe hir yeer by yeere
Vnnethe trowed they but dorste han swore
That to Ianicle of which I spak bifore
She doghter were for as by coniecture
Hem thoughte she was another creature
For thogh that euere vertuous was she
She was encressed in swich excellence
Of thewes goode yset in heigh bountee
And so discreet and fair of eloquence
So benygne and so digne of reuerence
And koude so the peples herte embrace
That ech hir louede that looked on hir face
Noght oonly of Saluce in the town
Publissed was the bountee of hir name
But eek bisyde in many a Regioun
If oon seyde wel another seyde the same
So spradde of hir heighe bountee the fame
That men and wommen as wel yonge as olde
Goon to Saluce on hir to biholde
Thus Walter lowely nay but roially
Wedded with fortunat honestetee
In goddes pees lyueth ful esily
At hom and outward grace ynow hath he
And for he saugh that vnder lowe degree
Was ofte vertu hyd the peple hym helde
A prudent man and that is seyn ful selde
Noght oonly this Grisildis thurgh hir wit
Koude al the feet of wifly humblenesse
But eek whan that the cas required it
The commune profit koude she redresse
Ther nas discord rancour ne heuynesse
In al that land that she ne koude apese
And wisly brynge hem alle in reste andese
Thogh that hir housbond absent were anon
If gentil men or othere of hir contree
Were wrothe she wolde bryngen hem aton
So wise and rype wordes hadde she
And Iuggementz of so greet equytee
That she from heuene sent was as men wende
Peple to saue and euery wrong tamende
Nat longe tyme after that this Grisild
Was ywedded she a doghter hath ybore
Al hadde hir leuere haue had a knaue child
Glad was the Markys and the folk ther fore
For thogh a mayde child coome al bifore
She may vn to a knaue child atteyne
By liklyhede syn she nys nat bareyne
¶ Incipit tercia pars
Ther fil as it bifalleth tymes mo
Whan that this child hath souked but a throwe
This Markys in his herte longeth so
To tempte his wyf hir sadnesse for to knowe
That he ne myghte out of his herte throwe
This merueilous desir his wyf tassaye
Nedelees god woot he thoghte hir for tafraye
Forbere / wherfore he purposid on a day
He hadde assayed hir ynow bifore
And fond hir euere good what neded it
Hir for to tempte and alwey moore and moore
Thogh som men preyse it for a subtil wit
But as for me I seye that yuele it sit
Tassaye a wyf whan that it is no nede
And putten hir in angwyssh and in drede
For which this Markys wroghte in this manere
He cam allone a nyght ther as she lay
With steerne face and with ful trouble cheere
And seyde thus Grisilde quod he that day
That I yow took out of your poure array
And putte yow in estat of heigh noblesse
Ye haue nat that forgeten as I gesse
I seye Grisilde this persent dignitee
In which that I haue put yow as I trowe
Maketh yow nat foryetful for to be
That I yow took in poure estat ful lowe
For any wele ye mote your seluen knowe
Tak hede of euery word that I yow seye
Ther is no wight that hereth it but we tweye
Ye woot your self wel how that ye cam heere
In to this hous it is nat longe ago
And thogh to me that ye be lief and deere
Vnto my gentils ye be no thyng so
They seyn to hem it is greet shame and wo
For to be subgitz and been in seruage
To thee that born art of a smal village
And namely sith thy doghter was ybore
Thise wordes han they spoken doutelees
But I desire as I haue doon bifore
To lyue my lyf with hem in reste and pees
I may nat in this cas be recchelees
I moot doon with thy doghter for the beste
Nat as I wolde but as my peple leste
And yet god woot this is ful looth to me
But nathelees with outen your wityng
I wol nat doon but this wol I quod he
That ye to me assente as in this thyng
Shewe now youre pacience in your wirkyng
As we accorded was at the begynnyng
That ye me highte and swore in yone village
By youre bihest a fore youre fader ᵒage
That day that maked was oure mariage
Whan she hadde herd al this she noght ameued
Neither in word or cheere or contenance
For as it semed she was nat agreued
She seyde lord al lith in your plesance
My child and I with hertly obeisance
Been youres al and ye mowe saue or spille
Youre owene thyng werketh after your wille
Ther may no thyng god so my soule saue
Liken to yow that may displesen me
Ne I ne desire no thyng for to haue
Ne drede for to lese saue oonly thee vel ye
This wyl is in myn herte and ay shal be
No lengthe of tyme or deth may this deface
Ne chaunge my corage to oother place
Glad was this Markys of hir answeryng
But yet he feyned as he were nat so
Al drery was his cheere and his lookyng
Whan that he sholde out of the chambre go
Soone after this a furlang wey or two
He pryuely hath told al his entente
Vn to a man and to his wyf hym sente

A maner sergeant was this priuee man
The which that feithful ofte he founden hadde
In thynges grete and eek swich folk wel kan
Doon execucioun in thynges badde
The lord knew wel that he m loued and dradde
And whan this sergeant wiste his lordes wille
In to the chambre he stalked hym ful stille
Madame he seyde ye mote foryeue it me
Thogh I do thyng to which I am constreyned
Ye ben so wys that ful wel knowe ye
That lordes hestes mowe nat ben yfeyned
They mowe wel been biwailled or compleyned
But men mote nede vn to hir lust obeye
And so wol I ther is namoore to seye
This child I am comaunded for to take
And spak namoore but out the child he hente
Despitously and gan a cheere make
As thogh he wolde han slayn it er he wente
Grisildis moot al suffre and al consen te
And as a lamb she sitteth meke and stille
And leet this crewel sergeant doon his wille
Suspecious was the diffame of this man
Suspect his face suspect his word also
Suspect the tyme in which he this bigan
Allas hir doghter that she loued so
She wende he wolde han slayn it right tho
But nathelees she neither weep ne syked
Conformynge hire to that the Markys liked
But at the laste speken she bigan
And mekely she to the Sergeant preyde
So as he was a worthy gentil man
That she moste kisse hir child er that it deyde
And on hir barm this litel child she leyde
With ful sad face and gan the child to blesse
And lulled it and after gan it kesse
And thus she seyde in hir benygne voys
Fare wel my child I shal thee neuere see
But sith I thee haue marked with the croys
Of thilke fader blessed mote he be
That for vs deyde vp on a croys of tree
Thy soule litel child I hym bitake
For this nyght shaltow dyen for my sake
I trowe that to a Norice in this cas
It hadde been hard this routhe for to se
Wel myghte a moder haue cryd allas
But nathelees so sad stedefast was she
That she endured al aduersitee
And to the Sergeant mekely she sayde
Haue here agayn youre litel yonge mayde
Goth now quod she and doth my lordes heste
But o thyng wol I pray yow of youre grace
That but my lord forbad yow at the leeste
Burieth this litel body in som place
That bestes ne no bryddes it to race
But he no word wol to that purpos seye
But took the child and wente vp on his weye
This sergeant cam vn to his lord agayn
And of Grisildis wordes and hir cheere
He tolde hym poynt for poynt in short and playn
And hym persenteth with his doghter deere
Som what this lord hadde routhe in his manere
But nathelees his purpos held he stille
As lordes doon whan they wol han hir wille
And bad this Sergeant that he pryuely
Sholde this child softe wynde and wrappe
With alle circumstances tendrely
And carie it in a cofre or in a lappe
But vp on peyne his heed of for to swappe
That no man sholde knowe of this entente
Ne whennes he cam ne whider that he wente
But at Boloigne he to his suster deere
That thilke tyme of Pauyk was Countesse
He sholde it take and shewe hir this matere
Bisekynge hir to doon hir bisynesse
This child to fostre in alle gentilesse
And whos child that it was he bad hir hyde
From euery wight for aught that may bityde
The Sergeant goth and hath fulfild this thyng
But to this Markys now retourne we
For now goth he ful faste ymagynyng
If by his wyues cheere he myghte se
Or by hir word aperceyue that she
Were chaunged but he neuere hir koude fynde
But euere in oon ylike sad and kynde
As glad as humble as busy in seruyse
And eek in loue as she was wont to be
Was she to hym in euery maner wise
Ne of hir doghter noght a word spak she
Noon accident for noon aduersitee
Was seyn in hir ne neuere hir doghter name
Ne nempned she in ernest ne in game
