IN this estat ther passed ben 4 yeer
Er she with childe was but as god wolde
A knaue child she bar by this Walter
Ful gracious and fair for to biholde
And whan that folk it to his fader tolde
Nat oonly he but al his contree merye
Was for this child and god they thanke and herye
Whan it was two yeer old and fro the brest
Departed of his Norice on a day
This Markys caughte yet another lest
To tempte his wyf yet ofter if he may
O nedelees was she tempted in assay
But wedded men ne knowe no mesure
Whan that they fynde a pacient creature
Wyf quod this Markys ye han herd er this
My peple sikly berth this mariage
And namely sith my sone yborn is
Now is it worse than euere in al oure age
The murmur sleeth myn herte and my corage
For to myne erys comth the voys so smerte
That it wel neigh destroyed hath myn herte
Now sey they thus whan Walter is agon
Thanne shal the blood of Ianycle succede
And been oure lord for oother haue we noon
Swiche wordes seith my peple out of drede
Wel oghte I of swich murmur taken hede
For certeinly I drede swich sentence
Though they nat pleyn speke in myn audience
I wolde lyue in pees if that I myghte
Wherfore I am disposed outrely
As I his suster serued by nyghte
Right so thenke I to serue hym priuely
This warne I yow that ye nat sodeynly
Out of your self for no wo sholde outraye
Beth pacient and ther of I yow praye
I haue quod she seyd thus and euere shal
I wol no thyng ne nyl no thyng certeyn
But as yow list noght greueth me at al
Thogh that my doghter and my sone be sleyn
At youre comandement this is to seyn
I haue nat had no part of children tweyne
But first siknesse and after wo and peyne
Ye ben oure lord dooth with your owene thyng
Right as yow list axeth no reed of me
For as I lefte at hom al my clothyng
Whan I first cam to yow right so quod she
Lefte I my wyl and al my libertee
And took youre clothyng wher fore I yow preye
Dooth your plesance I wol youre lust obeye
And certes if I hadde prescience
Youre wyl to knowe er ye your lust me tolde
I wolde it doon with outen necligence
But now I woot youre lust and what ye wolde
Al your plesance ferm and stable I holde
For wiste I that my deeth wolde doon yow ese
Right gladly wolde I dyen yow to plese
Deeth may nat make no comparisoun
Vn to youre loue and whan this Markys say
The constance of his wyf he caste adoun
Hise eyen two and wondreth that she may
In pacience suffre al this array
And forth he goth with drery contenance
But to his herte it was ful gret plesance
This vggly geant in the same wyse
That he hir doghter caughte right so he
Or worse if men worse kan deuyse
Hath hent hir sone that ful was of beautee
And euere in oon so pacient was she
That she no cheere made of heuynesse
But kiste hir sone and after gan it blesse
Saue this she prayde hym that if he myghte
Hir litel sone he wolde in erthe graue
His tendre lymes delicat to sighte
Fro foweles and fro bestes hem to saue
But she noon answere of hym myghte haue
He wente his wey as hym no thyng roghte
But to Boloigne he tendrely it broghte
This Markys wondreth euer lenger the moore
Vp on hir pacience and if that he
Ne hadde soothly knowen ther bifoore
That perfitly hir children loued she
He wolde haue wend that of som subtiltee
And of malice or of cruel corage
That she hadde suffred this with sad visage
But wel he knew that next hym self certayn
She loued hir children best in euery wise
But now of wommen wolde I asken fayn
If thise assayes myghte nat suffise
What koude a sturdy housbond moore deuyse
To proue hir wifhod and hir stedfastnesse
And he contynuynge euere in sturdynesse
But ther ben folk of swich condicioun
That whan they haue a certeyn purpos take
And so wilful suche assayes to make
They kan nat stynte of hir entencioun
But right as they were bounden to that stake
They wol nat of that firste purpos slake
Right so this Markys fulliche hath purposed
To tempte his wyf as he was first disposed
He wayteth if by word or contenance
That she to hym was chaunged of corage
But neuere koude he fynde variance
She was ay oon in herte and in visage
And ay the ferther that she was of age
The moore trewe if that it were possible
She was to hym in loue and moore penyble
For which it semed thus that of hem two
Ther nas but o wyl for as Walter leste
The same lust was hir plesance also
And god be thanked al fyl for the beste
She shewed wel for no worldly vnreste
A wif as of hir self no thyng ne sholde
Wille in effect but as hir housbond wolde
The sclaundre of Walter ofte and wyde spradde
That of a cruel herte he wikkedly
For he a poure womman wedded hadde
Hath mordred bothe his children pryuely
Swich murmur was among hem comunly
No wonder is for to the peples ere
Ther cam no word but that they mordred were
For which wher as his peple ther bifore
Hadde loued hym wel the sclaundre of his diffame
Made hem that they hym hated therfore
To ben a mordrer is an hateful name
But natheles for ernest ne for game
He of his cruel purpos nolde stente
To tempte his wyf was set al his entente
Whan that this doghter xij yer was of age
He to the court of Rome in subtil wise
Enformed of his wil sente his message
Comaundynge hem swiche bulles to deuyse
As to his cruel purpos may suffise
Ini maner and in this same gyse
How that the pope as for his peples reste
Bad hym to wedde another if hym leste
I seye he bad they sholde contrefete
The popes bulles makyng mencioun
That he hath leue his firste wyf to lete
As by the popes dispensacioun
To stynte rancour and dissencioun
Bitwix his peple and hym thus seyde the bulle
The which they han publissed at the fulle
The rude peple as it no wonder is
Wenden ful wel that it hadde ben right so
But whan thise tidynges cam to Grisildis
I deme that hir herte was ful wo
But she ylike sad for euere mo
Disposed was this humble creature
Thaduersitee of Fortune al tendure
Abidynge euere his lust and his plesance
To whom that she was yeuen herte and al
As to hir verray worldly suffisance
But shortly if this storie I tellen shal
This Markys writen hath in special
A lettre in which he sheweth his entente
And secrely he to Boloigne it sente
To the Erl of Pavyk which that hadde tho
Wedded his suster prayde he specially
To bryngen hom agayn his children two
In honurable estat al openly
But o thyng he hym prayde outrely
That he to no wight thgh men wolde enquere
Sholde nat tellen whos children that they were
But seye the mayden sholde ywedded be
Vn to the Markys of Saluce anon
And as this Erl was prayd so dide he
For at day set he on his wey is gon
And forth he rod / ful fast a noon
Toward Saluce and lordes many oon
Toward Saluce / this Mayde for to gyde
In riche array this mayden for to gyde
Hir yonge brother ridyng hir bisyde
Arrayed was toward hir mariage
This fresshe mayde ful of gemmes clere
Hir brother which that seuen yeer was of age
Arrayed eek ful fressh in his manere
And thus in gret noblesse and with glad cheere
Toward Saluces shapyng hir iourney
Fro day to day they ryden in hir wey

This Markys yet his wif to tempte moore
To the outreste preue of hir corage
Fully to han experience and loore
If that she were as stedefast as bifore
He on a day in open audience
Ful boystously hath seyd hir this sentence
Certes Grisilde I hadde ynogh plesance
To han yow to my wyf for your goodnesse
As for youre trouthe and for your obeysance
Noght for your lynage ne for your richesse
But now knowe I in verray sothfastnesse
That in gret lordshipe if I wel auyse
Ther is gret seruitute in sondry wyse
I may nat do as euery Plowman may
My peple me constreyneth for to take
Another wyf and cryen day by day
And eek the pope rancour for to slake
Consenteth it that dar I vndertake
And trewely thus muche I wol yow seye
My newe wif is comynge by the weye
Be strong of herte and voyde anon hir place
And thilke dower that ye broghten me
Tak it agayn I graunte it of my grace
Retourneth to youre fadres hous quod he
No man may alwey han prosperitee
With euene herte I rede yow tendure
The strook of Fortune or of auenture
And she agayn answerde in pacience
My lord quod she I woot and wiste alway
How that bitwixen youre magnificence
And my pouerte no wight kan ne may
Maken comparisoun it is no nay
I ne heeld me neuere digne in no manere
To be your wyf no ; ne youre chambrere
And in this hous ther ye me lady made
The heighe god take I for my witnesse
And also wisly he my soule glade
I neuere heeld me lady ne maistresse
But humble seruant to youre worthynesse
And euere shal whil that my lyf may dure
Abouen euery worldly creature
That ye so longe of youre benygnytee
Han holden me in honour and nobleye
Where as I was noght worthy for to be
That thonke I god and yow to whom I preye
Foryelde it yow ther is namoore to seye
Vn to my fader gladly wol I wende
And with hym dwelle vn to my lyues ende
Ther I was fostred of a child ful smal
Til I be deed my lyf ther wol I lede
A wydewe clene in body herte and al
For sith I yaf to yow my maydenhede
And am youre trewe wyf it is no drede
God shilde swich a lordes wyf to take
Another man to housbond or to make
And of youre newe wyf god of his grace
So graunte yow wele and prosperitee
For I wol gladly yelden hir my place
In which that I was blisful wont to be
For sith it liketh yow my lord quod she
That whilom weren al myn hertes reste
That I shal goon I wol goon whan yow leste
But ther as ye me profre swich dowaire
As I first broghte it is wel in my mynde
It were my wrecched clothes no thyng faire
The whiche to me were hard now for to fynde
O goode god how gentil and how kynde
Ye semed by your speche and your visage
The day that maked was oure mariage
But sooth is seyd algate I fynde it trewe
For in effect it proued is on me
Loue is noght old as whan that it is newe
But certes lord for noon aduersitee
To dyen in this cas it shal nat be
That euere in word or werk I shal repente
That I yow yaf myn herte in hool entente
My lord ye woot that in my fadres place
Ye dide me strepe out of my poure wede
And richely me cladden of youre grace
To yow broghte I noght ellis out of drede
But feith and nakednesse and maydenhede
And here agayn my clothyng I restore
And eek my weddyng ryng for euere moore
The remenant of your Iewels redy be
Inwith your chambre dar I saufly sayn
Naked out of my fadres hous quod she
I cam and naked moot I turne agayn
Al youre plesance wol I folwen fayn
But yet I hope it be nat youre entente
That I smoklees out of your palays wente
Ye koude nat doon so dishoneste a thyng
That thilke wombe in which youre children leye
Sholde biforn the peple in my walkyng
Be seyn al bare wher fore I yow preye
Lat me nat lyk a worm go by the weye
Remembre yow myn owene lord so deere
I was youre wyf thogh I vnworthy weere
Wher fore in gerdou of my maydenhede
Which that I broghte and noght agayn I bere
As voucheth sauf to yeue me to my mede
But swich a smok as I was wont to were
That I ther with may wrye the wombe of here
That was youre wyf and here I take my leeue
Of yow myn owene lord lest I yow greeue
The smok quod he that thow hast on thy bak
Lat it be stille and bere it forth with thee
But wel vnnethes thilke word he spak
But wente his wey for routhe and for pitee
Biforn the folk hir seluen strepeth shee
And in hir smok with heued and feet al bare
Toward hir fader hous forth is she fare
The folk hir folwen wepynge in hir weye
And Fortune ay they cursen as they goon
But she fro wepyng kepte hir eyen dreye
Ne in this tyme word ne spak she noon
Hir fader that this tidynge herde anon
Curseth the day and tyme that nature
Shoop hym to been a lyues creature
For out of doute this olde poure man
Was euere in suspect of hir mariage
For euere he demed sith that it bigan
That whan the lord fulfild hadde his corage
Hym wolde thynke it were a disperage
To wedde oon of so pore alynage
To his estat so lowe for talighte
And voyden hir as soone as euere he myghte
Agayns his doghter hastiliche goth he
For he by noyse of folk knew hir comynge
And with hir olde cote as it myghte be
He couered hire ful sorwefully wepynge
But on hir body myghte he it nat brynge
For rude was the clooth and she moore of age
By dayes fele than at hir mariage
Thus with hir fader for a certein space
Dwelleth this flour of wifly pacience
That neyther by hir wordes ne hir face
Biforn the folk ne eek in hir absence
Ne shewed she that hir was doon offence
Ne of hir heighe estat no remembrance
Ne hadde she as by hir contenance
No wonder is for in hir grete estat
Hir goost was euere in pleyn humylitee
No tendre mouth noon herte delicat
No pompe no semblant of realtee
But ful of pacient benygnytee
Discreet and pridelees ay honurable
And to hir housbonde euere meke and stable
Men speke of Iob and moost for his hunblenesse

Namely of men but as in soothfastnesse
Thogh clerkes preyse wommen but alite
Ther kan no man in humblesse hym acquite

As wommen been but it be falle of newe
Fro Boloigne is this Erl of Pavyk come

That neuere was ther seyn with mannes eye
So noble array in al westlumbardye
The Markys which that shoop and knew al this
Er that this Erl was come sente his message
For thilke sely poure Grisildis
And she with humble herte and glad visage
Nat with no swollen thoght in hir corage
Cam at his heste and on hir knees hir sette

Grisilde quod he my wyl is outrely
This mayden that shal wedded been to me
Receyued be tomorwe as really
As it possible is in myn hous to be
And eek that euery wight in his degree
Haue his estat in sittyng and seruyse
And heigh plesance as I kan best deuyse
I haue no wommen suffisant certayn
The chambres for taraye in ordynance
After my lust and ther fore wolde I fayn
That thyn were al swich manere gouernance
Thow knowest eek of old al my plesance
Though thyn array be badde and yuel biseye
Do thow thy deuoir at the leeste weye
Nat oonly lord that I am glad quod she
To doon youre lust but I desire also
Yow for to serue and plese in my degree
With outen feyntyng and shal euere mo
Ne neuere for no wele ne no wo
Ne shal the goost with Inne myn herte stente
To loue yow best with al my trewe entente
And with that word she gan the hous to dighte
And tables for to sette and beddes make
And peyned hir to doon al that she myghte
Preyynge the chambreres for goddes sake
To hasten hem and faste swepe and shake
And she the mooste seruysable of alle
Hath euery chambre arrayed and his halle
Abouten vndren gan this Erl alighte
That with hym broghte thise noble children tweye
For which the peple ran to seen the sighte
Of hire array so richely biseye
And thanne at erst amonges hem they seye
That Walter was no fool thogh that hym leste
To chaunge his wyf for it was for his beste
For she is fairer as they demen alle
Than is Grisilde and moore tendre of age
And fairer fruyt bitwene hem sholde falle
And moore plesant for hir heigh lynage
Hir brother eek so fair was of visage
That hem to seen the peple hath caught plesance
Commendynge now the Markys gouernance
O stormy peple vnsad and euere vntrewe
Ay vndiscreet and chaungynge as a vane
Delitynge euere in rumbel that is newe
Here may ye se the peple how newe
For lyk the moone ay wexe ye and wane
Ay ful of clappyng deere ynow a Iane
And changeable be right as the mane
Youre doom is fals youre constance yuele preueth
A ful greet fool is he that on yow leueth
Thus seyden sadde folk in that Citee
Whan that the peple gazed vp and doun
For they were glad right for the noueltee
To han a newe lady of hir town
Namoore of this make I now mencioun
But to Grisilde agayn wol I me dresse
And telle hir constance and hir bisynesse
Ful bisy was Grisilde in euery thyng
That to the feste was apertinent
Right noght was she abayst of hir clothyng
Thogh it were rude and somdel eek to rent
But with glad cheere to the yate is she went
With oother folk to greete the Markysesse
And after that dooth forth hir bisynesse
With so glad cheere his gestes she receyueth
And so konnyngly euerich in his degree
That no defaute no man aparceyueth
But ay they wondren what she myghte be
That in so poure array was for to se
And koude swich honour and reuerence
And worthily they preysen hir prudence
In al this mene while she ne stente
This mayde and eek hir brother to commende
With al hir herte in ful benygne entente
So wel that no man koude hir prys amende
But at the laste whan that thise lordes wende
To sitten doun to mete he gan to calle
Grisilde as she was bisy in his halle
Grisilde quod he as it were in his pley
How liketh thee my wyf and hir beautee
Right wel quod she my lord for in good fey
A fairer saw I neuere noon than she
I prey to god yeue hire prosperritee
And so hope I that he wol to yow sende
Plesance ynogh vn to youre lyues ende
O thyng biseke I yow and warne also
That ye ne prike with no tormentynge
This tendre mayden as ye han do mo
For she is fostred in hir norissynge
Moore tendrely and to my supposynge
She koude nat aduersitee endure
As koude a poure fostred creature
And whan this Walter saw hir pacience
Hir glad cheere and no malice at al

And she ay sad and constant as a wal
Continuynge euere hir Innocence ouer al vbique
With pacience Grisild he quiteth
This sturdy Markys gan his herte dresse
To rewen vp on hir wifly stedfastnesse
This is ynogh Grisilde myn quod he
Be now namoore agast ne yuele apayed
I haue thy feith and thy benygnytee
Mankynde which that he wroght
As wel as euere womman was assayed
In greet estat and poureliche arrayed
Now knowe I deere wyf thy stedfastnesse
And hire in armes took and gan hir kesse
And she for wonder took of it no keep
She herde nat what thyng he to hir seyde
She ferde as she hadde stirt out of a sleep
Sche ferd as sche had stert oute of hir slepe
Til she out of hir mazednesse abreyde
Grisilde quod he by god that for vs deyde
Thow art my wyf noon oother I haue
Ne neuere hadde as god my soule saue
This is thy doghter which thow hast supposed
To be my wyf that oother feithfully
Shal be myn heir as I haue ay supposed
Thow bare hym in thy body trewely
At Boloigne haue I kept hem priuely
Tak hem agayn for now maistow nat seye

And folk that oother weys han seyd of me
I warne hem wel that I haue doon this dede
For no malice ne for no crueltee
But for tassaye in thee thy wommanhede
And nat to sleen my children god forbede
But for to kepe hem pryuely and stille
Til I thy purpos knewe and al thy wille
Whan she this herde aswowne doun she falleth
For pitous ioye and after hir swownynge
She bothe hir yonge children vn to hir calleth
And in hir armes pitously wepynge
Embraceth hem and tendrely kissynge
Ful lyk a moder with hir salte terys
She batheth bothe hir visage and hir herys
O which a pitous thyng it was to se
O such a pitous thing it was to see
Hir swownyng and hir humble voys to heere
Grant mercy lord god thanke it yow quod she
That ye han saued me my children deere
Now rekke I neuere to been ded right heere
Sith I stonde in your loue and in youre grace
No fors of deeth ne whan my spirit pace
O tendre o deere o yonge children myne
Youre woful moder wende stedefastly
That cruel houndes or som foul vermyne
Hadde eten yow but god of his mercy
And youre benygne fader tendrely
Hath doon yow kept and in that same stounde
Al sodeynly she swapte adoun to grounde
And in hir swogh so sadly holdeth she
Hir children two whan she gan hem tembrace
That with greet sleghte and greet difficultee
The children from hir arm they gonne arace
O many a teer o many a pitous face
Doun ran of hem that stoden hir bisyde
Vnnethe aboute hir myghte they abyde
Walter hir gladeth and hir sorwe slaketh
She riseth vp abaysed from hir traunce

Til she hath caught agayn hir contenaunce
Walter hir dooth so feithfully plesaunce

Bitwix hem two now they ben met yfeere
Thise ladies whan that they hir tyme say

And strepen hir out of hir rude aray

With a coroune of many a riche stoon
Vp on hir hed they in to halle hir broghte
And ther she was honured as hir oghte
Thus hath this pitous day a blisful ende

This day in murthe and reuel to dispende
Til on the welkne shoon the sterres lyght
For moore solempne in euery mannes syght
This feste was and gretter of costage

Ful many a yeer in heigh prosperitee
Lyuen thise two in concord and in reste
And richely his doghter maried he
Vn to a lord oon of the worthyeste

His wyues fader and his court he kepeth
Til that the soule out of his body crepeth
His sone succedeth in his heritage
In reste and pees after his fader day
And fortunat was eek his mariage
Al putte he nat his wyf in gret assay
This world is nat so strong it is no nay
As it hath been in olde tymes yore
And herkneth what this Auctour seith therfore
This storie is seyd nat for that wyues sholde

For sith a womman was so pacient

Nat for to knowe oure wyl for certes he

And for oure beste is al his gouernance
Lat vs thanne lyue in vertuous suffrance
But o word lordynges herkneth er I go
It were ful hard to fynde now a dayes

Whos lyf and al hir secte god mayntene

And namely vpon the wyffys syde
This olde knyght Ianuar the which I tolde
Consyderyd hath wyth in his days olde
The lusty lyf the vertuous quyete
That ys in maryage hony swete
And for his frendys on a day he sent
To tel them the effecte of his entent
Wᵗith sadde cher his tal he hath them tolde
He sayd frendys I am hore ⁊and not olde
And almoste god wot at pyttys brynke
Vpon my soule . som what most I thinke
I haue my body folyly dispendyde
Blessyd be god þat I schal be a mendyd
And þat a non in al the hast I can
For I wol be certeyn a weddyd man
Vn to som mayd Fair ⁊and tendʳ of age
I pray you schappyth For my maryage
Al sodeynlly For I wol not a bydde
And I schal assay to spy y on my syde
To whom I may be weddyd hastely
But for as mych as ye arn moo then I
Ye schal rathur such a thing aspyen
Then I ⁊and wher me best wer to alyen
But on thing I warne you my Frendys der
I wol non olde wyff in no maner
Sche schal not passe xvj yer certayn
Olde Fysch ⁊and yong Flessh wold I haue fayn
Bettʳ qd he ys a pyke then a pykrel
And bettʳ þen olde beffe ys the tendur veyle
I wol no woman . xxxᵗⁱ yer of age
It ys but benstrawe and gret Forage
And eke thes olde wydowes god yt wot
They know so mych crafte on wades bote
So mych brokyn harme when them lyste
That wyth them schuld I neủer lyve in reste
For Sondry places makyn subtyl clerkys
A woman of many stoles half a clerke ys
But certaynly a yonge thing men may gye
Ryght as men may warme wax wᵗith handys plye
Wher for I sey you playnly in a clause
I wol noo olde wyff haue ryght for þis caus
For yiff so wer I had such myschaunce
That I in hur coude haue no Pleysaunce
Then schuld I lede my lyff in advoutery
And streyght go to the deuyl when I dy
Ne children schuld I non vppon her getyn
Yt had me leuer hovndys had me eten
Then that myn herytage schuld fal
In strange hange . and this I tel you al
I dout not I wot the cause wy
Men schuld wedde and furthermore wot I
Ther spekyth many a man of maryage
That wot no more of hit then doth my page
For which causys man schulld take a wyff
Yff he ne may not lywe chaste his lyff
Take hym a wyff wᵗith gret deuocoun
Be cause of lefful ꝓprocreacioun
Off childeryn to the honour of god a bove
And not only for ꝑparamour and love
And for they schulde lechery eschue
And yelde ther dettys which that ys dewe
And for that ech of them schulde helpyn othur
In myscheff as Suster schal the Brother
And lyve in chastyte Ful holily
But syrys by your leve that am not I
For god be thankyd I darre make a vaunt
I Fel my lymmys starke and sufficiaunt
To do al that a man be longyth to
I wot my self / beste what I may do
Though I be hore I fare as doth a tre
That blomyth er that frute I waxin be
A blossomede tre ys neythur dry ne dede
I Felle me noo where hore but on my hed
Myn harte and all my lymmys byn so grene
As laurer thrugh the yere is for to sene
And sithen that ye haue harde all myn entent
I pray you to do my wil ye wote assent
Dyủers men diủersly hym tolde
Of mariages many ensaumples olde
Som blamed it . som preised it certayne
But at the last shortly for to seyne
As al day fallith altrecaciou
Betwixt frendis in disputaciou
There fele a strif betwixt his bretheren . two
Of which that on was clepid placebo
Iustynus sothely called was that other
Placebo seide . O . Ianuarie Brother
Ful litle nede had ye my lorde so dere
Counseile to aske of eny that is here
But that ye be so full of Sapience
That you ne likith for youre high prudence
To weive fro the worde of Salamon
This worde seide he vnto vs eủerychon
Werke al thyng by counsaille thus seide he
And then shalt thou not repent the
But though that Salamon spake suche aworde
Myn owne dere Brother and myn lorde
So wisly god my soule bryng to rest
I holde youre owne Counseill is the best
For brother myn of me take this motif
I haue ben nowe a Courteman al my lif
And god it wote though y vnworthy be
I haue stonden in full grete degre
Above lordes . and folke of high estate
Yit had y neủere with non of them debate
I neủere them contraried truely
I wote wel that my lorde can more than y
What that he seith y holde it ferme and stable
I sey the same or elles thynge semblable
A ful grete fole is eny Counseilloure
That servith eny lorde of high honoure
That psume or elles thynkyn it
That his counseil shulde passe his lordis wit
Nay lordes be no foles by my fay
Ye haue youre self seide here to day
So high scentence . so holily and so wel
That y consent and conferme eủery del
Youre wordes all and youre oppynyou
Bigod ther is no man in al this town
Ne in Itaille coude bet haue seide
Criste holde hym of his counseill ful wel apaide
And truely it is an high corage
Of eny man that stoupyn is in age
To take ayonge wif by my fader kyn
Youre hert hongith on a Ioly pyn
Doth nowe in this matere right as you lest
For fynally y holde it for the best
¶ Iustinus that by still sate and herde
Right in this wise he to placebo aunswerd
Nowe brother myn be pacient y prey
Syn ye haue seide harkyn what y sey
Senec amonge his other wordes wise
Seith that a man ought hym right welle a vise
To hom he yevith his londe or his Catel
And sen y ought a vise me right wel
To whom y yave my good a wey fro me
Wel moche more me ought avisen me parde
To whom y yeve my body for al wey
I warn you wel it is no childes pley
To take a wif withoute a visement
Men moste enquere this is myn Assent
Whether she be wif sobre or dronkelewe
Or proude or elles otherwise a shrewe
A Chider or a . wastoure of good
Or Riche or poure . or elles mannysshe wode
All be it so that no man fynden shal
None in this worled that trottith hole in al
No man no beste suche as men coude devise
But natheles it ought y nowe suffise
With eny wif . yif so were that she hadde
Moo good thewis then there wifis badde
And al this askith leiser for to enquere
For god it wote I haue wepte many a tere
Ful pryvely syn y had a wif
Preise who so wil a wedded mans lif
Certeyne y fynde in hit but cost and care
And observaunces of all blissys bare
And yit god wote myn nyghtbours aboute
And namly of wymmen many a route
Seyn that y haue the moste stedfast wif
And eke the mekist on that berith lif
But y wote best where wryngith me my sho
Ye mowe for me right as thou likest do
A viseth you ye ben aman of age
Hou that ye entren in to mariage
And namely with a yonge wif and a feire
By hym that made Water Erthe and Eire
The yongest man that is in al this route
Ys besie y nough to brynge it a boute
To haue his wif alone trustith me
Ye shul not please hure fully yeres thre
This is seyne to do hure full pleasaunce
A wif askith ful many an observaunce
I pray you that ye be not evil apaide
¶ Wel qd this Ianuar and hast thou saide
Strawe for thy Senec and for thy proverbis
I counte not a panyere ful of herbis
Of scole termes wiser men then thowe
¶ As thou hast harde . assentid right nowe
To my purpos Placebo what seie ye
I sey he is a cursed man qd he
That lettith a matrimonie sikirly
And with that worde they sodenly
And ben assentid fully that he sholde
Be weddid when hym lust ⁊and where he wolde
Hure fantesie and curious besynesse
Fro day to day gan in the soule impresse
Of Ianuarie a boute his mariage
Many a feire shappe and many a faire visage
There passith thrugh his harte nyght by nyght
As who so toke a Merroure polisshed bright
And set in Commune Market place
Then shull he se ful many a diủers face
By his Merroure and in this same wyse
Gan Ianuarie with in his thought devise
Of Maidenes . which that dweld hym beside
He wist not where that he myght a bide
For yif that on haue beaute in hure face
And other stonden so in the people grace
For hure sadnesse and hure benygnite
That of the people the grettist voice hath she
And som were Riche and had a bad name
But natheles bitwixt ernest and game
He at the last empoyntith hym on one
And lette al other from his harte gone
And chesith hure of his owne auctorite
For love is blynde al day and may not se
¶ And when he was in his bed brought
He purtreide in his harte and in his thought
Hure fresshe beaute and hure age tendre
Hure myddil smal and hure armes sclendre
Hure wise . goủernaunce hure Ientilnesse
Hure wommanly beryng and hure sadness
And when that he was on hure condiscended
Hym thought his s choys myght not be amended
For when that he hym self concluded hadde
Hym thought eche other mannes wit so badde
That impossible it were to replie
Ageyns his choice this was his fantasie
His frendes sente he to at his instance
And preide them to do hym that plesaunce
That hastely they wolde to hym com
He wolde acquyte there laboure al and som
Nedith nomore for hym to go nor ride
He was a poynted there he wolde a bide
Placebo com and eke his frendes sone
And altherfirst he bade them al aboue
That none of them . none argumentis make
Ageyne the purpos which that he hath take
Which purpos was pleasyng to god seide he
And verrey grounde of his prosꝑperite
He seide there was a Maide in the Toun
Which that of hure beaute had grete renoun
Al were it so she were of smal degre
Suffisith hym hure yougth and hure beaute
Which maide he seide he wolde haue to his wif
To lede in ease and holynes his lif
And thankid god that he mygh haue hure al
That no wight his blis partyn shal
And preide hym to laboure in this nede
And shape that he faile not to spede
For then he seide his Sprite was in ease
Then is qd he nothyng that may me displease
Save on thyng prickith my conscience
The which y wil reherce in youre psence
I haue hard sey qd he ful yore ago
There may no man haue parfit blisses two
This is to sey in Erthe and eke in heven
For though hepe hym fro alie synnes seven
And eke from eủery Braunche of thilke tree
¶ Yit is ther so ꝑperfite felicite
And so grete ease and lust in mariage
That eủere y am agast now in myn age
That y shal lede nowe so merye a lif
So delicate withoute wo or strif
That y shal haue myn heven in Erthe here
For sith that verrey heven is bought so dere
With tribulacions and grete penaunce
Hou shulde y than . that live in suche plesaunce
As all weddid men don with hure wifis
Com to the blisse there Criste et̉erne on live is
This is my drede and ye my brether twey
Assoileth me this questiou y prey
Iustynus which that hatid his folie
Aunswerd anon right in his Iaperie
And for he wolde his longe tale a breigge
He wolde non auctorite alleigge
But seide Sir so ther be non obstacle
Other this god of his high myracle
And of his mercie may so for you werche
That ere ye haue youre rightis att holy Cherche
Ye may repent of weddid mans lif
In which ye seyne . there is no wo nor strif
And elles god forbede but he sent
A weddid man grace to repent
Wel ought rather then a sengle man
And therfore Sir the best rede y can
Dispeire you not but haue in youre memorie
Paraventure she may be youre Purgatorie
She may by goddis mene and goddis whippe
Than she shal youre soule vp to heven skippe
Swifter than an arowe doith oute of a Bowe
I hope to god hereaftur shal ye knowe
That there nys non so grete felicite
In Mariage . ne neủere more shal be
That you shal lette of youre savaciou
So that ye vse it as skil is and reasou
The lustis of youre wif attemprely
Take hym not ofte but mesurably
And that ye kepe you eke from other synne
My tale is don for my witte is thynne
Beth not agast hereof my brother dere
But leten vs wade oute of this matere
The wif of Bathe yaf ye haue vnderstonde
Of Mariage which we haue on honde
Declared hath ful wele in litle space
Fareth nowe wel god haue you in his grace
¶ And with that worde . Iustinus and his Brothere
Have tane there leve and eche of them othere
For when they saugh that it mot nedes be
They wroughten so by sleight and wise trete
That she this Maide that Mayus hight
As hastely as eủere that she mygh
Shal wedded be vnto this Ianuarie
I trowe it were to longe yeve to tarie
Yif y you tolde of eủery scripte and bonde
With which she was feffed in his londe
Or forto rekyn of hure riche aray
But fynally y comyn is that day
That to the Churche bothe be they went
For to resceive the holy sacrament
Furth comth the Prest with stole aboute his necke
And bade hure be like Sarra and Rebecke
In wisdom and in trouth of Mariage
And seide his orisons as is vsage
And crouchid hym and bade god shulde hym blesse
And made al siker y nough with holynesse
¶ Thus they ben wedded with solempnyte
And at the feste sithen he and she
With other worthy folke vppon the deis
And full of Ioy and blis is in the Paleis
And ful of Instumentes . and of vitaile
The moste deynteis of all Itaille
Beforn them were there Instrumentis of suche soun
That Orpheus ne Thebes . Orpheoun
Ne nerie maden such a melodie
Atte eủery Cours come lowde mynstralsie
That neủere Trumped Iacob for to here
Ne he Theodomas half so clere
At Thebes whan the Cite was in doute
Bachus the wyne hym syngith al a boute
And venus laughith vppon eủery wight
For Ianuarie was bicom hure knight
And wolde bothe assaien his Corage
In liberte and eke in Mariage
And with hure firebronde in hure honde aboute
Daunceth bifore the Bride and all the route
And certaynly y dar well seyne this
That Imyneus which god of weddyng ys
Saugh neủere in his lif so mery a weddid man
Holde thou thy pees thou Poet Marcian
That writist vs that ilke weddyng murie
Of hure Phiologie and hym Mercurie
And of the songes that the Musis songe
To smale is bothe thy penne and eke thy tonge
For to discriven of his Mariage
When tender youth hath wedded stoupyng age
There is suche myrth that it may not be wreten
Assaieth yt youre self there may ye weten
Yif that y lie or non in this matere
Mayus that sittith with so benygne achere
Hure to be holde it semed feirye
Quene Ester loked neủere with suche an ye
On assure so meke aloke as she
I may you not devise al hure beaute
But thus moche of hure beaute tel y may
That she was like the bright morowe of may
Fulfilled of all beaute and plesaunce
This Ianuarie is ravisshed in a Traunce
At eủery tyme he lokith on hure face
But in his hart he gan hure to manace
That he that nyght in armys wolde hure streyne
Harder than eủere Parise did Eleyne
But natheles . yit had he grete pite
That thilke nyght offende hure most he
And thought alas . o . tendre creature
Nowe wolde god ye myght wel endure
All my corage . it is so sharpe and kene
I am a gast she may it not sustene
But god for bede that y did al my myght
Nowe wolde god it were woxen nyght
And that the nyght wolde wlaste eủere moo
I wolde that al this peple were agoo
And fynaly he doth all his laboure
As he best myght savyng his honoure
To haste them fro the mete in subtile wise
The tyme come that reason was to rise
And aftur that men daunce and drynke fast
And Spices al a boute they cast
And ful of Ioy and blis is eủery man
¶ All but a Squyere hight Damyan
Which carf bifore the knyght ful many a day
He was so ravisshed on this lady gay
That for verrey peyne he was nygh wood
Almost he sweld and swouned as he stood
So sore hath venus hurte hym with hure bronde
As that she bare it daunsyng in hure honde
That to his bed he went hym hastely
No more of hym at this tyme speke y
But there y lette hym wepe y nough and compleyne
Til fresshe May wil rewyn on his peyne
O . perilous fire . that in the Bedstrawe bredith left
O . famuliere . foo . that his servise biddith
O . Servaunt traitoure fals homly hue
Like to the Adder in bosom slie vntrue
God shelde vs al from youre acquayntaunce
O . Ianuarie droken in plesaunce
In mariage se howe Damyan
Thyn owne Squyer and thyn born man
Entendith for to don the vilanye
God graunte the thyn homly foo for to espye
For in this worlde nys wors pestilence
Than homly foo . al day in thy presence
Parformed hath the sonne his Arke dyvrne
No lenger may the body of hym soiorne
Of the orisoun as in that latitude
Right with his mantel that is derke and rude
Gan oủere sprede the Emyspirie a boute
For which departid is this lusty route
For Ianuarie with thanke on eủery side
Hom to there houses lustily they ride
Where as they don there thynge as then lest
And when they sawe there tyme go to rest
Sone aftur that this lusty Ianuarie
Wolle go to bed he wol no lenger tarie
He drynkith ypocras Clarrey and vernage
Of spices hote to encresen his corage
And many a letuarie had he ful fyne
Suche as the cursed Monke Daun Constantyne
Hath writen in his boke de Cornewe
To ete hym alle he was no thyng eschewe
And to his preve frendes thus seide he
For goddis love as sone as it may be
Lette voiden al this hous in curteise wise
And they haue done right as he wol devise
Men drynken and the travers drawen anon
The brid was brought in bed as stil as ston
And when the bed was with the prest blessed
Oute of the Chambre hath eủery wight hym dressed
And Ianuarie hath fast in Armys take
His fresshe May his Paradise his make
He lulleth hure he kissith hure ful ofte
With thikke bristles of his berde vnsofte
Like to the skyn of houndis fisshe sharpe as abrere
For he was shave al newe in his manere
He rubbeth hure a boute hure tendre face
And seide thus alas y mot trespace
To you my spouse and you gretly offende
Or tyme com that y wolde doun descende
But natheles considerith thus qd he
There nys no werke man what so eủere he be
That may bothe werke wel and hastily
This wil be don at leiser parfitly
Hit is no force hou longe that we pley
In true wedlok coupeled be we twey
And blessed by the yoke that we ben Inne
Fo in actes we mowe do no synne
Aman may do no synne with his wif
Ne hurte hym self with his owne knif
For we haue leve for to pleie as by the lawe
Thus laboureth he til that the day gan dawe
And then he takith a soppe of fyne Clarre
And vpright in his bed then sittith he
And aftur that he songe ful loude and clere
And kyst his wif and made wantou chere
He was al Coltisshe ful of Ragerie
And ful of gargon as a flekked pie
The slak skyn a boute his necke shakith
While that he songe . so chauntith he and crakith
And god wote what that May thought in hure harte
When she sawe hym vprisyng in sharte
In his nyght Cappe and with his necke lene
She preisith not his pleyng worth a bene
Then seide he thus my rest wol y take
Nowe day is com y may no lenger wake
And doun he leide his hede and slepte til pryme
And afturward when that he sawe his tyme
Vprisith Ianuarie . but the fresshe May
Hilde hure Chambre vnto the . iiij . th day
As vsage is of wifis for the best
For eủery laboure somtyme motte haue rest
Or elles longe may he not endure
This is to seyne none lyvis creature
Be it fisshe or Brid best or man
Nowe wol y speke. of woful Damyan
That languysshith for love as ye shal here
There for y speke to hym in this manere
¶ I seide . o . selye Damyan alas right
Aunswere to my demaunde as in this cas
Hou shalte thou to thy lady fresshe May
Tel thy woo . she wol alwey sey nay
Eke yif thou speke she wol thy wo bewrey
God be thyn helpe y can no bettʳ sey
This seke Damyan in venus fire
So brennyth that he dieth for desire
For which he puttith his lif in a venture
No lenger myght he in this wise endure
But prively a Pennar gan he borowe
And in a lettre wrote he all his sorowe
In mane of a compleynte or a lay
Vn to this feire fresshe May
And in a Purs of silke . hyng on his shert
He hath put it and layde it at his hert
The mone that atte noon was that ilke day
That Ianuarie hath weddid the fresshe May
In two of Taure was in to Cancr gliden
So longe hath Mayus in hure Chambre biden
As custom is vnto thise nobles alle
A bride shall not ete yn the halle
Til days . iiij . or . iij . daies at the leste
Passed ben then let hure go to feste
The . iiij . th day complete from non to none
When that the high masse was done
In hal sate this Ianuarie and May
As freshe as is the bright someres day
And so befele hou that this good man
Remembrid hym vppon Damyan
And seide seynt Mary hou may it be
That Damyan entendith not to me
Is he ay seke or how may it betide
His Squyers which that stoden by his side
Excused hym by cause of his sikenesse
Which lettid hym to don his bisynesse
None other cause myght make hym tarie
That me forthynkith qd this Ianuarie
He is a Ientil Squyere by my truthe
Yif that he died it were harme and ruthe
He is as wise discrete . and as secre
As eny man y knowe of his degre
And therto manly and eke servisable
And for to be aman trusty and able
And aftur mete as sone as eủere y may
I will my self visite hym and eke may
To don all the comforte that y can
And for that worde hym blessid eủery man
That of his bountie and his Ientilnesse
He wolde so comfort in seknesse
His Squyer for his Ientil dede
Dame qd this Ianuarie take good hede
At aftur mete ye with youre wymmen alle
When ye haue ben in Chambre oute of this halle
That alle ye gone to se this Damyan
Doith hym disporte he is a Ientilman
And telleth hym that y wil hym visite
Haue y nothyng do but rest me a lite
And spede you fast for y wol a bide
Til that ye slepe first by my side
And with that worde he gan to hym calle
A Squyer that was Marchall of the halle
And tolde hym certayne thynges that he wolde
This fresshe May hath streight hure wey holde
With al hure wymmen vnto Damyan
Doun by his beddis side sette she hure than
Comfortyng hym as goodly as she may
This Damyan when he his tyme say
In secrete wise his purs and eke his bille
In which that he writen had his wille
Hath putte in to hure honde withoute more .
Save that he sighith wondre sore
And softly to hure right thus seide he
Mercie and that ye not bewreie me
For y am dede yif that thynges be kid
This purs she within hure bosom hid
And went hure wey ye gete no more of me
But vnto Ianuarie ageyne comyn is she
That on his bed side sate ful softe
And takith hure and kissith hure ful ofte
And leide hym doun to slepe and that a non
She feyned hure as though she moste gon
There as ye wote that eủery wight moste nede
And when she of this bille had takyn hede
She rent it al to peces at the last
And in the prive softly it cast
Who stodieth nowe but faire fresshe May
A doun by olde Ianuarie she lay
That slepte til the Cough hath hym waked
Anon he preide hure to stripen hure al naked
He wolde of hure he seide haue som pleasaunce
And seide hure cloth did hym combraunce
And she obeith hym be the lef or loth
But lest that precious folke be with me wroth
Howe that he wrought y dar not you tel
Or whethir hure thought it Paradise or hel
But here y leh tehym werkyn in this wise
Til evensong rong . and that they moste rise
Were it by desteny or by a venture
Were it by influence . or nature
Or Constellaciou that in suche estate
The heven stode in that tyme fortunate
Was for to put a Bil of venus werkis
For all thyng hath tyme as seyne thise Clerkis
To eủery womman for to gete hure love
I cannot sey but grete god a bove
That knowith that none acte is causeles
He deme of al for y wol holde my pes
But soth is this hou that the fresshe May
Hath take suche impressiou that day
Of pite of this seke Damyan
That fro hure harte she ne drive can
The remembraunce for to don hym ease
Certeyne thought she whom that thise thynges displease
Y recke not for hure . y hym assuere
To love hym best of eny creature
Though he no more had then his shert
Lo pite renneth sone in Ientil hert
Here may ye se hou excellent Fraunchise
In womman is whan they them narowe avise
Som tyraunt is as there ben many on
That hath an harte as hard as eny ston
Which wolde haue let hym starve in that place
Wel rather then haue grauntid hym hure grace
And hym reioisen in hure cruel pride
And recke not to ben an homicide
This Ientil May fulfilled of pite
Right of hure honde a lettre makith she
In which she grauntid hym hure verrey grace
There lackith nought but only . day and space
There as she myght vnto his lust suffise
For it shalbe right as he wol devise
And when she saugh hure tyme vppon a day
To visite this Damyan goith this May
And softly this lettre doun she threst
Vnder his pelowe rede ht yif hym lest
She toke hym be the hande . and hard hym twyst
So secrettly that no man it wist
And bade hym be al hole and forth she went
To Ianuarie whan that he for hure sent
Vp risith Damyan the next morowe
Al passed is his sekenes and his sorowe
He kembith hym proyneth and pikith
He doith al that his lady lust and likith
And eke to Ianuarie he goith as lowe
As eủere did a dogge for the bowe
He is so plesaunt to eủery man
For crafte is al . who so that do it can
That eủery wight his faine to speke hym good
And fully in his ladyes grace he stood
Thus latte y Damyan a boute his nede
And in my tale furth wol y procede
Som Clerkis holden that felicite
Stont in delite and therfore certeyne he
This noble Ianuarie with al his myght
In honest wise as longeth to a knyght
Shope hym to lyve ful deliciously
His house is arraied as honestly
To his degre was made as a skyng
Amonges other of his honest thyng
He made agardyn walled al with stone
A fairere gardyn wote y no where none
For oute of doute y verreily suppose
That he that wrote the Romaunce of the Rose
He coude of hit the beaute wel devise
Ne Priapus myght not suffise
Though he be god of Gardens for to telle
The beaute of the Gardyn and the welle
That stode vnder a laurer alwey grene
Full ofte tyme Pluto and his Quene
Proserpina and al hure fairie
Disporten them and makyn melodie
A boute that welle and daunsyng as men tolde
This noble knyght Ianuarie the olde
Suche deynte hath in hit to walke and pley
That he wolde suffre no wight to bere the key
But he hym self for of the smal wiket
He bare alway of silvir a Cliket
With which when that hym list . he it vnshet
And whan he wolde pay his wifis det
In somer season thider wolde he go
And May his wif and no wight but they two
And thynges which that were not done a bedde
He in the gardeyn . ꝑperformed them and spedde
As in this wise ful many a mery day
Levith this Ianuarie and this fresshe May
But worldly ioy may not alway endure
To Ianuarie ne to . no creature
O . sodayn hap . o . thou fortune vnstable
Like to the Scorpyon so disceyvable
That flaterest with thyn hede when that thou wilte styng
Thy taile is deth thrugh thyn enveinymiyng
O . brotel ioy of swete venym queynte
O . monstre that so sotelly canst peynte
Thy yiftis vnder hue . of stedfastnesse
That thou desceivest bothe more and lesse
Why has thou Ianuarie thus desceivid
That haddist hym for thy ful frende receivid
And nowe thou hast birafte hym bothe his yeen
For sorowe of which he desirith to dyen
Alas this noble Ianuarie the fre
In myddis of his lust and his prosꝑperite
Is woxen blynde . and that so sodenly
He wepith and he wailith also pitouslys
And there with al the fire of Ielosy
Lest that his wif shulde falle in som foly
So brent his hart that he wolde fayne
That som man bothe hure and hym had slayne
For neither aftur his deth ne his lif
Ne wolde he that she were no love ne wif
But eủere live as a widowe in clothis blake
And morne as the Turtil that lost hath hure make
But at the last aftur a moneth or twey
His sorowe gan to swage sothe to sey
For whan he wist it myght none other be
He paciently toke his adủersite
Save oute of doute he may not forgon
That he nas Ielous eủermore in on
Which Ielousie it was outragious
That neither in hal ne in none other hous
Ne in none other place neủere the mo
He nolde suffre hure for to ride ne go
But yif that he had honde on hure alway
For which ful ofte wepith fresshe may
That lovith Damyan so benygnely
That she most other dien sodenly
Or ellis she mot haue hym as hure lest
She waitith whan hure harte wolde brest
Vppon that other side Damyan
Bicom is the sorowfullist man
That eủere was . for neither nyght ner day
Ne myght he speke a worde to fresshe May
As to this pʳpos of no suche matere
But yif that Ianuarie most it here
That had an honde vppon hure eủermo
But natheles by writyng to and fro
And prive signes wist he what she ment
And she knewe eke the syne of his entent
¶ O . Ianuarie what myght it a vaile
Though thou myght seen as ferre as shippis saile
For as gode is blynde desceivid be
As ben desceivid . whan a man may se
Lo Argus . which had an . C . yeen
For al that eủere he coude poure or pryen
Yit was he blynde as god wote so ben mo
That wenyn wisly that it be not so
Passe oủere is an ease y seie nomore
This fresshe May that y speke of bifore
In warme wax . hath emprynted the Cliket
That Ianuarie bare of the smale wiket
By which to hir gardyn ofte he went
And damyan that knewe al hure entent
The Cliket countrefetid prively
There is no more to sey but hastely
Som wondre by thes Cliket shall betide
Which ye shulle here yif ye woll a bide
O . noble Ouide full soth seist thou god wote .
What sleight is it though it be longe and hote
That love nyll fynde it oute in som manere
By Priamus and Tesbe may ye lere
Though they were kepte full longe and streite oủere al
There no wight coude haue founde on suche a sleight
They ben accordid rounyn thrugh a wal
But nowe to oure purpos er that days eight
Were passed or that the noneth of Iule bifel
That Ianuarie hath caught so grete a wil
Thrugh eggyng of his wif hym for to pley
In his gardeyn and no wight but they twey
That in a morowe vnto this May seith he
Rise vp my wif my love my lady fre
The turtils voice is harde my wif so swete
The wynter is gon with his reynes wete
Comforth nowe with thyn yeen columbyne
With thy brestis whitter then y can devyne
The gardeyn is enclosed al a boute
Comforth my swete spouse for oute of doute
Thou has me woundid in myn hert . o . wif
No spot ne knowe y in the in al my lif
Comthfurth and lette vs taken oure disporte
I chese you for May wyf and my comforte
Suche olde lewde wordis vsed he
On Damyan a syne than made sche
That he shulde go before with the Cliket
This Damyan then hath opened the wiket
And in he stert and that in suche manere
That no wight myght hym se neither neither here
And still he sate vnder a busshe anon
This Ianuarie as blynde as eny ston
With Mayus in his honde and no wight mo
Into his fresshe gardeyne is y go
And clappid to the wicket sodenly
Nowe wif qd he here is but ye and y
Ye are the creature that y best love
For bi that lorde that sittith in heven above
Leủere y had to dien on a knyf
Then you offend true dere wyf
For goddis sake thynke hou y the chese
Not for no covetise doutlese
But only for the love y had to the
And though that y be olde and may not se
Bith to me true and y will tel you why
Iijᵉ thynges certis shul ye wyn therby
Furst love of Crist and to youre self honoure
And al myn heritage bothe Toun and Toure
Y yeve it you makith Charters as you lest
This shalbe don to morowe or the son rest
So wisly god my soule brynge to blisse
I pray you first in covenaunt ye me kysse
And though y be Ielous wite me nought
Ye ben so depe empreynted in my thought
That when y considre youre beaute
And therewith al the vnlickly age of me
I may not certis though y shulde die
For bere to ben oute of youre companye
For verrey love this is withoutyn doute
Nowe kysse me wif and lette vs rome aboute
This fresshe May . when she thise wordes herde
Benygnely to Ianuarie she aunswerde
But first and forward she be gan to wepe
I haue qd she god wote a soule to kepe
Also wel as ye . and also myn honoure
And of my wifhode thilke tendre floure
Which that y haue assured in youre honde
Whan that the prest to you my body bonde
Wher for I woll answer in þˢ man
By the leve of you that be my lorde so dere
I pray to god that neủere dawe the day
That y ne sterve as foule as womman may
Yif eủere y do vnto my kyn that shame
Or elles yif that y empeire so my name
That y be fals . and yif y do that lacke
Do stripe me and put me in a sacke
And in the nexte River do me drenche
I am a Ietilwomman and no wenche
Why speke ye thus . but men ben eủere vntrewe
And wommen haue of you ay repreve newe
And with that worde she sawe where Damyan
Sate in a bushe and cough she began h
¶ And with hure fynger assigne made sche
That Damyan shulde clyme vppon a Tre
That charged was with fruyt and vp he went
For verrely he knewe al hure entent
And eủery sygne that she she coude make
Wel bettre than Ianuarie hure owne make
For in a lre she had tolde hym alle
Of this matere hou he werkyn shalle
And thus y lette hym sytte vppon this pirie
And Ianuarie and May romyng ful merie
Bright was the day and blue the firmament
Phebus hath of golde his streames doun sent
That gladen eủery floure with there warmnesse
He was that tyme in Gemynys as y gesse
But litle from his declinacion
Of Cancer Iouis . exaltaciou
And so it befel in that bright morowe tide
That in that Gardeyne in the ferther side
Pluto that is kynge of Fairie
And many a lady in his companie
Folowyng the Quene his wif Proserpina
Which that he ravisshed oute of Cithia
While that she gadred floures in the mede
In Claudian ye may the stories rede
Hou in grislely Carte he hure sette
This kynge of Fairie doun hym sette
Vppon a benche of turves fresshe and grene
And right anon thus seide he to his Quene
Nowe wif qd he there may no wight seye nay
The ful exꝑperience so provith it eủery day
The treasou which that wymmen don to man
X . C . M . ˢ wel tel y can
Notable of youre vntrouth and brotilnesse
O . noble Salamon Richist of Richesse
Fulfilled of Sapience and of worldly glorie
Ful worthy ben thy wordes to memorie
To eủery wight that wit and reason can
Thus preisith he yit the bountie of man
A monge a . M . men yit founde y one
But of wymmen al yit founde y none
Thus seith this kyng that knowith youre wickidnesse
And Iesus filius Sirac as y gesse
Ne spekith of you but selde reủerence
A wilde fire and corrupte pestilence
So fal vppon youre bodies yit to nyght
Ne se ye not this honourable knyght
By cause allas that he is blynde and olde
His owne man shal make hym cockholde
Lo where he sittith the lecchoure on the tre
Nowe shal y graunte of my magiste
Vnto this olde blynde worthy knyght
That he shall haue ageyne his yeen sight
And whan that his wif . wolde don hym a vilanye
Than shal he knowe al hure harlatrie
Bothe in rapref of hure and other mo
Ye Sir . qd . Proserpina wol ye so
Nowe by my Moders soule Sir I you swere
That y shal yeve hure sufficiaunt aunswere
And al wymmen aftur for hure sake
That though they ben in eny gilt take
With face bolde they shul them self excuse

l.seg: And ber them doon þᵗat wold hem acuse

div.l: For lacke of aunswere non of them shull dien
All had aman seyn a thyng with his yeen
Yit shull we wymmen visage it hardely
And wepe and swere and chide subtilly
So that ye men shul be as lewid as gese
What reckith me of youre auctoritese
I wote wel that this Iewe this Salamon
Founde of vs wivis . foles many on
But though that he fonde no good womman
Yit hath there founden many a nother man
Wymmen ful true ful good and vertuous
Witnes of them that wel in cristis hous
With Martirdom they provid there constaunce
The Romayns Iestes eke makyn remembraunce
Of many a verrey true wif also
But sir be not wroth al be it so
Though that he seide he fonde no true womman
I pray you take this sentence of that man
He ment thus that in soủeraygne bountie

l.seg: Nys non but good neyþ̉er he ne sche

div.l: Ey for verrey god that nys but one
What make ye so moche of Salamon
What though he made a Temple goddis house
What though it were riche and gloriouse
He made it a Temple eke of fals goddis
Who myght do a thyng that more for bode is
Parde as feire as ye his name emplastre
He was alechoure and an ydolastre
And in his elde he verrey god for soke
And yif that god ne had as seith the boke
Spared hym for his fadres sake he sholde
Haue lost his reigne rather then he wolde
I set not of al the vilanye
That he of wymmen wrote a buttirflye
I am a wōmman nedes most y speke
Or elles swelle till myn hart breke
For sith he seide that we be Iangeleresses
As eủere hole mot y bouk my tresses
I shall not spare for no curtesie
To spekyn hym harme that wolde vs vilanye
Dame qd this Pluto be no lenger wroth
I yeve it vp . but sith y swore myn oth
That y wolde graunt hym his sight ageyne
My worde shal stande y warne you certeyne
I am kynge it sittith me not to lie
And y qd she a Quene of feirie
Hure aunswere shal she haue y vndertake
Lette vs no mo hereof make
For sothe y woll no lenger you contrarie
Nowe let vs turne ayen to Ianuarie
¶ That in the gardeyn with his faire May
Syngeth merier then the Popyniay
You love y best and shal . and other none
So longe a boute the aleis he is gon
Till he was comen a geyne the pirie
Where as Damyan sittith full merie
An high amonges the fresshe levis grene
This fresshe May that is so bright and shene
Gan for to sygh and seide allas my side
Nowe sir qd she for ought that may betide
I moste haue one of the peris that y se
Or y mot die so sore longith me
To eten of the smale peris grene
Helpe for hure love that is heven Quene
I tel you wel a womman in my plite
May haue to fruyt . so grete an appetite
That she may dien but she it haue
Allas qd he that y haue here no knave
That coude clyme alas alas qd he
For y am blynde. ye Sir no force qd she
But wolde . ye whitsave for goddis sake
The pirie within youre armes for to take
For well y wote that ye mystrust me
Then shulde y clyme wel y nough qd she
So y my fote may set vppon youre backe
Certis qd he thereof shalbe no lacke
Might y helpen you with my harte blode
He stouped doun and she vppon his bak stode
And caught hure a twist and vp she goith
Ladies y praie you that ye be not wroith
I cannot glose y am a rude man
And sodenly anon this Damyan
Gan pullen vppe the smok and in he throng
And when that Pluto saugh this grete wrong
To Ianuarie yave anon his sight
That he myght se aswel as eủere he might
And whan that he had caught his sight a geyne
Ne was ther neủere man of sight so feyne
But on his wif his thought was eủere mo
Vppon the tre he cast his yeen two
And saugh that Damyan . his wif had dressed
In suche mane it may not be expressed
But yif y wolde speke vncurteislye
And vp he yave a roryng and a crye
As doith the Moder . whan the childe shal die
Oute helpe alas harowe he gan to crie
O . stronge ladye store what doist thou
And she aunswerd Sir . what eilith you
Haue pacience and reason yn youre mynde
I haue you holpen of bothe youre yeen blynde
Vppon ꝑperel of my soule y shal not lyen
As me was taught to helen with youre yen
Was nothyng better to make you se
Then to strogle with a man vppon a tre
God wote I did it in ful good entente
Strogle qd he . ye algate . In it went
God yeve you bothe on shames deth to dyen
He swivid the y saugh it with myn yen dhertil
And elles be I hanged by the hals
Sir then is qd she my medicyne fals
For certeyne yif that ye myght se
Ye wolde not sey thise wordes vnto me
Ye haue som glemeryng and no ꝑperfite sight
I se qd he aswel as eủere y myght
Thanked be god with myn yeen two
And by my trouth me thought he did the so
¶ The mase the mase good Sir qd she
This thanke haue y for y haue make you se
Alas qd she that eủere y was so kynde
Nowe dame qd he than let al passe oute of mynde
Com a doun my lef and yif y haue mysseide
God helpe me so . as I am evil apaide
And by my fadris soule y wende haue seyne
Hou that this Damyan had by the leyne
And that thy smok had ben vppon thy brest
Ye Sir qd she ye may seyn as you lest
But Sir a man that wakith oute of his slepe
He may not so sodenly take kepe
Vppon a thyng . ne se it so parfitly
Til that he be awakid verrely
Right so aman that longe hath blynde be
Ne may not sodenly so wel se
First whan his sight is com newe ageyne
As he that hath a day or . ijᵒ . seyne
Therfore bith ware for by heven kyng
Ful many a man weneth to seen a thyng
And yit it is al a nother thyng then it semyth
He that mys conceyvith mys demeth
And with that worde she lepe doun fro the Tre
This Ianuarie who is glad but he
He kissith hure and clippith hure ful ofte
And on hure wombe he strikid hure ful softe
And to his Paleis hom he hath hure ladde
Nowe good men y pray you al beth gladde
Thus endith here my tale of Ianuarie
God blesse vs al and oure lady Seynt Marie
Hic desunt fabula Mercatoris
Et incipit prologus Armigeri
Ex goddis mercy seide oure Oste tho
Nowe suche a wif y pray god kepe me fro
Lo suche sleightis and subtiltees
In wymmen ben . for ay as besie as bees
Ben they vs sely men for to disceive
And from the soth eủere more woll they weive
By this Marchauntis tale it previth wele
But doutles as true as eny stele
I haue a wif though she pore be
But of hure tonge a labbyng shrewe is she
And yet she hath an hepe of vices mo
Therof no force let all suche thyngis go
But wote ye what in counceile be it seide
Me ruyth sore that y am to hure teide
For and y shulde reken eủery vice
Which that she hath y wis y were to nyce
And cause why it shulde reportid be
And tolde to hure of som of this meyne
Of whom it nedith not for to declare
Sen wymmen con vttir suche Chaffare
And eke my wit suffisith not therto
To tellen alle wherfore my tale is do
Squyer com nere yif it youre wil be
And sey somwhat of love for certis ye
Con thereon as moche as eny man
Nay sir qduod he but suche thyng as y can
Seith hartly will for y will not be rebell
Ageyne youre lust a tale y woll you tell
Haue me excused yif y speke a mys
My will is good and lo my tale is thys
At Surrie in the londe of Tartarie
There dwelde a kynge that werred on Russie
Thurgh which there died many a worthy man
This noble kynge was clepid Cambustan
Which in his tyme was of so grete renoun
That there was nowhere yn no regioun
So excellent a lorde of all thyn
Hym lacked nothyng that longeth to a kyng
As of the secte of which that he was born
He kepte his lawe to which he was sworn
And therto he was wise and riche
And piteous and Iust and alway y liche
Sothe of his worde benygne and honorable
And of his corage alway sad and stable
Yonge fresshe and stronge yn armes desirous
As eny Bacheler of all his hous
A faire parsone he was and fortunate
And kepte alway so well his roiall estate
That there nas nowhere suche another man
This noble kyng this Tartre Cambustan
Hadde twey sonnes on̄e Elpheta his wif
Of which the Eldest hight Algarsif
That other sonne was called Camballo
A doughtᵘur had this worthy kyng also
That yongest was and hight Canace
But for to telle you of hure beaute
Hit lieth not in my tonge or my comyng
I dar not vndertake so hygh a thyng
Myn Englisshe eke is insufficient
It most be a Rethoricien excellent
That coude his colours longyng for that arte
Yif he shulde hire discrive eủer y parte
I am no suche y moste speke as y can
And so bifell that when this Cambustan
Hadde xxxᵗⁱ wynter born his diademe
As he was woned fro yere to yere y deme
He lete the feste of his Natiuite
To crien thrughoute Sarrey his Cite
The last Idus of Marche aftur the yere
Phebus the Sonne full Iolif was and clere
For he was in his exaltacion
In Martis face and in his mancion
In aries the colerik hote signe
Ful lusty was the wedir and benygne
For which the foules ageyne the Sonne shene
What for the season and the yonge grene
Ful lowde songen in there affeccions
Hem semed hane geten them proteccion
Ayenst the swerde of wynter kene and colde
This Cambustan of which y haue you tolde
In roiall vestymentis sate on his deis
With diademe full high in his paleis
And holdith his feste so solempne and so riche
That in this worlde was there none liche
Of which yif y shulde tellen all the arrais
Then wolde it occupie a Someres daie
And eke it nedith not for to devise
At eủery cours the ordre of there servise
I woll not tellen of there straunge sewes
Ne of there Swannys ne of there heron fewes
I woll not tarie yon for it is pryme
And for it is no fruyt but lost of tyme
Vnto my first y woll haue my recours
And so it bifell aftᵘur the iiiᵈᵉ Cours
While that the kynge sate thus in his nobleie
Herkyng the mynstrels synge and pleie
Biforn hym at his borde deliciouslie
In at the halle dore all sodenlie
There come a knyght vppon a stede of bras
And in honde a brode mirroure of glas
Vppon his thombe he had a gold ryng
And by his side a naked swerde hangyng
And vp he ridith vnto the high borde
In all the halle ne was there spoke on worde
For merveill of this knyght hym to be holde
Full besily they waiten bothe yonge and olde
This straunge knyght that cam thus sodenly
All armed save his hede full richely
Salueth the kyng Quene and the lordes alle
By ordre as they sitten in the halle
With so high a reủerence and obeisaunce
As well in speche as in his countenaunce
That Gawyn with his olde curtesie
Though he were com ageyne oute of Fairie
Ne coude hym not amende with a worde
And aftur this bifore the high borde
He with a manly voice seide his message Aftur the form
Aftur the forme vsed in his langage
Withoute vice of sillable or of lettre

l.note: And for his tale shulde seme the bettre

div.l: Accordaunt vnto his wordes was his chere
As techechith arte of speche who so that it lere
All be it that y cannot sowne his stile
Ne cannot clymben oủere so high a stile
Yit sey y this as to Coen entent
Thus moche amountith all that eủere he ment
Yif it so be that y haue it in my mynde
He seide the kynge of Arabie of ynde
My liege lorde on this solempne day
